Not that I wouldn't go there again and try something else - I love the idea of being able to choose from small, medium and large plates - and other dishes looked good but it didn't completely blow up my skirt in any particular way.

But just to mention again, the service was stellar. I'd give it 5 stars.
author: Mi M.

description:
After coming here twice for delicious lunches, I had to find a place for a birthday dinner with a party of 14 the day after Thanksgiving - no easy task. Starbelly made it easy, accommodating extra people at the last minute and serving marvelous food and drinks in the comfortable, attractive environs.

The food I've had has always been absolutely scrumptious. The staff is always friendly and I love all of the recycled, elegant decor. 

Out of my party, everyone had at least one course and at least one drink, (many had more than that) and the bill came out to around $40 a person - very good, particularly considering the quality of the food.

It was such a pleasant surprise to be able to have such a great meal with so little stress. I would recommend Starbelly to anyone, for any occasion.
author: Sonia H.

description:
I went to Starbelly yesterday for brunch/lunch.  This is an adorable restaurant.  We sat on the patio.

I had the fish tacos with french fries and a cup of coffee.  I love that they french press the coffee right in front of you!  My tacos were delicious and full of flavor and the fries were perfect.

I will definitely be returning and can't wait to try more dishes on their menu.
author: Sarah K.

description: While their dinner is fantastic, the brunch menu continues to disappoint. The mimosa is small and for same price you can get two, or unlimited mimosas, somewhere else.  The brunch food is bland and the portion sizes at our table seemed small. Step up the brunch Starbelly, I know you can do it!
author: Mark S.

description:
Dearest Starbelly, 

I am sorry I didn't give you as much credit as you deserved the first time around. You are simply amazing. One of my favorite restaurants in the city. I have enjoyed lunch, dinner and even appetizers at gala events from your lovely staff. Thank you for always being there to feed my belly when it was starving for exquisite food.

With love & devotion,
Misty
author: Misty G.

description:
Any Seuss fans out there? Well, there's a book entitled "The Sneetches and Other Stories" that tells the tale of a species of bird-like creatures, some with stars on their bellies and others without. It forms the basis of discrimination amongst their ranks, and much hullabaloo follows entailing removing and stamping on stars. 

It's apropos that this trendy eatery was deemed "Starbelly", for the decidedly hip flock and pack the tables from communal to two top. Askew Grill be gone! At this point in the game, its a battle between the neophiles and the epicurean cognoscenti, so naturally the wait is unbearable. And though the staff is cordial, the waiting area is wee. Benches outside would be nice.

As my dining partner, Oksana T remarked, the open kitchen plays like a Benetton ad; folks of every color bustle about slinging California eats like clockwork. Broken down into small plates, apps, salads, pizzas and mains, the menu caters to every level of hunger swimmingly. 

We claimed the fried clams, soft and cornbread battered with mayo disguised as remoulade (yum, but add some zing to that dip), the grilled octopus on slaw (overly charred), starbelly salad with butter lettuce, goat cheese and cherry tomatoes (boring dressing, needs acidity), and the mushroom pizza with roasted red onions, gruyere and thyme (one dimensional). It's rare when I wouldn't re-order any dishes upon return as none were particularly outstanding, but the prices were reasonable and tasty overall. 

Probably most remarkable is the drink list, but surprisingly not because of their alchemy of the spirits (they only have an inherited beer + wine license). For me, 60% of the allure of a cocktail is in the art of its concoction, yet their "all ages" potions blow me away. Jasmine tea with lemon and sage, served in a coupe glass. Darjeeling tea with lime, basil and egg whites. I will forgo alcohol for creativity.

In conclusion, I prefer the moody, tipplelicious experience at Beretta though likely I'll pop back occasionally to see what's brewing. 

[3.5 stars]
author: Ligaya T.

description:
A castro local, I was excited to try out Starbelly, which replaced Asquew in that "cursed spot" on 16th/market where restaurants just don't seem to be able to make a business.

The place obviously wants to go against the "healthy food" trend and go for comfort food. I have absolutely no problem with comfort food, as anyone who knows me - and my own belly - can attest. But what I had (a roasted porchetta) was so ridiculously swimming in melted fat and uber salty it felt like a joke.

2 stars because the appetizer and service were decent. Still, I won't go back.
author: bart m.

description:
Went there for the 1st time last night.  It just might be my new fav neighborhood joint.  I loved everything i ate.... except for the dessert.  We ordered the bread pudding..  it was dense and not flavorful.   also its too small to share.  I was surprised by how small it was, compared to the dinner portion sizes.  Harvy Milk ice cream was yummy.

Make the bread pudding better and bigger..  otherwise i loved this place.
author: Marcia B.

description:
We had a 7:30 reservation and waited 20 minutes for our table on a weekday as the place was busy. For us, waiting 20 minutes seems excessive when you have a reservation but we waited patiently nonetheless. The hostess appeared terribly frazzled but was very nice. 

When we were finally seated we experienced friendly but extremely slow service. Now we don't mind a leisurely dinner but the wait in between courses was too long. We actually had to get out of our seats to find our server just to get a check. 

We ordered three salumi (which were very good), mache and grilled peach salad, cornmeal fried oysters (meh) and a sausage, broccolini and lemon zest pizza with pecorino. 

The food was good but we prefer Beretta's food AND service.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Starbelly is a place with great ambiance to enjoy solid food with good friends.  

Perhaps my friends and I did a poor job selecting dishes, but half were pretty good, while the other half weren't bad.  I would highly recommend the pate (it was quite delish), but not the mixed salumi pizza (tasted kinda ordinary).  The veggie pizzza that we had (I forget which) was pretty good too.  The crust was perfectly thin (near paper-thin) and the toppings were just about enough - to the point where you didn't want more, but maybe could have had more, but maybe more would have been too much. 

The service was good.  Our waitress was observant and kept the water refills coming.  That's always a good sign.

 The price was right too.  Bob Barker would have agreed.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Fun, reasonable restaurant with a great selection of pork treats.  I'm in between three (service) and four (food) stars, and opted for three stars.

Gruyere Grits with welted greens - delicious, not too cheesy but the gruyere gave the grits a great flavor.  The greens also gave the impression of a somewhat healthy dish, and broke up the carb-bonanza.

Broccolettes - Decent, don't know if I'd order it again, but was not disappointed.

Mussles with housemade chorizo - delicious, the chunks of chorizo gave the muscles a spicy flavor.

House cured bacon, jalapenos and arugula pizza  - BOMB.com.  One of the best I've had.  I'm usually a fan of deep dish, but the thin crust and combination of ingredients made this pizza really stand out for me.  I highly recommend any bacon lover to try this.  You won't be disappointed.

Other pluses were the fun atmosphere and creative drinks.  So far, sounds like a great review, but the service was on the blah side.  I went with a friend on a late Saturday night, and we didn't mind waiting... but it was the fact that I saw a few empty tables and it took the staff awhile to turn them.  In addition, when I entered the restaurant, it took at least five minutes before I was acknowledged by the hostess.  I totally understand you're with other customers, but you still look at the other patrons smile, or when you leave just a polite, "I'll be back shortly to assist you" would have been nice.  I'm not going to call anyone out, but there was definitely some staff working really hard, while others were just hanging out and seemed "confused" that they were at work.
author: Laura H.

description: Burger was great. Get it "Docs style" with a 2" piece of chicken liver pate on it. Salads, pizza and burata were uninspiring. They charged for bread, which was weird. No liquor license, but they have a really good beer and wine list.
author: Michael J.

description:
I've always enjoyed Beretta so thought I would give Starbelly a chance (it's closer to my house). Like other Yelp reviewers, I came away disappointed. My friend and I ordered:

- Pate (at the urging of the waiter - I told him I don't like pate but he said "everyone loves this pate". I didn't but my friend did.
- Little gems salad (this was the highlight of the meal)
- Margherita pizza + prosciutto. Generally I believe that prosciutto makes everything better (if not amazing), but sadly, I was still not that blown away by the pizza. I think the people next to us got the burrata pizza and that looked much better.

What I did like:
- Our server was really nice. Filled the water regularly.
- The toasted, olive oil soaked bread that came with the pate was off the chain. They have this at Beretta as well.

Conclusion: I think I'll probably just stick with Beretta, even if it is a few more blocks. It'll give me time to walk off those carbs.
author: ramya r.

description:
Normally I feel comfortable commenting on a restaurant after one visit, but with Starbelly I felt two visits were needed. Like many, I was excited to see a restaurant with a decent pedigree enter the Castro. Quality food in the gayborhood was at hand. Well after waiting awhile for the hubbub to die down--well, it hasn't. I figured out the secret of calling 45 min ahead to get on the list (and wait 90 minutes or more) for a table at what is quite the hot dining spot.

Well, two visits later, the word that most comes to mind when I think of Starbelly is uneven, especially foodwise. I've sampled elements of pretty much each part of the menu, and they ranged from delicious to just not working at all. The chorizo mussels were full of flavor, cooked perfectly, and generous, while the crab hush puppies were a bit more concept than delivery. The blue cheese, pear, arugula and ham pizza was dominated by the cheese, and the crust was limp and damp. The burger I had on my first visit was delicious, as were the fries. On my second visit, the lamb chops I ordered were very despondency's flavor, but so fatty that I think I only got about one or two meaty bites per lamb chop. (In that dish's defense, the generous portion of grits on the plate were amazing.) In all, the quality of the food seems to depend on what you order.

This was not true of the service; it was consistently good... not rushed, attentive, and friendly. Also, the servers seem to be well-versed in the nicely rounded wine list. Also the host really does try to get the patient in pretty much as promised.

Despite the curse of their location, I hope Starbelly makes it. With time, I hope some of the unevenness of the food mellows out into what could be a really great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Based on the concept and the reviews I've read, I was expecting a lot from Starbelly. However, overall our meal had an equal amount of hits and misses, which provided for a mediocre experience.  

The good: The crab hushpuppies were chock full of seafood and fried to perfection, the burger was flavorful and the salted caramel pot de creme made me want to lick the jar it was served in. 

The bad: The popcorn clams were nothing out of the ordinary, the grilled salad sounded fabulous on paper, but in reality was overly salty, which ruined the flavor for me and the french fries were soggy. 

With so many great places to explore in the Bay Area, it's hard to think about coming back to Starbelly when it really was underwhelming.
author: Lee H.

description:
It's funny that another reviewer said that she went there for a reunion with a friend, because my friend and I also came here after not seeing each other for a long time! It was great to see her, but it was ALSO great to eat here! 

We started with the sardines and the bufala, and I found both to be yummy. My friend hadn't had fresh sardines before and wasn't necessarily a fan, but if you like fresh sardines, they were fantastic. I don't get that much where I live, and it was a treat. The bufala was creamy and delicious on the garlic toast.

Both my friend and I had pizza as our main event. I don't remember which one my friend got because I was so focused on my own, which was with fig, blue cheese, and arugula. Yum. My only regret is that I couldn't scarf it all down--though I took the rest with me, I wasn't game for it after it sat out in my hotel room. Certainly meant to be enjoyed at its prime. My palate may be skewed from living in DC--i.e. good pizza desert--but the crust had a lovely flavor.

I was sort of concerned being seated right inside the front door, that the in and out of people might be distracting, but I found the environment comfortable and fun. Definitely give it a try!
author: Christine G.

description:
I wasn't blown away nor was I disappointed.  Heard lots of hype but honestly didn't think it was as great as I thought it would be.  It's partially my fault, as I took a wrong turn and screwed up my order.  I had the roasted porchetta, with salsa verde, and salsa calabria.  I love me some pork, but I guess not as much as I thought.  That dish was definitely intended for someone else that enjoys goin' downtown on pigs guts.  I guess the preference is similar to that of liking crispy bacon over the rubbery fatty bacon not cooked as long.   I should have had the rotisserie chicken.  (My friend's dish was great).  Our crab hush puppies appetizer plate was really good though...  Best part for me, the dessert!  

Overall, the place is new, fresh, and great service.   Seating was easy, and the staff was really friendly and enthused.  I think I need to go back and try  a different dish before I totally form an opinion.
author: DJ P.

description:
I came to Starbelly on a perfectly sunny Sunday morning for brunch with my bf and friend.  We got here early enough to get an outside table in their back patio - so cute!  There are huge umbrellas if you need it and a darling little herb garden.  

Our waitress was amazing.  She knew the menu very well and her recommendations helped us settle on what we were going to eat.  I hearted her!

Here's what we got.
Greek yogurt and farm fresh fruit:  A delicious way to start the meal.  The bowl was loaded with berries, bananas, kiwi, pineapple and cantaloupe all over a hearty serving of yogurt.  

Asparagus, black garlic, mozzarella cheese, egg, truffle oil pizza:  It was definitely something that I've never had before and was pretty good.  The crust was yummy and there were tons of asparagus spears but the center part was a little too drenched and soggy.  We still finished the whole thing though!

Sunnyside Joe's: A delicious combo of perfectly seasoned ground beef, sauteed veggies, cheese and two sunny side up eggs (next time I'll get the eggs over medium) all in a mini cast iron pan.  We got it with potatoes and a side salad which I definitely recommend.  It looks small, but is really very filling and tasty.

BLT: We wanted to get the BLT for the house cured bacon, but unfortunately it was forgotten.  We immediately forgave them because 1. we were already pretty stuffed, and 2. our waitress brought over a salted caramel donut.  The donut was standard, but the salted caramel was what made it.  It was delish and I licked up every bit of it.

All in all, I am a fan of the place.  Getting your food may be a wee bit slow (on a busy brunch day), but the atmosphere, service and food more than make up for that.  Plus, our tab was under $20 a person.  

I will be back again to try more things on the menu!
author: Sara T.

description:
This place is just soooo goood!! We had a group of 8 and were able to easily make a group reservation the day before. Everyone in our party enjoyed their brunch, drinks, and service. The service was fantastic! The prices were just right ($32/person, including tax & tip) and the setting was bright, airy, and modern. Perfect brunch place. The Castro desperately needed a place like this! 

I had the pulled chicken sandwich with fries - yum! My girlfriend had the decadent chorizo & egg pizza - Wow! Several of our friends had burgers and they were all very pleased. They even serve Micheladas (beer with lemon juice, served in a salt & chile rimmed glass)!!

Can't wait to return!!
author: Patricia Z.

description: I only moved to the city and I think I've now been to starbelly 5x! I've been for dinner and brunch and have always found the staff to be great and accommodating both with and w/o rezzos. The pate is A MUST!!! I've also had the burger, thin crust pizza with figs and the chicken salad for brunch. I'll for sure keep coming back, enjoy!
author: Jaimisa G.

description:
I've driven by numerous times & felt myself drawn in by the bottle display in the window. But I won't lie.. what really sealed the deal was hearing Starbelly had made the 7x7 Big Sweet list. Having made a mental note to one day visit (yes, I do judge a restaurant by its window display), I finally found the right occasion in planning the BFF's birthday dinner. 

Service: We had a group of 10, and the restaurant was wonderful in getting our large group seated quickly & with drinks, even in light of friends running late. This coming off of another birthday dinner, where the other restaurant wouldn't seat us until all members of the party were present, delaying the meal by almost an hour.

I came for the toffee cake, but I found myself pleasantly surprised by all the dishes. For starters, the hush puppies, fries, and bread were decent. The heirloom tomato salad was a refreshing counterpart to the deep fried & carbs, but I've tasted better. Tomato soup was deelish, but I was a bit disappointed by the accompanying grilled cheese sammie, which was unfortunately not grilled to perfection and lacked the requisite grill marks. Margherita pizzas were fab, as was the pork shoulder, which was surprisingly akin to a braised short rib. I loved how thick and chewy the spaghetti noodles were, and my lavender honey lemonade was nice and sweet. As for desert, toffee cake was the best, followed by the salted caramel pot de creme and peach dessert. YUM. Everyone was satisfied with their respective dishes, and so I give Starbelly a resounding two thumbs up!
author: Erika C.

description:
From the Beretta team, Starbelly opened in what's becoming a hot place for new restaurants, the Castro. Parking isn't too bad...if you can't park on the street (usually not too bad) there's a lot across the corner. OK. It totally sucks that they don't take reservations but I called ahead and got our name on the list. Ten minutes at the front of house was long enough to order a bottle of Monastrell. Two sips in and we were escorted to our table.

I'm guessing the place seats about sixty plus a few at the bar. Some out back as well when the weather permits. We got a table by the back window and went to ordering. The menu offers "snacks", salads, small  plates, pizzas and a handful of entrees. I had mini corn dogs with spicy mustard & house made ketchup and house cut fries with three dips, both from the snacks menu. My guest ordered market apple & celery root salad, pistachio & dried cherries. All were very good. The dips for the fries were very good. Some of the better fries in town (though not as good as those at Ramblas, my new faves). My entree was fresh spaghetti, starbelly bacon, jalapeno, tomato & basil. Good to the last strand. My guest had the Prather Ranch burger, house cut fries & pickle, grilled sesame bun. Very good as well.

Service was friendly and fine. Ambiance was busy but relaxed. Full of couples and friends, I didn't see a single kid. Fine. Not really a kid place. Food was good to very good. Parking OK. I wish they took reservations (same for Beretta). A nice evening out.
author: Gary C.

description:
The best part about this place is the atmosphere. The inside is cute, with the corrugated cardboard light fixtures, and the back patio is just adorable.

The food has been hit or miss. The first time I came for lunch, everything was delicious. I had a burger and it was cooked to perfection, and the fries were tasty. But I came here for my birthday brunch and was disappointed, along with the rest of my party. The meals were just so-so. Everything was way too greasy. I could only finish about half my meal before I could feel it sitting in my stomach like a big brick. The grits were good, though.

Overall, it's a cute place for lunch, but definitely does not live up to the stellar recommendations people have given me.
author: Geno B.

description:
Now that I've been here 3 times, I can say that it has been alot better!!
They now take reservations and their wait time management is more organized and efficient!  The waiters here are great.

The food presentation is a lot better! I can now enjoy my meals here without loosing my patience over the wait time :)  Thanks Starbelly.
author: Alvin M.

description:
I had a dinner to plan for a party of 10 and recently found out its nearly impossible to get a reservation between 5:30 and 10 in San Francisco.  However, the folks at Starbelly were very accomodating and got us in at 7:45.

We sat in the back patio area on a long picnic table, which was the perfect ambiance.  The heat lamp above us was blazing, but our server turned it off without a problem.  She was super nice and made us all feel welcome.  I never had that feeling of being the burdensome large party from anyone who interacted with us.

I really enjoyed the beer list and the Shandy (beer and lemonade), as well as the chicken liver pate, warm spinach salad and Starbelly bacon pizza with jalapenos and green goddess dressing.  We were all amazed at the size of the pate and the great mound of grilled bread with it.

I was disappointed in the sardines though.  We expected a few little ones, but it was one whole fish that was hard to eat.

I would like to go back during the day on the weekend and sit in the back with the covering pulled back.  Would be a nice spot.
author: Neila M.

description: Nice addition to the Castro. Interesting and delicious menu. Will return for certain!
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Oh Starbelly why have I not reviewed you yet!
Love love this place and had an exceptional meal here the other night. 
It was a good friends birthday and a few of us gathered here for an early dinner. 
We were seated on the patio almost right away even though we didn't have a reservation (awesome) and started off with a bottle of merlot the waiter recommended, it was delicious and actually worth the $50!!
With five people we definitely over ordered but we were incredibly satisfied! As a new totally vegan lady I had a slightly hard time finding things but I ate my way around the cheese in the starbelly salad and absolutely loved the veggie burger sans curry yogurt :-)
My friends had an assortment of pizzas and apps and highly recommended the chorizo pizza and the lentil soup!
We ordered the bread pudding for dessert and they graciously stuck a candle in it and helped us sing happy birthday to my friend. 
It was a perfect night on the patio and the overall vibe was so welcoming and comfortable. Thank you Starbelly!!
author: Andrea K.

description:
I love this place.  Try their rotisserie chicken for a true treat -- it melts in your mouth.  Their pizzas are also very good if you want to eat something more traditional.

Also, love the service.  They're fast, nice, and accommodating.  This is one of my fav restaurants and definitely recommend you to try!
author: J L.

description: Solid food. Great atmosphere with cool wood, cool lighting, cool people and cool waitstaff. Food was comforting and ingredients are all top notch.. they seemed organic. I would go back anytime.
author: Ari R.

description:
I was disappointed. 

Be prepared for a long wait and for your server to bring you the wrong thing.  I shared a salad, pizza, mini-corn dogs, and beer.  

Eh.
author: Carol L.

description:
Very Cool and Hip Restaurant, I came here on a tuesday night and it was quite busy.

While the atmosphere may have impressed, the entree I ordered was A-OK. 

I ordered their Prather Ranch Burger (medium) with roasted onions and I was really expecting more out of it after hearing from others that their burgers were good. It really needed more salt or something, the patty was thick, but it didn't really have any flavor.

I was also surprised that they charged $2 for cheese, avocado, bacon, and roasted onions.

If you were to take the original burger and add all the extra toppings, it would have easily been $19

I will give this place another shot, but will be staying away from their burgers.

I do like that they give you an option between regular water and sparkling water
author: Eric A.

description:
I've passed by this place so many times so when a friend suggested we double date there, I thought why not.

The Bummer:
-Had a reservation for 8:00, didn't get seated until 8:45 (not a big deal).  The host was nice enough to get us a round of drinks
-The pizza had a paltry amount of cheese 
-The french fries starter was over priced for what you it was.  Should be more like $3.00 or something
-Very loud inside, hard to hold a conversation

The Pleasing:
-Host was kind enough to get us a round of drinks while we waited.  Good customer service insight
-The pizza I ordered had pear slices on it...my favorite fruit...just needed some cheese on it
-The Pâté was good, and the bread was robust
-As a whole, the food was reasonably priced and the service was good.

The Low Down:
I'd go back.  Am I a raving fan? No, but the place is a bit above average.  If the pricing was a bit higher I'm afraid I'd have to take away a star.  So keep the pricing where it is and I think the place will do well.

That's my  2 cents.  Cheers.
author: Blake J.

description: LOVE Starbelly. One of our favorite neighborhood places. Excellent food, greg drinks, great outdoor patio. Also a great place for larger groups!
author: Michael S.

description:
Food, service, ambiance all awesome!!
The Starbelly pizza is my favorite!
Can't wait to go back!!
author: O. S.

description:
I like their option of having still or sparkling water. 

Their fries with trio dip are delicious! maybe just a little overpriced tho!

Also the chicken sandwhich with radish is AMAZING!!!

Service is also great, Menu should have more selection though.
author: NC B.

description:
I like Starbelly for many reasons.  The first and foremost - it is spitting distance from my front door.  But beyond that, the people who came up this concept did a great job.

They took a mediocre space and made it better than mediocre - reasonably comfie and with a patio out back.  They hired in staff that seem to care about good service and good food and take pride in their work.  And they created a robust wine menu with a nice smattering of wines to select from.  And finally, they put together a diverse menu with something for pretty much everyone.

I would consider this a great place to go for a conversation or a date.  

And despite my earlier comment related to proximity for me, it does have location, location, location going for it (centrally located in the Castro district).

I recommend giving it a try and I betcha you'll like it.
author: Dennis H.

description:
How does the saying go...."All show and no go".

First off the hostess is a hot little number and I give her 5 stars from an eye candy perspective. If only that wasn't the best part of the meal. 

Cool decor, nice ambiance, alotta of guys, but we are on16th and Market so what else could one expect. Went there for brunch and I have to say I was dissappointed. 

As one last reviewer pointed out, they are new and like an awkward teenager. I can give you a little leeway in this area while the place finds its legs, but some of my issue are issues that will not change even once they have their stuff together. 

Here is my list of complaints

1) Waitress that rolls her eyes when  you ask her for stuff, she was working the front of the restaurant around noon today if any management is reading this.  Multiple times by the way, it was as if we were bothering her with our requests and she did not know the menu very well. If it were my business I would give her the axe.

2) Homemade catsup sounds good on paper, but honestly that stuff would be better served if you called it chipolte salsa. I am a catsup lover. I hate when restaurants do this to look cool. It never is good, anyone that loves catsup usually love Heinz.. Offer both. Yours is a dissappointment with my potatoes.  There is a reason why heinz catsup has a 60% market share in the USA. 

3. Food came out all over the place. I ordered their (delicious, a must order) donut and coffee for starters. 10 minutes later the donut comes out without the coffee. When I asked my server for my coffee, her curt response was, "I told you the coffee is french pressed and has to steep" she forgot that she had also said that it takes about 4 minutes and this was 10 minutes later. I ordered a side of eggs and they came out before my food did and were semi cold. My semi warm french toast , which is mediocre at best was supposed to come with fruit, it did not, I had to ask the waitress where the fruit was, for which she told me it did not come with any. I asked her to grab the menu, and of course I was right and she was wrong. Lastly I asked for my bacon to be extra crispy and it came out cooked medium and I had to send it back. 

What a dissappointment. Although the pizza smelled amazing. 

My recommendation is drop the server, hire more hot chicks like the petite brunette at the door and get your food shit together. The place has potential. It is just not there yet.
author: D M.

description:
I went there for Sunday morning brunch and I really enjoyed it.  It had friendly staff, an open decor, quality food and a great drinks menu.  They have a nice heated outdoor patio area in the back too, but we sat inside.

I ordered chilaquiles, which were just ok, mostly because it probably wasn't the right dish for me at any restaurant, but everyone else's meals looked great.  I'd probably try the pizza with the egg on it when I go back again.  The server seemed a bit frazzled today, but was friendly.  Because it was a lazy Sunday morning, I didn't mind waiting a bit.

I also had a hot toddy.  It rocked.
author: Reuben S.

description:
what a nice place in the hood.

service, atmosphere and food were all very good.

Chicken liver pate - great flavor, fresh and complimenting other ingredients.

spaghetti with bacons - enough said, it was delicious.

fish taco - wouldn't normally go for fish taco but it was fresh and yummy

salted caramel pot de creme - huge portion and the cookies and pot de creme compliment each other very well.. very nicely done!

service was awesome as well.
will totally go back again to try their Porchetta sandwich.
author: Sung C.

description: I was intrigued by the spaghetti with bacon and jalapeños, so I got that. At first I thought the portion was a bit small, but it turned out to be the right amount of food, especially since we got the fries as well. Great stuff! Oh, and the pot de creme is outstanding and super decadent. Drake's amber to wash it all down. Great, simple decor (did you see the styrofoam cups on the ceiling for acoustic purposes?) and great attentive service. Looking forward to coming back.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Great food.  We ended up splitting pizzas as starters and I got one of the brunchy egg dishes.  Everything was delicious.  I was definitely pleasantly surprised with the pizza--good toppings, tasty crust.  I can say the fig and blue cheese was delicious, as was the bacon and jalapeno.   Also, cute (and heated when necessary) covered patio seating in the back.
author: Lauren C.

description:
My my you are buuusssyyyy aren't you?  We popped in here last night at around 6:30 with a party of 4 and were told our wait would be about 50 minutes. It was actually about an hour and a half.  They were fairly gracious to be honest, but the wait was interminable. There is not really a good place to just "hang out" here but we made it happen at the edge of bar.  I would note that our observation was that they have WAYYYY more two tops here so I'd suggest sticking to that dining size until further notice. 

Once we were seated we really did enjoy perusing the menu, they have some awesome virgin drinks which we really appreciated with one of us on the wagon and another on antibiotics.  We started with the mixed peppers in olive oil and salt and they were fab. We also had the corn with marscapone which, while a small portion, was fabulous.  We also enjoyed the japanese cucumber salad and the muscles.  Of note, the salad is also very small, I'd share it with two people max.  The dressing on the salad really made the cucumbers pop! 

For our mains we had the spagetti which was good, but perhaps a little too bacon-y for my taste.  The romano (I think...) beans with tomatoes were excellent as was the mushroom pizza.  Yum! 

Our waitress was a gem and was very attentive, which was hard given our packed in location at the community table.  She gets 5 stars for good service. 


As we walked out of the restaurant at 9:15 pm I noted that a variety of tables had opened up so I would suggest hitting this hot new spot after the 9 pm time slot and you can avoid the never-ending wait that accompanies any new dining location.  

All in all I'm pleased that we have a nice, new local resto.  Given I live a mere 2 blocks away I'm sure that we will return and get to enjoy some of the other gems on the menu. The pate walked by and my mouth watered.  I'm also looking forward to the lamb cheeks.  Welcome to the Castro!
author: Claire C.

description:
Seriously, it's gotten to the point that even if I'm with people I prefer to wait for a seat at the bar rather than at a table in most restaurants, and Starbelly is no exception.  Yuka is another of m favorite bartenders, who even at 11:30 p.m. seems like she just started her shift.  When some people in her position can't even bother to fake a smile, she is just genuinely friendly, pleasant, helpful, and always in a good mood.  

What keeps this place from getting five stars is that they don't have a full bar.   I personally avoid the "mocktails," but I've got to hand it to the bar manager that they're doing just about everything they possibly can without spirits, including a madeira-based hot toddy and a housemade "Pimm's cup."  That's pretty creative.
author: Sven E.

description:
Stopped in during SF Beer Week for a Barrel Aged event.  They had it out on the back patio that was covered and had some infrared heaters.  It was 45ish outside and we were very comfortable out there.  The place is pretty cool and was very crowded, we didnt try the food but will the next time we are in San Francisco. 

The tasting was well organized and had some rare vintages from Portland, OR and a local brewery.  The pours were decent sized and they had paired some appetizers with the selection.  Good location although parking was a bit tough.  Definitely stop in if you are in that area.
author: Thomas S.

description:
Overall: Good food (harmonious pairing of ingredients), fair prices, worth a second visit.

Friday night, dinner, party of 2, 8-ish.  After reading yelp reviews about the long wait, I expected much worse. Called 40 min ahead, got there exactly when the 40 mins was up and waited 20 mins.  The patrons here all seem very hip. Service was friendly.

Apps: Fries w/3 dipping sauces (ok, could use a little more salt); popcorn clams (oysters?).  It tasted like calamari, maybe it was.  Roasted beets w/some cheese-- tasty.

Pizzas: We got two (1): the jalapeno w/bacon w/goddess dressing.  Delicious and oh yeah, I felt the fire burn in my mouth.  (2) Squash pizza w/pine nuts-- had an nice sweetness and crunch from the earthy pineuts.  I've never had a pizza like this at all, in either texture or flavor.
I'll go back for their other pizzas.

Dessert: sticky toffee pudding.  Can't really go wrong with this. I love sticky toffee anything!

Vibe: warm, kinda hip, comfortable.  I wish this were in my hood! There are a few two-top bar-level tables in the back, against the wall.  Those have far more privacy than the two-tops at the front of the restaurant.
author: Caroline I.

description:
Just went to the test dinner tonight at Starbelly.

The noise level was a little high - not a lot of sound wave absorbion here, so you need to shout a bit when the place is full.

The interior is gorgeous, with a lovely patio out back.

Madeira Cobbler - absolutely awesome and refreshing drink.  Highly recommended.

House cut fries with three dips - The fries were made *perfectly* with a fantastic fresh potato, perfectly salted, and nice and crispy.  The three sauces were a fresh and delicious basil aioli, Old Bay remoulade, and a house-made catsup.  I'm not really a fan of catsup to start, and this was a little too sweet for me.  The remoulade and aioli were both fantastic.

Heirloom tomato gazpacho with spicy avocado & basil oil was lovely, but under salted.  Once we added a bit of salt, it was fantastic.

Roasted Mariquita Farms padron peppers, sea salt & olive oil - These were slightly undercooked and underseasoned, but overall they were very fresh and delicious.  I attribute it to the first night jitters.

Guanciale pizza with wild nettles and parmesan - Absolutely delicious.  It's a flatbread style pizza with a cheesy and tangy sauce.  I liked it, my partner wasn't a huge fan.  He thought the taste of the nettles was lost and tasted too similar to broccoli rabe.  

Prather Ranch burger, house cut fries, and pickle, grilled brioche bun - This burger was perfect in every single way. Absolutely awesome.
author: Cameo W.

description:
I immediately bookmarked Starbelly as soon as I saw all the twitters, daily candy, urban daddy, etc. Same owners as Beretta? I'm there. 
Yesterday I checked the reviews before I dined just to see how it was faring and was shocked. Yikes! I didn't let it sway me I was still going to give it a shot. Well I'm glad I did. 
The decor is great, like I knew it would be (complete with my favorite communal dining table)...and the garden/dining area outside? Can't wait till it's open. They have some amazing "art" installations by Flora Grubbs and boxes filled with herbs, lettuce, tomatoes. I hope they're planning to use it in their food. 
My friend and I decided to share a bunch of the smaller plates. We had the fries with three dipping sauces (only the aioli was worth dipping), mini corndogs (same mustard and catsup as the fries, boring), fresh corn with marscapone (too small of a portion!), butter lettuce salad with hazelnuts and figs (I hate blue cheese, but this was good!), and the heirloom tomato gazpacho with avocado (by far my favorite item of the night). For dessert we had the peaches with olive oil ice cream from Humphrey. Good combination, but a little on the pricey side for the portion and basically no preparation (this did not take a pastry chef to prepare). 
Service was superb. I definitely think they've taken these bad reviews and worked out the kinks. Our server explained items come out as they're prepared (what I prefer...course style), so to let them know if we wanted it all at once. 
We got there a little after 6 and it was pretty empty, but it filled up fast. I'm sure the wait will be Berettaish in no time.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Let me start with the only poor thing I can say... we could not eat on the back patio... because the neighbors complain that the restaurant is too loud (really? you live in a city... )

That out of the way... the food was fantastic... 

I hate to admit that what stands out particularly in my mind was the cocktail... the house made Pimm's Cup... wow.

A few weekends ago I met a friend here for brunch, and we both enjoyed the food, the drinks and the overall experiences tremendously... and well worth the wait to get in the door (thank goodness that there were only two of us...)

This place is definitely in rotation for me in the Castro for dinner... but just waiting for things to die down... 

Luckily the Castro is going through its own culinary revolution right now... so more great restaurants are just around the corner
author: Jordan Y.

description:
Damn you Starbelly and you tantalizingly low prices.

The 10oz. pours of draught beers for $3 or $4 are a brilliant strategy, as are the $5 snacks. Cheap enough to make me order it, expensive enough for me to be annoyed at myself at the end.

The tomato soup with toast was good, nothing special. The pizza with bleu cheese and figs was delicious. Quite fresh; and unlike most places, they didn't burn the crust.

Might be a better idea to go back and do tapas-style.
author: Mark A.

description:
I love you Starbelly. 

Not only is your name cute but you fill my belly with fantastic eats! From the home brewed ginger kombucha, crispy shoestring fries and dipping sauces to the delicious pizzas and pasta with bacon. Oh the bacon. Thick cut pieces that pepper many of the dishes here. So good. The food is always fresh and the service very friendly and prompt. They have a nice patio in the back too. I've had lunch and dinner and every visit is consistently good.
author: Lindsay H.

description:
A very charming dinner spot for couples or small groups of friends.  We hit up Starbelly this last Wednesday with no reservation and they sat 4 of us right away.  Menu was reminiscent of Beretta with a strong pizza showing and smaller plates of seafood, veggies, and meats. 

I had the fried smelt appetizer and a salad.  Friends had the pizzas.   Nothing was too original but everything was well-made with fresh ingredients.  Love the outdoor patio area & the rustic looking wood walls.  Def a cute Castro spot that we'll go to again.
author: Sid D.

description:
I had been waiting to try Starbelly for what seemed like an eternity (call me impatient). Recently, the wait finally ended! Hurrah!

I have to go back again. My dining companion was dying to try the burger, and, I mean, I love a good burger as much as the next girl, but in my opinion you can't top Pearl's Teriyaki burger, so it was sort of a wasted effort. Good burger tho.

I will say, the other courses we shared were really very good. Tomato soup with tiny crostini grilled cheese? Maybe the best tomato soup I've had (and this combo is well-tested by me). Butter lettuce wedge salad? Delicioso--if you're a butter lettuce fan, which I definitely am. For dessert, well, I missed an opportunity to try Humphrey Slocombe's Secret Dessert ice cream, but market peaches with Harvey Milk ice cream, made me quickly forget my disappointment. 

Until I try some of their more adventurous dishes, I have to say that I was most impressed by the service! I haven't experienced such professional and attentive service since... well I don't know when. A+ for that, it really made the dining experience special. 

Next time I go, perhaps it won't be winter in August, because the back patio looked like it had the potential to be very inviting, and I LOVED the framed "paintings" of greenery on the wall. Overall, the decor was a little different than I expected, but very nice--polished and modern but warm. One point against it: the chairs seemed to be about an inch or so lower than the banquette. Odd, no? Made my date feel like he was at the kid's table. No bueno. That could use some reconsideration.

Conclusion: I will be back, Starbelly, I will be back. And perhaps then your will gain another star for your... um... belly?
author: Sara W.

description:
3 gals, a bottle of wine, great food, and fabulous service.
I LOVED my dinner at Starbelly!  
warm spinach salad with pears, crunchy onions, toasted almonds was amazing and fresh!
i went with a safe choice, the burger, for my entree and i was glad i did.  Cooked to perfection with white cheddar and tasty fries.  The old bay remoulade I got with the fries was incredible.
author: Meg D.

description:
I think this place has great potential for a 4 star rating. They had lots of delicious things on their menu - amazing sounding pizzas, pate toasts, hush puppies, etc. BUT, we didn't order any of those. We got the burger instead, which I was totally excited about. Because I LOVE BURGERS. However, disappointed was I. The burger was pretty tasteless, even with the bleu cheese that I added. It was disappointing :(

I would though come back to try the other stuff. Skip the burger though.
author: Carol L.

description:
Every time I come here I promise myself that I'll get something else besides the cheeseburger...and every time I fail gloriously. The burgers here could almost compete head-to-head with the best in town.

The beer selection is quite interesting, although they're simply ripping you off in some cases. Seven dollars for a glass of Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA? No thanks, I'll go to Lucky 13 and get it for three dollars instead. 

The food was sometimes oddly priced as well. Four dollars for an appetizer of fried oysters: not bad. But the waiter will inform you that there are three to an order, so if there are two of you and you want to share, he can add one more for an additional two dollars. What? Just sell four for four. Otherwise it kind of seems scammy.

Otherwise, I love the decor, the service has always been good, I've always gotten a table, and the food, once again, is great (delicious homemade ketchup!) But I can only give it the four stars because of their curious pricing.
author: Chris H.

description: Good brunch in the Castro. Wait usually isn't too bad. I enjoy the French Toast. For the Castro I'd rather go to Bisou which has slightly better food and bottomless mimosas.
author: T S.

description:
The Castro finally gets a quality restaurant!  I went to the test dinner and tried most everything on the menu.  We were with a large group so it was easy.  I loved the mussels with chorizo.  Another hit was the mushroom pizza.  The crust was thin and crunch and the pizza was not over loaded with toppings.  I can't list everything I loved because that list is way too long.  The only item that fell flat with most of us was the mini corn dogs.  The texture of the meat was way too soft.  It reminded me of a vienna sausage that had been deep fried.  Hopefully that item is dropped from the menu or greatly improved.  I really hate having anything bad to say but, I have to be honest on that one item.

The interior is light and very crisp.  They have simple touches that I really loved like the mixed flatware rather than everything matching.  

The deserts were very fresh and sized so they were not overwhelming after a meal.  They also offer french press coffee, desert wines and cocktails.
author: Carl C.

description:
I've lived in SF for a year and still can't list more than two restaurants in the Castro that I've eaten at. I don't know why, but when I think of the Castro, I think of things other than food: cheap and stiff drinks, cheaper and stiffer boys, and the awful 33 Muni line. But after going to Starbelly, I've decided that I need to eat out in the Castro more often (no pun intended, ew).

I walked into the restaurant and immediately noticed that the decor is simple and modern, which is a nice change from the overall loud aesthetic that you get from most establishments in the Castro. Started off with a Pimm's cup, which was crisp and delicious-- just like how a Pimm's cup should be. The menu is pretty varied; however, I ordered the spaghetti because I wanted something simple after working a 12-hour day at work. I usually refrain from getting any type of pasta because I follow this ethic of not ordering food at restaurants that I can easily make myself, but this spaghetti was pretty damn delicious. The pasta was perfectly al dente, the marinara sauce was fresh and flavorful and didn't taste bland as if it were jarred/canned like most places (which is another reason why I avoid pasta dishes at restaurants), and the crispy bacon bits really were the best part of the entree. I would happily order this again and again.

There was only one negative aspect of this meal. After my Pimm's cup, I asked for a Tom Collins and our waitress told me that they only serve beer and wine and their specialty cocktails, so she was going to ask the bartender what they could do. I didn't mind too much because I've been to a ton of restaurants that have similar schticks. She comes back and tells me that the bartender recommends that I get some other drink on the menu without telling me what was in it. I said sure, assuming that the bartender knew what a Tom Collins was and that he was going to pick something that was a little similar. Wrong. Instead, our waitress comes back with a sparkling wine cocktail that had no resemblance of a Tom Collins. This didn't ruin my experience at Starbelly, it was just annoying that I got something totally different than what I wanted. I drank it anyway, because let's get real, a drank is a DRANK. 

But thank you, Starbelly, for proving that there IS good food in the Castro!
author: Jerome C.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in the Castro.  Every time I've been the food has been great and I've tried most of the menu as well.  I like the atmosphere and when it's nice enough I recommend sitting in the back patio for sure.  The mussels are the BOMB!  Other favorites are the crab salad (when in season) & bacon/jalapeno/arugula pizza.  It's great food for good price so you can't beat it.  Nice wine and beer selection too.
author: Eran B.

description:
Got take out here last night. Quite disappointed. Wanted the Starbelly Salad, but they didn't have the ingredients so opted for a Cesaer. Not sure what their idea of a salad is, but mine includes a least some dressing. Theirs was a small amount of romaine lettuce, a quarter of a small avocado and a smidge of Parmesan, with no discernable dressing. Also split two pizzas with my friends: margarita and a pear one. The first was the best thing of the night but not very remarkable and by the time we finished and the pizza had cooled, the crust was leathery. The second was not very good. 

The Castro apparently needed a moderately priced pizza joint because it seems to be doing great. I may give it another try or I may simply grab a slice from one of the many other good pizza joints in the neighborhood.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Had dinner last night and I really appreciated the wonderful service we received from beginning to the end.  We arrived at 10 and asked for a table for 3.  I saw a table that had just cleared out, but it was next to a drunk couple that were clearly not happy with each other.  The host said she'd check what was available and didn't offer us that table.  She didn't mention the couple, but you know she wanted us to be comfortable and have an enjoyable experience; she was cool, calm and collected - exactly what you want in a host that mans the door and manages the riff raff.  However, we asked to sit at that particular table (to avoid the communal table) and she happily sat us there.

Next encounter (the server), she was very good at giving us strong suggestions for food and you could tell she was being geniune vs just saying what was top of mind; she went through section by section (small plates, pizza, to entrees etc.) and gave us her top choice.   Also she checked in from time to time and gave us just the right amount of attention.  My man friend found a rubber band from one of our entrees and made a mention to the server.  We just wanted to mention it, so that another guest doesnt choke on it.  We weren't expecting anything at all.  She responded in a way that restaurants should but don't these days; she quickly cleared it away, didn't charge us for it and gave us a comped dessert.  I was really impressed.  

Somehow, we got into a conversation with the manager about the food, my man friend is a bit chatty sometimes,( ok me too when it comes to good food and we love having discussions about it).  We asked about his favourites and told him it was our first time.  He went to check on what we ordered and comped us some grilled peppers to give us something a little different to round out our meal, which I thought was a really nice gesture.  

The food was all very well done (and very affordable!!) with a few exceptions here and there, but my main favourites were:

-Mussels - perfectly cooked.  (i detest restaurants that overcook them into these dried shrivelled tiny pea)
-Chicken Liver Pate - phenomenal and perfect comfort food for a cool SF night
-Japanese cucumber salad with heirloom tomatoes, olives, feta, and arugula - just wow wow wow, perfect balance of flavours, textures, and tang (the feta was amazing) 
-Margherita pizza - nice thin crust and tangy sauce  - i saved a slice for breakfast and it was still tasty cold

Desserts are ok....get one to share, maybe ice cream since its from humphrey slocombe (get the olive oil with sea salt if they have it - amazing!) - all others where flour / eggs/ baking is involved, I would just pass and enjoy the small savoury dishes.
author: Miss H.

description:
I had lunch at Starbelly recently and was excited since I'd heard so much praise about this place.  The decor is nice and open and the menu looked quite good.  I'm giving the low rating because of the HORRIBLE service.  Really, it was just awful.  Not only did we wait a good 10 minutes before anyone even noticed us and took our drink orders, but the drinks took ANOTHER 10 minutes to arrive.  The food was pretty good, although I did find some gristle in my pulled chicken sandwich... a little too much for my liking. And true to form the food took its sweet time getting out to us.  The one thing on the menu I DID enjoy immensely was the donuts.  YUM.  However I was disheartened to hear later that they purchase these pre-made from some place in the Mission.  FAIL.  

I may go back in 6 months to try this place out again, but they need to work out the kinks first.
author: AJ L.

description:
Delicious! That's all I have to say!

Maybe not all... I ordered the blue cheese, pear and arugular pizza and it was perfect. It was tasty and appropriately prices ($14 for a pretty large pizza for about 2-3 people). 

The other thing that was wonderful was that they didn't push us out when we finished eating. I was catching up with old friends and we sat there for 3 hours and they didn't mind at all, even with only a $40 bill. That was something I really appreciated. 

I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Went back a third time and decided this time  to sit inside. I love the patio, but the cold air coming directly at your legs is such a buzzkill. I suggest inside unless it's a hot day/evening or if you get cold easily. We sat at a four top near the back window and it was perfect. Also, the server was super kind to indulge our indecisiveness and gave us a wee tastings of four wines to help is choose one. Easy to get a table, a great space with top notch and unpretentious servers and fabulous food. Highly recommend it.
author: Uda W.

description:
Like the other reviewer, I really wanted to like Starbelly.  It's been opened less than a week, so I'm open to the idea that I might need to revise my review upwards in the future.  

My friend and I went for a late lunch at around 2:00PM on a Saturday.  The place was maybe 15% full.  The waitress was very helpful and funny, and gave us suggestions on food and drinks.   The place has a similar vibe to Beretta, which I like.  The design is cool, but in a way that's no longer unique.  Unfortunately, the venue and waitress were probably the only things that were notable.  

I ordered a frittata and my friend ordered a wedge salad.  We also had two of their non-alcoholic cocktails; both drinks were tasty enough, but nothing special.   

As I said the restaurant was mostly empty, but it took about 40 minutes to get our food.  Not unreasonable, but hear me out:  my frittata was obviously pre-made, the egg had congealed to the point that I had to use a knife to slice it, and the sauce had also turned to the consistency of old ketchup.  The whole thing could be charitably described as lukewarm.   My friend's salad was a wedge of lettuce with grilled chicken, bacon, and a cream-based dressing.  Before the salad was delivered, the manager came over to apologize that they had oversold their bacon and that there would therefore be no bacon in the salad.  He did graciously comp the salad.  

We really did want to like this place, but when your signature is bacon and you run out in the middle of a Saturday, that's a problem.  Also, when a lunchtime re-heat of an old frittata and salad takes the better part of an hour to get through, it doesn't send me running back. 

I might go back, but not for a while.  Maybe these are all kinks, and this will get better.  But for now, I'll let them work out their problems on someone else.
author: Bucko W.

description:
It's just like Buretta: average.

This classy place is EXACTLY what the castro needed. I hope the castro gets more good restaurants!!!

How do you get your entire table to order the small plates? Easy! Make all the large plates sound disgusting.  We did get a pizza that was pretty good. Chorizo and egg pizza.

Octopus: could have been better. I prefer it Japanese style.
Scallops: the star of the evening! but $7 a scallop.
Tomatoes: yum! the tomatoes were slightly warmed
Fries with 3 dipping sauces: the basil aioli was insanely good. the ketchup not so much.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I dunno understand how Starbelly doesn't have a better rating? I thought the food here was pretty good. The burgers were perfectly cooked, and tasted great. Their homemade ketchup was an interesting combination of your normal ketchup mixed with a sort of a marinara sauce, with a distinct sweetness to it.

We HAD to order the spaghetti because we saw another group getting it and it looked really good, and it was. The thing about Starbelly's spaghetti is that it's quite spicy - they cook in jalapenos and chunks of their house bacon into the sauce. You'll feel the tingle of spiciness on your lips after every bite. Also of note, the noodles are quite thick, more like a spaghettoni. But it came out cooked perfectly al dente. Overall the spaghetti was delicious.

The space was small but nice and the decor was simple. People were packed inside and it was fun sitting at the large communal table. The back patio is unfinished but it looks like it'll be a great place to grab a meal.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Okay, I admit it. I'm in love with Starbelly.

My girlfriend and I always get a table quickly (brunch on weekends and weeknight dinner) and the service is always top notch. 

The pizza, fries, beets, salads, burgers, drinks.. all delicious. 

Oh, and the back deck is lovely (especially for warm days!).

Um.. I'll add that the scallops, soups and salads are all delicious and worth every penny. yum.
author: Lara M.

description:
I have been driving by this place since it opened and had always wanted to check it out, I had friends tell me is was good so I really wanted to check it out. 

I had the pleasure of going to this fine establishment last night and I must say I was impressed! The service was friendly and on top of things, the pinot was yummy and my favorite dish was the pasta with bacon and jalapeños! 

The place is lively, your not going to fall asleep in here, yet I was able to hold a conversations with my friend. I would suggest it as a good date place.
author: Bobby B.

description:
This was a pretty nice place!  I had heard RAVINGLY good reviews and I don't think it lived quite up to them, but it's a good solid 4-star place.  I was there on a Thursday night and it was PACKED.  There's tables, a long two-sided bistro area, and bar seating.  The bistro seats are very close so you need to be a "plays well with others" kind of person to enjoy these.  Service was great though and the wait staff very friendly.  My biggest impression of the space was "these people are HAPPY" and that included staff and customers!

I had a great dish and a very good dish!

The asparagus soup is beautiful!  Subtle green color with a mild asparagus flavor, chunks of crab meat on top, and a black-garlic swirled into the bottom of it.  I have never had black-garlic; it was a sweet slightly tangy flavor, but not "garlicy" like you'd assume.  The combination of flavors was very good.

I also had the burger with frites.  It was very tasty, beautifully done (medium rare inside).  It was a lot to eat so if you like a lighter fare, it may not be the right selection for you, but it was good.

I had an asian beer to drink that was very nice too - refreshing in an unusual way.  There's several wine and unusual beer selections.  

All in all, this was a little bit spendier than I thought it should be.  I dropped about $55 with tip for the food above and two beers.  But, it was a great experience - I left very satisified and very full - and that "HAPPY" spirit rubbed off on me!
author: David K.

description:
I went here Friday night with a large group of people.  We were just going to check out the bar as we wanted to try this place.  The bad news was that the place was packed, which could be expected becuase they had just opened, however, they really had no real bar area.  I ended up just having beer but their other drinks were made with fresh cut fruit and veg.  This was great but it caused the bar to be really backed up and it took forever to order another drink.  I assume that this is just a growing pains issues.

After about 30 mins we were able to get a few seats at their small bar area.  I was starved so I ordered their cheeseburger.  I thought the cheeseburger was really good.  It wasn't overly cooked.  I agree with D M. that their homemade ketchup was not up to par.  

Another friend I was with order a pizza which looked great but at $17 it seemed a bit expensive for a pizza.

 I am only giving them 4 stars but if I could do 3.5 I would 

-1 for taking forever to get a drink
-.5 for the homemade ketchup 

That be said, I am looking forward to going back in a few weeks.
author: Deborah R.

description:
I was excited to hear about a new place opening in the Castro. The area certainly needs some more culinary destinations, and I had heard some good buzz on Starbelly.

Unfortunately, the restaurant didn't live up to expectations, especially the second time around (the first time was, admittedly, much better). The pizza was flimsy and over sauced, the corn dogs tasted undercooked, and, both times, they were out of something on the menu. Keep in mind, I went right when they opened - both times.

I couldn't even finish my dinner last time (the pizza) as it was so unappetizing. My friend seemed to enjoy his burger, though.

All in all, not worth the wait (no reservations) and I'd recommend going elsewhere.
author: David P.

description:
Starbelly is in my neighborhood and I wanted to like it more.  The pro:  very friendly staff, fresh ingredients, interesting menu, nice wine list, good dessert (summer crumble - yum).

The con:  First, although we got there at about 5:30 and there were a lot of 2-person tables available, we were seated in the rear right by the restroom (like 2 feet from the door).  Call me paranoid, but does the fact that we are older with gray hair make us poor candidates for those nice window tables in the front, 3 of which were available?  Shame on me for not asking to be re-seated.  I did not know how very many people would be using that restroom (at least 15 during our meal, opening and closing door, waiting, etc.).  The restroom door should be set apart by a ledge, partial wall or something.  It is an eyesore and a real annoyance for those close by.

I thought the 3 little corn dogs were tasty but overpriced even at $5.

We got a lot of attention up front but it took a long time before our server took our order and even longer to get the check.

Some of their food is spicy when it should not be.  What is with spicy spaghetti sauce?  I didn't order it because I was warned (which is a good thing) but why have spicy tomato sauce that a lot of your pasta-loving patrons won't be able to eat?   The gazpacho, which I did order, was too spicy too.  

If I were rating the food it would be more like a 3 1/2.  It's not that I'll never go back.  I just was not as impressed as I expected to be.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
My friend and I went to Starbelly on opening night. As one of the first five people to arrive on the official opening night, I decided to seat myself at the edge of the community table. I started with a champagne cocktail with vermouth and a touch of bitters. Although the combination would be good for bitter lovers, I wasn't a big fan of the cocktail. No matter. 

When my friend arrived, she opted for Blush Rose champagne and I tried the New Mexico champagne. We swapped tries and I was definitely a fan of the Blush Rose champagne (and had one after). 

For appetizers, we decided on some fancy in-house, organic mini corn dogs. These come in threes with a side of ketchup and spicy mustard. I wasn't sure if I was supposed to eat the corn dog with a knife and I fork, or as a regular corn dog -- straight from the stick. I decided to go primitive and use the stick. The 'corn of the dog' was delicious -- sweet with a nice hint of crispiness to the exterior and just the right moisture inside. I give it a thumbs up for these fancy little dogs.

For our main dish, we decided to share the lamb cheeks with cheese grits and collards. Now, this was an absolute favorite. I give my friend credit, as she chose this (and, typically, I would not think of lamb cheeks as delicious). The lamb cheeks were braised so the meat melted in your mouth, with a wonderful sauce covering. The cheese grits, mixed with the sauce and greens were delicious. I'm not finding the right words to give this dish justice. I guess it was something about the combination of texture, taste and the right amount of fat gave your brain a really satisfied feeling. There was no gamy aftertaste and the texture of the cheeks was perfect. I highly recommend this dish for meat and lamb lovers. 

For dessert, we tried the fig with Humphrey's balsamic vinegar ice cream and crumbs. When you initially put a bite of the ice cream, fig and crumble into your mouth, you get the 'wow this is amazing' reaction. Something about the combination of the slightly tart ice cream, texture of the crumble and sweetness of the fig triggers the happy sensors in your brains to go wild.

I was going to deduct a star from this review because of the champagne cocktail but just because I'm not a bitters fan, others may find the cocktail delicious. 

I think this is as good as it gets, especially on opening night. And the waitress with the red hair (never got her name) was very attentive, answered all our questions and was great. Not to mention, all the staff members chipped in when it got busier towards the end of the night. What also made this an A+ experience was the community table. We sat next to two folks that made the experience even better: a photographer who is writing a book on life in a restaurant but a surgeon by day (and friend of the owner) and the SF fire inspector that needed to be there to ensure everything was up-to-code on opening night since the restaurant opened a tad bit earlier before everything was done. 

Congratulations on a successful opening night, Starbelly!
author: Chubby D.

description:
We tried Starbelly recently for brunch on a rainy Sunday afternoon. The first thing I noticed is that the restaurant is not very big. We were kept waiting for upwards of 10 minutes, ostensibly because they were waiting for a table to open up. Mr Q ran to the restroom while waiting and noticed a bunch of empty tables in the back, so we were not really sure why we had to stand up there for so long, especially since there was no place to sit while we waited and barely any room for 2 people to stand. I also noticed one of the employees seemed a little ocd...she rearranged the umbrellas that were left at the front, straightened all the menus into neat little stacks etc. To me if there are customers in the restaurant that should be your first priority, not standing up front looking bored and straightening things that don't need to be straightened but hey, it's not my restaurant. 

The food was pretty good-I had the strata and Mr Q had the Sunnyside Joes. We had a Dynamo donut for dessert. Probably the best donut I have ever had. 

Would we come back? Maybe. I wasn't enthralled with the service.
author: Fancypants J.

description:
Truth be told, I have a soft spot in my heart for Starbelly.  Finally, a restaurant that should become the first neighborhood fixture in this location since Josie's Juice Joint closed many years ago.  Great casual atmosphere, a bright and busy patio, and some of the best bacon in town.

I took a friend visiting from Boston there for brunch on Sunday.  After a rainy few days, the unexpected February sunshine made the patio seem very appealing.  I had the Croque Monsieur with one sunny (sunnyside-up egg), my friend had the Joe's scramble.  The CM was generously made with ham, lots of gooey cheese and thick slices of light, eggy brioche.  The scramble, nicely presented in a small individual skillet, got a very favorable thumbs up from my friend.  A pot of excellent coffee for the two of us, sangria for the Bostonian and a perfectly crisp and tangy Pimm's Cup for me, nicely served with a thin slice of cucumber.

Reading the negative comments about the service surprises me.  I've always found the service attentive, friendly and, if the place isn't too busy,   a lot of fun.  All in all, while Starbelly isn't a destination restaurant, it IS a comfortable, reliable and reasonable neighborhood place that always puts me in a good mood with a good meal.
author: George W.

description:
05/26/2012

So I decided to go to a restaurant that I've never been to, the condition being that it was American cuisine and that it was located in a trendy neighborhood, in which I searched for the Castro.

We were seated immediately despite being 15 minutes early for our 6:30 reservation.

Starbelly's menu looked delicious, and it immediately became my place to celebrate my birthday.

We ordered (to share) - grilled asparagus salad with hard boiled egg, and beef liver pate with sweet onion marmalade and grain mustard (this was delicious, especially on top of buttered toast). I ordered a glass of prosecco (MMMMM, the Italians sure now how to drink their bubbly). 

Individually, we ordered - harvest mushroom pizza [a slice of heaven, pizza is best when it's done gourmet], margherita pizza, bangers and mash (house made pork sausage with mashed potatoes), herb roasted chicken (with chunks of bacon, asparagus, and potatoes) [I loved how the chicken was moist, crisp skin, and delicious chunks of bacon], and prather ranch burger [my friend that ordered that was exceedingly pleased with the burger]. 

I would have given a full five stars had it not been for the waitress that, quote, "your reservation for 6:30 was nearly half an hour ago, where is the rest of your party?" Earlier, we were seated immediately even with just two, where 7 were supposedly on their way, where 4 canceled at the last minute, So I let the waitress know that there are three that are on their way and are running SUPER late. She did not seem okay with that, when I asked her if there was a problem, she answered by saying "as a business, we do provide service for those seated and paying, how about you order an appetizer or drinks so that your table is covered". That sounded more like an insult, as if we had the incapability to pay, and needed a validation for such. I could have gone elsewhere, but because my friends were already on their way, I didn't feel like changing the venue. Never question a paying customer, never ever!

Overall, the food was great, ambience was superb, and our waiter provided top notch service.
author: Alex C.

description:
After a great yoga class on Market, my BF and I dropped in for lunch. I'd tried to have dinner a few times in the past, but was too hungry or impatient (or both) to wait. I think the promise of lunch here was the only thing that pulled my BF through the yoga class. The restaurant was super cute and we loved the layout, especially the bar. Waitstaff was very nice. Iced tea was yummers! Pate was delish with sweet onion relish and mustard. The Bibb wedge salad was bigger than I imagined, with tomatoes, pulled chicken and two huge pieces of bacon criss-crossing on top. The chicken was tender and the Green Goddess dressing flavorful, without overwhelming my mouth. 

We second guessed our choice for margherita pizza with burrata, basil and sausage only because the BF loves thicker crusted pizza, and this was pretty thin and almost too "well-done" in the cooking department. In hindsight, he should've ordered the BLT or the burger that he initially wanted. 

I will definitely be back to try some other choices from the menu, but knowing my creature of habit Taurean self and mate, we will be ordering the pate and salad again and again!
author: Megan D.

description:
I had heard rumors of a new offering last August from the creators of Beretta, and one that featured spectacular brunches and a burger that rivaled that of Zuni and Spruce.  And considering that this new restaurant,  Starbelly, was just a few blocks away in the Castro, it's a shame that it took me until December to check it out.

I've gone there for brunch a few times and have been really impressed, nothing I've had has been short of very, very good.  A simple one page menu features a ton of rich new American comfort food offerings.  The chilaquiles with house-made chorizo, corn chips, chile sauce and cilantro is mouth-wateringly good, and will crush any hangover you bring in there.  The open-faced sunny-side up egg sandwich with cheddar and Starbelly's delicious thick-cut bacon is a solid favorite, too.  The sourdough flapjack or the sour Levain french toast are great too if you're in the mood for those.  And the burger: it's legit; Prather Ranch beef on a grilled brioche bun with choice of aged white cheddar or Pt. Reyes blue cheese, bacon, and roasted onions.  I go with the cheddar and bacon, and the onions on the side.  It's a stand-out burger and up there in the Zuni and Spruce echelon fo sho.  Both the dinner and brunch menus feature a variety of thin crust pizzas, as well a surprisingly diverse beer selection.

Service has always been friendly, warm, and attentive and the decor also parallels that of Beretta: a long communal table is the middle of the dining room, and the rest is a blend of bright varnished wood and brushed silver metal.  It's clean and spare but not boring, filled with rich accents that capture your upon each visit.  One edge Starbelly has over Beretta is a full back patio with open sunlight.  Nice.

Highly recommended, check it out.
author: Saminda W.

description: Great atmosphere. Friendly staff. Perfect place for a small or large group to have a wonderful breakfast.
author: Fred O.

description: Told it would be a 45 minute wait. Ordered a bottle of wine while we waited. Were repeatedly told just a few more minutes. After 2 HOURS we were still waiting and offered anything to compensate. I've been here before. Not worth waiting any longer for mediocre food and service. I will never eat here again.
author: Baby J.

description: I have been to Starbelly a handful of times, but I was especially pleased with my dining experience there last night.  I ordered the Pino Noir from Sierra Madre which was a great medium bodied Pinot, with hints of berry and a cola finish.  For starters, my date and I shared the plum salad (it was okay- the plums could have been a bit more ripe as they lacked in flavor) and the chicken liver pate!!!  I would come back for the chicken liver pate alone... it was incredibly smooth, rich and paired perfectly with the carmalized onions it was served with!  I also ordered the steak entree which had a nice mild spice and smokey flavor from being cooked on a grill.  Like I said, I'd go back for the chicken liver pate and wine alone :).  Also, our waiter was super friendly and attentive.  Overall, great dining experience.
author: Gazelle B.

description: Starbelly is a solid restaurant that helps San Fancisco live up to its reputation as an innovative culinary hub. If you are looking for a nice date spot, or a group dinner with friends, this is an excellent venue to share tapas, knock back some wine, and explore different food groups and ingredient combinations. You have all sorts of fresh veggies, cheeses, and meats to top your flat bread pizza, and the seafood dishes are prepared with good sauces and bastes. Most of the Servers are friendly, and while knowledgeable, they don't come of as pretentious and douchey like many foodie enclaves. (Attention Service Industry: We know you love food just as much as the diners---no need to get in to a know it all debate---it will hurt your tip). You can't go wrong with Starbelly, and you will get a great meal while leaving satisfied.
author: Culinary C.

description:
Well the food is pretty decent, but this place needs a new staff on the floor. Been there for dinner a few times now and my last experience was sadly ruined by a dim witted server and an outrageously rude manager.
There are too many great places in SF that I wouldn't waste my money going back to this place where the food can't make up for bad service.
author: michael L.

description: Just returned from my second visit to Starbelly, and I am officially hooked. The first occasion was a nice intro to everything they had. I would pass on the porchetta because I was not expecting the skin/fat to be baked onto the pork. It was a bit unnerving... Today, however, was thoroughly perfect. It started with the sardine appetizer, which was topped with a tangy blend of peppers and capers. It was fresh and tasty. I ordered the Canadian cod w/ carrot sauce over a bacon/brussel sprout mix. The fish was cooked perfectly, and sucked up all the carrot sauce, which was slightly sweet. The savory and texture was added by the bacon and brussel sprouts. Everything just tasted damn good. Also try the Mexican coke w/ red wine... its refreshing. To top it off, in these tough economic times, their prices are super reasonable.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Starbelly is fantastic.  Everything is just right for a high class local joint - nice interior, good seating, not too much flash.
