The food is uniformly good - the superb cole slaw sandwich for lunch, the burger, the appetizers, all of it says "we're kind of pretentious, but we're kind of trying not to be.  Look, you can have a corn dog!"  It works. Very SF that way.  Cf. Father's Office in Santa Monica, which also has accessible food but fully owns the pretension.  SF vs. LA in a nutshell.  I like them both.

Like Father's Office, the owner of Starbelly cares about beer.  The place does not have 50 choices, but it has 15 great ones that go with the food.  They have Hitachino, which is the new hit in beer circles, they have random belgians, they have some nice locals.  And they are thankfully taking a stand against the Pabst phenomenon in this town.  Mustaches and PBR were never a good idea - keep them in the 19th Century.  Watch Tombstone rather than wearing it, please.  And go to Starbelly - the slaw's comin!
author: Brian D.

description:
Definitely one of the best dining spots I've been to in the Castro area. The fried oysters were heavenly in both taste and texture. We also had a dish of three cold meat, and then both the spaghetti with bacon and the rotisserie chicken were nothing short of fantastic.

It is however a small place and seats are pretty hard to come by. I didn't make the reservation and I'm typically reserved against restaurants that are hard to get a reservation... like Starbelly.
author: Q L.

description:
My amazing friend took me to this restaurant in celebration of us being reunited again in SF.  Hooray!  She's a pretty hardcore foodie much like myself and so I trusted that any restaurant she would introduce me to would be just as wonderful as she is.

And you know what?  Starbelly fit the bill.

It was a welcome back to my other old friend, the Castro, replete with the parking god(dess) bestowing upon us a space on the street out front.  Walking in I enjoyed the lovely rustic ambiance of the place, and hey, is that their own herb garden in the back patio?

D.F. (darling friend) was eager to try the fig, blue cheese and prosciutto pizza so we decided to share that as our main course.  We started with burrata, heirloom tomato and basil on toasted bread.  Rich and wonderful, good olive oil, amazing tomatoes, but not enough bread.  We had to ask for extra bread, but somehow I didn't really care because ...burrata....

Ordered a Primitivo (also known as Zinfandel in the U.S. to you wine geeks out there) and when the glass arrived I remember tasting it and getting kind of confused.  A few minutes later the manager came by, apologized, and said that the server sent over the Carmenere instead.  Ah ha.  But hey, I got to keep both, so yay.  (Unfortunately don't remember the names, so can't really tell you what exactly I drank.)

Other than that (to me, minor) goof, our server was just plain awesome, I hate that I can't remember her name, but she answered all of our questions and was attentive and oh so sweet.  

When the pizza came to our table we devoured it pretty quickly.  Strong blue cheese flavors, which I felt overpowered the rest of the ingredients - even the peppery arugula.  Still a tasty, tasty pizza.

For dessert I order the toffee cake with mascarpone and dates. She ordered the caramel pot de creme with rosemary cookies.  This was hands down the best part of the meal.  I think she and I wanted to pick up our respective plates and lick them clean.  Absolutely swoon-filled accolades to both dishes!

So overall my experience at Starbelly was great.  Was it a combination of the company and the restaurant?  Perhaps.  They served fresh, vibrant flavors, but not what i would call outstanding - good, with a rustic elegance I suppose - so a perfect neighborhood establishment.  Dessert was the star.  This, as well as the service, are reasons I will come back.
author: Mo R.

description: I wanted to like Starbelly but they have disappointed me. We had reservations for 10 at lunch. The restaurant was not particularly busy, the service was attentive. But it took way too long for the food to be prepared. The lunch menu is not even complex. Then the plates were delivered at different times. It was like there were different cooks in different kitchens preparing the dishes and they did not coordinate the timing of each plate to be ready at the same time. Very disappointing.
author: Suzy B.

description:
we had a pretty good meal here. the pizza was good, the ice cream was raved about, and the service was pretty darned good.

we sat at the bar for just a bit too long, and the owner/manager comp'd our round of drinks while waiting for the table (our reservations were at 8:00, and we were seated like 8:40).

the chicken wasn't that exciting.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Came here with a big group and everything went smoothly and its oh so delicious. I guess we're lucky we didnt have to wait for a table (even on a Monday it was packed) but I am willing to go back with a group under 6 and try it out.

The service and food was outstanding. We brought in our own wine for a $15 corkage. I also brought in a birthday cake and was charged a $18 plating fee without warning which was then knocked down to $9 when I complained.

They even brought us a free pizza that was really yummy. Skip the octopus salad, definitely get the scallops, the pate and the parsimmon salad.

Awful, awful music played in here but it still deserves 5 stars!
author: Rachel J.

description:
Well lookie here, the reputation that I have heard whispered about that you can't find good eats in the castro is quickly fleeing.  This sweet little restaurant with a sweet little name is positioned just right to win your heart. 

It seems to me that they are emphasizing fresh ingredients with a local green twist that is becoming a norm with many new restaurants in SF (and old ones!) No complaints here, I am deeeeelighted. 

The one thing I thought was odd, was how many people 'touched' our table serving up food, wine, clearing, watering, etc. There is still that new restaurant flow that needs to be perfected. The patio was not open yet, which was a shame because it would have been a great weekend for patio dining, but the FOOD is delectable.

I was going on the light side and ordered one of my mainstays---ceasar salad---it is a personal journey of mine to try every ceasar salad in the United States. It was wonderful small two heads of baby gem lettuce with a decadent, simple creamy dressing and two slices of perfectly ripe avocado. I love how they shave the outside of each avo slice to get rid of any burgeoning brown spots and just make a perfect presentation. Truly scrumptious, could've had a double serving! I also got an appetizer of deep sea scallops pan fried in a creamy corn sauce. They were simple and quite good as well. BUT, for a special treat, I asked for bread and they brought out two thick pieces of toasty whole wheat french bread that had been grilled in butter. Oh the decadence of it. 

My companions shared the mini-corndogs which were a big hit and Brian got the jalapeno spaghetti (not sure he would get it again, said his mouth was on FIRE), Matthew ordered the Mt. Tam Pale Ale braised lamb cheeks which he seemed to enjoy and I should have tasted because those cheeks looked amazing. I love me some cheeks.

The prices seemed reasonable and I think one reason is because the portions are quite small. However, the table next to us ordered the half roasted chicken which looked like a large portion and smelled delicious.

Also, Liquor, yes. They do not have a liquor license but were quite creative with their beer and wine cocktails. I ordered a 'Lillet on ice' which is how they stated it on the cocktail menu. Um. This place was made for me!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Came here for dinner. Everything was perfect. The server was very attentive and was good at helping us decide what to get for appetizers and dessert. The food was delicious. I could write more but maybe I'll add more when I go back...because I wil be back!
author: Colleen D.

description:
This has become my favorite neighborhood lunch place.  Possibly my favorite in the whole city.

What's good?  Well, I love the chicken liver appetizer to start.  Wonderfully creamy and served with outstanding jam and chutney.

I'd be hard pressed to choose between pulled chicken sandwich and roasted porchetta one - both are bursting with flavor.  The fries are, of course, a great accompaniment to them or the very nice burger.  The salads are great, especially the generous dungeness crab.  (But the dedication to seasonal ingredients lost us the wonderful cucumber salad from when they opened.)

On the spring menu, there's a outstanding asparagus pizza with caramelized onions and truffle oil, but all the pizzas I've tried have been great.

And then, everything they say about the salted pot de creme is true.  The rosemary shortbread cookies are the perfect complement.  It's a not-too-sweet dessert that I can't get often enough.

Service is incredibly friendly and very indulgent.  They're not too helpful in ordering, just because everyone seems to like every dish.  (But, heck, I do, too.)

If the weather's nice, just sit on the back deck and enjoy it all.

Despite the rave, I'm giving only four stars, because dinner isn't quite as satisfying as lunch.  The menu is very similar, but what works for a leisurely lunch feels rushed and unexciting for dinner.  For lunch alone, five stars.
author: Paul H.

description:
The food was great, but the atmosphere was not. 


The good: 
I had the mushroom pizza with gorgonzola and truffle oil. It was very, very good. 

The bartender helped me order a good white wine and saved me from a terrible one.  

My friend had another type of pizza and the burger. They both seemed to like their food. 

The price was pretty moderate too. 10-15 dollars for entrees. Wine less than 10/ glass

The Bad
"Is it warm in here?" It must have been pushing 80 degrees. Gross. 

The Ugly
We were seated at the dreaded communal table. 

Usually I don't mind this sort of thing, especially in cities where space is limited. However, this set up was just uncomfortable. There was no space between us and our neighbors. We literally were rubbing elbows (and not in a good way). 

Also, the table wasn't very wide so it felt even more cramped. The seats are stools which is fine if you're at a bar, but this was supposed to be some sort of table. If you have a purse it has to go underneath the table on a little hook. Great concept if the table was wider and everyone's knees weren't constantly hitting your purse. 

Bottom Line: 
This place is probably a lot better if you are seated at one of their actual tables.
author: Amy T.

description:
Just had brunch here for the first time; lucked out becuase it wasn't too busy.  Just found out that they now accept reservations for dinner, which they did not initially.  This means I will be back to try their dinner menu.

I noticed that they have what looks to be a good selection of wine and beer, and a few signature mixed drinks.  Not sure you can get other cocktails however... I suppose I'll find out at dinner.
author: Nathaniel H.

description:
We returned to Starbelly on a Friday night and got to experience the legendary (infamous?) wait.  We were told that we could come back in an hour (8:30pm), and to call 45 minutes ahead next time.  We called back 45 minutes later, only to be told, oh - 8:45pm.  When we reached Starbelly at 8:45pm, they told us that they would try to seat us closer to 9pm.  At this point I was past looking at my watch to check the time.  

Why am I still awarding 5 stars? 'Cause Starbelly, despite its wait-challenges, is still fabulous.  

We ordered 4 appetizers (since we were *that* ravenous) and were comped 2 more - the fries and the spicy sausages - (both *excellent*) for our long wait.

On this time around we got to sample:

-Octopus with fennel and radicchio slaw - not the best, though tender - it didn't taste uber fresh.
-Spicy Sausage - round, juicy and meaty and not too spicy
-Corn with marscapone & garlic - like dessert - sweet and rich and decadent
-Fig & Bleu cheese pizza with arugula. We opted to add Spanish Ham, as the menu suggested, but the ham on top of the bleu proved to be too salty. I ended up pulling the ham off and eating it separately.
-Spaghetti, starbelly bacon, jalapeno, basil and roasted tomato sauce -- boy do the folks here like their spice.  This dish was almost *too* spicy to finish, but very flavourful.

Starbelly, we hope you consider taking reservations, but we will return by hook or by crook.  Let's also hope you get better at setting wait expectations.  Thanks as always for the classy treatment and fabulous food.
author: Claudine C.

description: This restaurant has become our "go to" staple restaurant in the Castro.  It's consistent in all aspects from food to service.  Thank you Star Belly!
author: Kai N.

description:
Since I live nearby, Starbelly is a great spot when I want some good food and don't feel like thinking too hard/going to far to get it.  I've been to Starbelly more times than I can remember, and generally enjoy it.

The apps and salads are all great.  They had mini corn dogs at one point, and I really wish they would bring them back.  The pizzas are OK, but I wouldn't call them amazing.  There is some magical combination of crust and sauce that is just right for me, but they don't have it.  I've only had a few of the entrees (the burger (SO good!) and the spaghetti stand out).  I also like the changing beer menu, encourages me to try new things. 

The staff is super friendly, and always seems eager to please.  I've had the same server the last two times I went (most recently, yesterday for lunch) and she's awesome!  I wish I could remember her name =( but she has an accent (we were guessing S.African).

I'm really glad we've got a place like this in the neighborhood, we just need a few more now!  I always recommend Starbelly to out-of-towners, and they always love it too.
author: Matthew P.

description: Went back to Starbelly and I've got to comment on the bacon, jalapeno spaghetti... So yummy! Also, I think it's important to mention that it. is. LOUD in there. So be prepared to make your voice hoarse.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Always fun and full of people, but the staff will do their best to find you a spot if you just walk in. 

Cocktails are well done. Pizza and risotto dishes are kind of their specialty.  Tried their desserts for the first time recently - the rice pudding and the caramel pot de creme - and both were outstanding. 

And of course perfectly located close to the Muni/F-market line.
author: Shruti Y.

description:
Had a chance to finally try the infamous Starbelly in SF and  I must say the food was excellent! Must have's are the pate and caramel dessert which is a pretty unique creamy caramel pudding that you probably would never find anywhere else! 

For the entree, I had the mushroom pizza which was really good but I say go for the short ribs or clams which was even better! It can get crowded on the weekend because the place is not really big. I would definitely come here again to try some of the other dishes.
author: Victor C.

description:
I had a great time there. Very rustic and not pretentious decor. Great service. I love love love the hand made spaghetti, split pea soup and the summer squash pizza. :D 

Please make sure you make reservation in advance and you may be sitting in the communal table. 

Have fun!
author: Hubert C.

description:
Every dish was good to fabulous. The depth of flavors was amazing.

We ordered:

cheddar grits with braised Mariquita Farms greens
roasted padron peppers with olive oil and salt
pan roasted black mussels with chorizo, chiles, and cilantro
diver scallops with sweet potato puree
heirloom apple and butter lettuce with roasted oregon hazelnuts

Grits were very nice, though not as good as Gators Neosoul Cafe down in San Mateo.  The cheddar was sharp which matched well with the bitter greens. Salad was fresh and perfectly dressed. Loved those hazelnuts - added great crunchy texture to the salad. The roasted peppers were a nice treat - I think it would probably be even tastier with a bit of toasted garlic on it. Yum. The diver scallops were nicely browned yet still tender and moist on the inside.  I wasn't too thrilled with the puree -the sweetness overpowered the delicate flavors of the scallop. The scallops were nicely flavored on their own.
 
Last but not least, my favorite of the night was the mussels. The broth was INCREDIBLE - so many layers of flavors - it was a party in my mouth! We even asked for more crostini after all the mussels were gone. We just couldn't let that delicious broth go to waste. 

We had the pot de creme for dessert. Though the container was a nice presentation, it was a little too rich for me. Thankfully, the salt helped cut the sweetness. My husband really liked it. Wasn't wowed by the rosemary cornmeal cookies - found them a bit too dry. Maybe sitting out too long?

Everything was very good, but the mussels were fantastic. And truth be told, there wasn't anything horrible.
author: Eso R.

description: We had a perfectly decent but fairly unremarkable dinner here. I would not recommend going for any sort of "occasion." We were seated on the outdoor, covered patio area that, even with the heat lamps, was not quite warm enough. We did not ask to be seated outside and the tables and chairs were akin to cheap patio furniture - I'd recommend asking to be seated inside. I liked the salumi, which came with olives, bread and pickled onions (a nice touch, would have been even better if they were mentioned on the menu). At $6, I found it a bit too expensive, as were most things on the menu. We had the burger, chicken, and cioppino. The chicken was described as 1/2 chicken on the menu, but was only 1/4 when put on the table! (drum + thigh). On the one hand, that was fine as I only wanted a 1/4 chicken, but on the other hand, it was a pretty big ripoff. Overall I found the dinner selection to be fairly lacking. The cobbler was a lot breadier than I'm used to and the sorbet was overly sweet. In short, I don't plan to go back.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Consistently, I have had great service and very tasty food.  This place is a much needed hot spot for the Castro.  

Keep up the good work Starbelly!  :)
author: Ryan B.

description:
I read some of the reviews before writing this one. Bitter party of one came to mind. My experiences however were completely the opposite. 

After running into a good friend at the gym we decided to have lunch together. I suggested Starbelly. I had noticed it opened and stopped to read the menu a few nights before. The place was jamming that night so I already had an idea about had dinner might go down.

We arrived around 12:15 p m on a Friday afternoon and were promptly seated. Our server Kelly Nicolaisen ( amazing artist I found out  later) seamed like she was on roller skates. She would float in and float out at all the right times. She helped me refine my selections 
so that I got exactly what I was craving. Oh boy was I satisfied. Both my friend and I kept getting distracted from catching up by the amazing food we were putting down.

Before leaving we had the pleasure to meet Danielle who was able to answer all my excited questions about where the kept the Starbelly sneaches, how to get in for dinner, the concept , the inspiration and anything else I could think of in my foodie high.

The following night I went again with my boyfriend and two friends ( I am working my way thru the menu since I live a block away ;-}  ). I knew to call ahead to be put on the list. This was at 7:00 p m on Saturday. After being on hold maybe 15 seconds ( thank  you for that) I was told that we could be sat around 8:30. I was also told that I could call back around 8:00 to check on the status of our table. ( I liked that)  After calling back at 8:00  they said our table would be ready in 10 minutes. ( Most excellent) We arrived to a packed house. People outside, inside, and everyone was smiling. I was so excited to share this experience with my friends.

We were set down within a few minutes and were seated at the corner of the communal table. I purposely positioned myself so I could see into the kitchen. I felt like the cat that caught the mouse. I had the best seat in the house. I could see the front ,the back, and into the kitchen.
Our  server Margo showed up to help orchestrate our evening. She was knowledgeable, interested and quite the charmer. At one point in the evening she even said she felt so lucky to be there because everyone that she gets to interact with both guest and co workers are nice and fun and interesting. ( Loving that). I am not going to go into the eight dishes that we ordered and devoured. You will have to come and navigate those waters for yourself. Trust me, you will love me for that. 

Part of the way thru our meal you will never guess who shows up to our table with a dish for our table , the chef Adam. ( I am dying now.) He says " I hear you have been here a few times".  I explained to him just once but I plan on coming back for sure.( someone had been talking to the chef) 

My evening was complete. I later obsessed on Allison's command of the kitchen after Adam stepped into the expediting role,  Allison is the Sous Chef . I commented to Margo our server about how impressive she was in the kitchen and she said " they are so on point together". Well need I say more.

There are some wonderful rooms in this city to dine in. There are interesting selections of  food prepared amazingly.  However to me there are few restaurants were you feel like you are part of the experience and not the audience. I am so grateful that Starbelly is now part of the fabric of my neighborhood. I hope that anyone in the biz who reads this knows that this is the direction we should be taking our dining rooms.
author: Gib B.

description:
Starbelly falls squarely into the "3.5" category, if only Yelp had one. 

The owners of Starbelly (same as Berretta), really know how to do atmosphere. The lighting, design, decor etc all lends a warm and sophisticated vibe to the place. Each time I've been for dinner, I've called ahead about 30 minutes before I want to go, and they usually are able to seat us between 5-10 minutes after arrival. Of course, I've never tried this on a Friday or a Saturday! 

The service was friendly and helpful, the menu was true to form... interesting, easy to understand and filled with yumminess!

Recommendations: the butter lettuce salad, the asparagus and crab soup, scallops, the half chicken. 

MUST-HAVES: the pork shoulder, chicken liver pate, salted caramel pot de creme, any of the Humphrey Slocumbe ice creams they offer.
author: Nissa A.

description: Still amazing and the all-out best SF restaurant! Their roasted butternut squash and black garlic pizza is simply heaven from the oven!! Our table added eggs to the pizza order, and it was great to have the runny yolk making the toppings just that much creamier. The best Brussels sprouts ever - divine is not an exaggeration. They are flash-fried, and while your waistline might complain tomorrow, your taste buds will demand more. Ending the meal - must we? - tempts us with rice pudding and a heavy dose of Oregon hazelnuts. Such sparkly comfort food... the hazelnuts give the right balance of flavor with the perfectly mild and creamy rice pudding. As always, the service at Starbelly is enthusiastic, warm and helpful. Top notch.
author: Jen S.

description:
We had a good time at Starbelly. 

We arrived on a Friday night around 9 pm and were able to sit at the bar immediately. The bar staff was so nice and friendly. They served a perfectly legit and tasty dinner that was fairly well prepared. The food was not the best in the world but it still made for a good dinner at a reasonable price.  We loved the salad and and the pate starter was great. The scallops were actually slightly undercooked. 

We loved the warm atmosphere and the friendly staff, these made the dinner experience worthwhile.
author: john m.

description: I've been here for brunch a few times and I think the food is quite good for a casual, American style meal. I like how the outdoor back patio which is covered so even in the rain you can still dine outdoors. Service is good and prices are fair so I'm sure I'll be going back again for brunch at some point. I believe a good portion of their menu is organic, which is nice to have as an option.
author: Kent W.

description:
If I was grading on a Castro curve, this place would probably have five stars, considering its competition is, like, Bagdad Cafe and La Fajita Grill, amongst other positively David Lynchian establishments right around that cursed intersection. Unlike these places, Starbelly is a real restaurant in our normal reality, despite being called "Starbelly," a word that just makes wonder if the Beretta people think gays are complete kooks, like we're all going to go, ooh, Starbelly, I just have to make my belly a th-tar! Sigh. The environment is nice enough if a bit generic, our 3-person party was seated immediately although at the big communal table. Waiter's effusive enthusiasm was amusing at first, irritating by the end of the night -- yes, we heard you the first time about the special Ketchup made with unicorn dust or whatever, but it just tastes like Heinz, buddy. 

I'm being harsh. Really, gotta love a place with a Pimm's cup and kir on the drink menu (although both a tad on the pricey side), and the fried clams and pizza were fun hang-out sharey food. In general we got out of there pretty cheaply, which is a good thing, although we specifically went for the cheaper options. It wasn't bad, it just wasn't anyplace I feel like going back to, unless I'm on the corner of 16th and Noe and too hungry to walk to the Mission. 

Crime about the patio too.
author: Ben G.

description: my favorite spot. great aesthetics, great staff. best dish,fresh pasta with jalepenos and bacon - CRAZY good.
author: Mister M.

description:
I don't yelp often. However, I feel really compelled after my Derrr--icous lunch at Starbelly!

The food was AMAZING. Nothing short of pure perfection; the type that can only be described by the best of culinary experiences.

The fig and blue cheese flat bread tasted fresh and burst with salty, sweet, deliciousness. My boyfriend had the burger that was juicy and moist - delectable. With the burger we ordered a side of fries and requested an aioli. It was pesto aioli and hearkened to a fritz dipping sauce; we devoured the fries in seconds and if wasn't for a better conscious I would have ordered another batch!

What was bad? Not much, except maybe some of the timing issues around food delivery. It seems that whomever is expediting the line with the the kitchen is working out how to get food delivered in a more harmonious synchronization. This can most certainly be overlooked as my taste buds were singing sweet sweet happiness by the end of our meal.

Be sure to check it our for lunch as dinners are serving up quite a wait!

You wont be disappointed!

YUMMMM
author: Anthony R.

description:
Late Saturday evening dinner with friends - party of 6 - we had a reservation.

First thing we noticed is how beautiful the space is and that there's a beautiful outdoor space with romantic lights.

We ordered several small plates to share:
- Corn & jalapeno hush puppies, jalapeno jam: a must try!  Delicious!

- Burrata, shaved heirloom radishes, olive oil, sea salt, & toasted bread: plenty for sharing!  Another must try - it's served with grapes which I wouldn't have thought would really work with the burrata but it was fantastic.  A bit of burrata, with a few grapes on toasted bread - it's all you need!

- Coriander dusted scallops, white corn puree: everyone who tried this agreed it was absolutely delicious.  It is served with just 3-4 scallops so you may want a double order depending on the size of your party - or if you want to make this the meal which I heard several of my friends say they would!  If you love scallops this is a for sure order.

The main course I had was fresh Spaghetti, starbelly bacon, jalapeno, tomato & basil  and I was left underwhelmed with this one.  There was way too much bacon, thick chunks - so note to those that don't like a lot of meat - do not order this dish.  I was most intrigued because of the jalapenos which was a nice flavor in the dish - but overall I would skip this one.  My husband ordered the Pizza - market mushrooms, gruyere, thyme & roasted onions and he thought it was good but it didn't knock his socks off.

My recommendation would be to perhaps skip some of the larger plates and make an evening of the small plates here.  Their snacks, salads and small plates were all note worthy - so that's what I will probably do next time I visit.  

My other recommendation is go for the dessert!  In fact, I would give their desserts 4.5 stars!  We ordered the following to share:
 - Salted caramel pot de crème, rosemary cornmeal cookies: Perfection!  This was amazing amazing amazing!  The rosemary from the cookies combined with the salted caramel was a fantastic flavor dream.  I recently wrote that Pomelo's Hazelnut Chocolate Mouse was the best dessert I have had in San Francisco, but Starbelly's Pot de Creme gives it a serious run for its money!

 - Scoop of Humphry Slocombe seasonal ice cream: The flavors offered were the Harvey Milk and Secret Breakfast - seriously amazing - both of the flavors.  It was perfect for sharing as well!  You really just need a few bites to appreciate the taste.

I would give the savory foods 3 stars, but the sweets at Starbelly are first class 4-5 stars!  I'll definitely be back for an evening of small plates and desserts!
author: Kavita M.

description: When we have so many choices for New American, California Cuisine, "A New Take on Comfort Food" restaurants in San Francisco, why choose Starbelly? Do you like waiting for over an hour for your reserved table? Do you like being upsold at the bar? (Why have two sizes for beer if you're going to try to sell me the large one when I order the small one? I don't drink that much. A little beer is perfect for me.) The service was terrible, I had no idea who was running the show.  And the food was totally meh!  Since they seated us an hour after our reservation time they brought us free french fries to make amends.  Too little too late.
author: Jordan A.

description:
This place was delicious, friendly, and fast. I'm in love.

I ordered the apple and celery root salad which was really good. The pistacios and dried cherries packed an extra punch. I definitely recommend tasting this salad.

My friend had the split pea soup and said it was very flavorful.

We split the market mushrooms, gruyere, thyme & roasted onions pizza. This was seriously one of the best pizzas I've ever had. I was only planning on eating a slice but ended up eating half the pizza. I will definitely order this again next time I go. 

For dessert we had the salted caramel pot au creme. I've never had salted caramel before so didn't have any expectations. The next time I have it, however, I have high expectations as this dessert was so delectable. They also served this dish with rosemary cookies. I love rosemary! They paired nicely with the caramel.

Our waiter was friendly and attentive and we got our food quickly. Thumbs up to Starbelly!
author: Jeanette L.

description: Burger was good, margarita pizza was good. Sangria was very strong, french fries were DELICIOUS!  I wanted an artichoke but they "ran out" -really?  Would think about coming back, but there are sooo many other places in the castro to try that I probably wont!
author: Ting B.

description:
Today was our second visit, as we wanted to give it a second chance, but unfortunately it was still disappointing.  

We like the atmosphere with the exception that it gets loud and cramped.  The overall design is warm and modern with lots of light.

Service on both visits was below average.  Food on both visits was just ok, lets call it average.  We had 2 burgers (so-so) and 2 iced teas, total with tip $37.  On the prior visit we tried breakfast, and that was also just ok.
author: Brian H.

description:
I came here with a group of 6 (which is a huge group for this place), and we ordered nearly everything on the menu.  It's true, the pate was yummy, although, one can order nearly anything off the menu and be surprised and delighted.  

We had a pretty long, awkward wait near the door for a table.  Later, we experienced some mistakes with our many orders.  These are likely a result of being such a big group.  

The decor at Starbelly has been called "Oregon chic".  I wouldn't think it possible, but the feeling is mixed between rustic/casual, and formal/sophisticated.  A few of us from down the Peninsula felt a little underdressed.  

Overall, a great place to visit with a group to make a sampler out of the menu!
author: Margaret C.

description:
We had a very enjoyable meal.

We started with the mussels with chorizo and a bowl of gazpacho. For mains, my wife had the chicken and I had the spaghetti with bacon. We also got the fries with three dipping sauces.

We made happy plates with everything.

My only complaint is that it was very loud and often hard to hear each other.

We'll be back.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Interesting menu, great beers, and bustling scene make Starbelly a solid four-star. 

Saturday night was very busy, and it seems that reservations are important -- there were several groups that were waiting due to wrong group size / being late.  My group had a fearless leader who organized a group dinner for 14, and we were seated promptly and had great service.

Had a New Britain, great dark beer.  

We ordered in groups, and my pod of four got a mushroom thin crust pizza, several small dishes including fried crab balls and brussel sprouts, and a pasta dish.  Not spetacular but good.  Two bottles of wine.

Total $40 per person, which is super reasonable
author: Aki N.

description:
My friends and I arrived here at 9 PM without reservations, on a Tuesday, and waited 5-10 min to be seated.  We ordered drinks from the bar and had a great time drinking and visiting in the waiting area before being seated.  The hostesses and bartender were truly cordial and warm.  

We sat in the communal table area and ordered 2 butter lettuce salads for starters and 2 pizzas.

All the dishes my party and I ordered were perfect!  They offer many specialty pizzas; I enjoyed one with arugula, bacon, and Green Goddess dressing.  I ate the entire thing.  The bacon was thick and cooked to be what I would call a great match between crisp and chewy.
author: James B.

description: for the past 2 years this restaurant has stayed at the very top of my favorites list. I dine out at least 3-4 times a week & I have to say that Starbelly just can't be beat. The atmosphere is swanky & reminds me of my hometown in Vancouver, BC. The staff are friendly & helpful & the food is always amazing! The menu changes often so there is always something new to try.
author: Colleen J.

description:
Yum Yum Yum - that's my take on this wonderful spot.  I have been walking by this place for some time and finally got the chance to come here for brunch.

The chiliquiles with choriza  and BLT are absolutely delicous - fortunately our group got to taste a bit more since we split our dishes.  

The place is located in a really fun spot - feels vibrant and alive - and the place itself has a really good buzz and energy.  The decor is bright and airy - and the staff is friendly and efficient.

Definitely a place to put on your favorites list - will definitely go back.
author: Gina C.

description:
The food was ok.  But even before the food arrived, a few things seriously dampened the experience:  they don't have any diet sodas (seriously? this is taking the organic thing way too far), you only get bread if you order it as an appetizer, and the table height is too high for the freestanding chairs.

The margherita pizza with basil was actually quite yummy while it was warm, but during the meal it cooled and lost its flavor.  My favorite part of the meal turned out to be the fries that came with my boyfriend's burger, salty and delicious!
author: Sumner P.

description:
this is a decent spot. sitting there, i noticed the surroundings were inviting for someone like me. the ceilings are high and there's wood everywhere. in the back there's an outdoor area which would be great to hang out at on a nice warm evening. 

of the things i tried that night i liked the frito misto the best. but don't be fooled like i initially was. a frito misto usually invovles calamari and some sort of veggie so i thought, but at starbelly, this isn't the case. it was all veggies including onions, broccoli and lemon (which i guess isn't a veggie). it was tiny, but tasty. the chicken with mushroom risotto was juicy but there was no wow factor. and i added some salt to it. the bacon jalapeno and arugula pizza was good but again, nothing special.
author: Regina C.

description:
Short:  Delightful and delicious brunch, lovely back patio, get the Salted Caramel cremel!!!

Came here for Sunday brunch, as we wanted to try something new.  We happened upon Starbelly previously, but were a bit turned off by the construction happening around it.

This time, I'm so glad we looked passed it and went in!!  They have an absolutely adorable back patio, and interior in general, with a cute communal eating bar area as well.

The brunch menu was YUUMM!!  Simple, but so flavorful and delicious, especially for the decently priced menu!!!  Also not annoying and dark and "sheeshee", just casual and comfortable and delicious!!

There were 4 of us, and we had the Asparagus Egg Scramble, Mushroom Pizza, Buttermilk Pancakes, and a Steak Salad.  ALLL amazing!!!!!!!

We also ordered a side of Fries (which came with a lovely Trio of sinful dips) and the extremely popular and talked about Salted Caramel Creme!!! (they don't usually serve that for brunch, but the chef was so sweet to make an exception!)

And so imagine our eyes rolling to the back of our head as we all split some pancakes, and topped it with the Salted Caramel!!!  We died and went to Castro heaven...

HUGE thumbs up!!!
author: Rollio R.

description:
Wasn't sure what to expect when I first walked in (the tacky empty bottles in the window throws you off a little. Btw, if the owner is reading this- take down the bottles display. Its super tacky and the lighting is all wrong).
This place is surprisingly big! Very nice atmosphere, but gets kinda loud though- definitely not a romantic evening type of restaurant. The menu is short, simple and nice. Everything sounds tasty. I had the mushroom pizza (surprisingly delicious) and the Bavette steak (a little chewy, but still pretty good). And the wine selection is pretty neat too- washed the food down with Barbera d'Alba and the Zinfandel blend- went nicely with the food.
Took it down one star because of the desserts! The bread pudding was simply atrocious, I repeat, simply atrocious!! And the lemon ricotta, although not bad, was just bite sized! Rather disappointing after the nice meal.
author: Blue C.

description:
This place deserves 5 stars!!

The atmosphere is great, not pretentious at all

The chef is super nice

And the food let's talk about the food cause that's what yelp is supposed to be for: 

The food is DAMN GOOD!!! I loved every bite of it!!!
From the appetizers to the pizza and the dessert!!!
Go for the : burratta; the creamy mushrooms soup; the gazpacho; and the pizzaaaaaaa!!!!
Oh and must have: the caramel pot de creme just EXCELLENT!!!
author: Mina T.

description:
Since I have lived near the Castro all my life, I can tell you Starbelly is a welcome addition.   Upscale restaurants have a hard time surviving in this neck of the woods, often being replaced by fancy bars, that sell OK food.  I have now eaten there on three separate occasions and each time it has been its own eating experience.

#1 Back in early December with our funky cool staff.  14 people for dinner in this small restaurant was not the easiest feat and yet they managed to fit us in.  Since they were running about 15 minutes late, they provided us with three (or four) free appetizers. Dinner was excellent, served hot and the herbal infusions (green-jasmine tea with sage) blew my mind.  That night I had the apple-celery root salad, the fish of the day and the Salted Caramel Pot-Du-Creme.  Considering the size of our party, everything was spread out nicely and the timing of service was great.

#2 and 3.  Two times in one week (Gialina was packed)  Second round I had the Prather Ranch burger, and I can honestly say it was the best burger I ever had.  The meat was a perfect medium rare like I ordered it and it lacked the heavy, greasy feel of Niman Ranch Beef.  The fries are thin cut and crunchy, the way they should be.  I even managed to eat some of the beet salad, and that is the biggest compliment to the restaurant, since I detest beets (up there with tongue and liver, damn Eastern European upbringing).  More of the amazing herbal tea infusions (they seriously are like crack) and we had the toffee cake for desert which both my husband and I are a sucker for.  Our server on Wednesday night was AMAZING and entertaining :)  We had a great conversation with him about Cairo.  Saturday night the service was good, not as great, but then again, it was around 9PM and crowded.

So TTK (things to know):  

The wait can be grizzly on the weekends.  You can call 45min/ one hour ahead and put your name on the list.  They soon will take limited amount of reservations per night, so if you are good at planning ahead the whole wait thing will be behind you.

Contrary to what a lot of people say, the restaurant is fairly loud.  The back is better for group conversations, but at the communal table you definitely have to speak up.

They serve super late on weekends, so you finally have a place to go after seeing a movie at the Castro.

Parking in the Castro is a bitch.  Be aware that zone parking is often until 9/10pm so make sure you don't leave your car for more than  2 hours or you will come back to a nasty ticket !
author: Monika S.

description:
So I'm a little late the party I admit but I'm with Courtney N and a number of others, the food in the hood is such a downer, there's just so little quality for a discerning palate.  Frankly, the gays deserve better and have for sometime.

That said, I enjoyed Starbelly and think it's a boon to the neighborhood.

As a vegetarian, I can't say I found the entree choices exceptional.  Having pizza is not the direction I wanted to go in.  Thankfully there were a lot of appetizers to choose from to make a tapas meal happen.

The beets aforementioned by others was delightful. The salads are a nice choice and an easy way to take out some meat where it was offered.

If you're a vegan, this place isn't offering you much choice at this time though. The waitress agreed.

Go with Yelper Liz S.  and it's hard to give any place less than 5 stars but in this case, until they fatten up the veggie options, it remains a 4 star. Maybe I'll change my mind after I experience brunch there.
author: Sean S.

description:
Starbelly wouldv'e made it to 5 on account of it's good, good food, but the horrible service negates it.

Food: We tried the pear/gorgonzola/spanish ham pizza, and it was ooey gooey and delicious.  A little rich after 2 slices, but nonetheless, AMAZING.  The grilled asparagus was fantastic, as were the steaming beets and candied walnuts.  Also had a simple beets and greens salad that was an (accidental) added bonus.

Service:  Our waitress was cute and quirky, but the servers messed up our orders not once, twice, but thrice.  Really?  Really.  Our pizza was late because it was "overcooked" the first time, we received a beet dish that was not our own (hence our accidental delight), and we were given the wrong check (which we waited a good minute to actually get).

Otherwise, the communal dining experience was awesome, the decor is inspiring, and I would love to come again in the warmer months to sit out on their patio.

Me likey.
author: Ivy R.

description: I have been three times and have not been dissappointed. Love the burger, the pizzas (especially the bacon, arugula, and jalepeno), solid beer selection. A good option for late afternoon, comfortable space, friendly staff.
author: M J.

description: later dinner reservations at eight:thirty pm..lucky tuesday night with easy street parking in difficult castro...immediate seating and an old rasputin stout delivered...ready for starbelly for my belly!..browsing through menu and yelp..deciding on chicken liver pate and a pizza...having flexibility in pizza choice for others...flat square of chicken liver pate served...knife cut and bread spreading delicious...tastes fantastic...others sharing a plate of salumi meat choices...decent snacking and more bread...another choice of barruta...a buffalo mozzarella...milder, wetter and frankly little blander...adding quince jelly from another plate for little sweetness...enjoying with more bread...trying a chorizo pizza with sunny egg...runny yolk and chorizo flavors...a first experience and okay...but, having had too much bread at this point...added by a thicker chewy pizza crust...no more bread!...half a chicken next...extremely tender and moist...a great chicken on a bed of good risotto...server forgetting the spaghetti with starbelly bacon...our group full and not needing another meal...cancel noodles and paying...$thirty-one total per person for filling meal variety with a drinks...
author: Hen A.

description:
First impression: Slightly hip, casual spot to grab a bite. Also, when we first arrived, the service was top-notch....and it continued throughout the evening. 

Ambiance was nice- candle-light, big windows at the front, outdoor seating area, and a hip, environmentally-friendly (reclaimed wood?) look inside. 

The waiter concocted a strawberry-Prosecco drink for me, that I LOVED, so props for the effort. My husband ordered a Pimm's cup, and not only was it attractive, but it tasted lovely! 

Also, since we were meeting friends here and they ran late, our waiter was super-relaxed with us, and didn't make us feel rushed.

When our friends arrived, we ordered a cheese/salumi plate, and it was delicious- especially the goat cheese. You need to try it! 

We also ordered crab "hush puppies" and they were good too, but someone at the table commented that they were dry and not very flavorful. I liked them, though, and would order them again. 

By the time our pizza came (sausage and pineapple), I was too full to have more than a bite, but it was delicious also. 

Overall, I would say that our experience was well above average...and I'd go back, for sure!
author: adrienne l.

description: I came here on thursday night, I love the patio ,it make me feel good about my self for some reason with the vegetable garden around the patio. I had the blue cheese pizza with arugula and a glass of wine,the service was friendly and helpful,always around to refill my water glass.music was nice and not to noisy. over all a great choise to me.
author: Luis R.

description:
I had a lovely time at Starbelly.

To start, the cocktails the bartenders concoct are delicious, quirky twists on older, classier drinks. For example, the Pimm's Cup was a very generous pour garnished with a slice of cucumber and a sprig of basil. One gets a tiny whiff of the garnishes during every sip.

The wine list is also different and wonderful compared with other restaurants in the area. Many of the wines are Spanish or South American, and the selections are impecable for each category, making any uneducated choice a tasty one.

We had the salumi plate to start and requested that the server choose the specific cuts to serve. All were very nice, and the board was served with some olives, fresh mustard, and toasted bread. My only thought here was that the portion of the salumi itself could have been bigger.

I ordered the spaghetti for the entre. I know, I know. I can make pasta at home. But that's what makes it such a good way to evaluate whether the kitchen staff knows what they are doing or not. Besides, Starbelly's spaghetti has a little bit of jalapeno in it, which gives it a tiny zing. The freshly shaved parmasean on top was nice too. I really enjoyed that spaghetti!

Since we were drunk and already impaired by the time the dessert menu came, we decided to order dessert wine instead of sweets. The muscat was a little too sweet for me - almost like syrup. But the Zinfandel! Good Lord, was that tasty! Not too sweet, and there was a touch of tannin remaining. A very nice late harvest.

All said and done, I liked my dinner. It didn't exactly amaze me, but the price was very reasonable. Only other thing is that I found the restaurant a little noisy for a Tuesday.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
The food is absolutely wonderful and ultra-tasty at Starbelly!  LOVE the roasted beets, fig+blue cheese pizza, the hamburger, and Sangria.... in addition to the lengthy wine list :)

The only thing that's inconsistent is the service...... sometimes it takes an awfully long time for the server to get to the table.... or recognize cues when you're ready to order....or pay.

But, other than that we take many of our SF visitors for dinner there and it never disappoints.
author: anna p.

description: It was a 45 minute wait on a monday night, so this must be the place to go for dinner in the Castro. I really enjoyed the mini corn dogs and my spaghetti with staqrbelly bacon and jalopenos. I also loved my Chupacabra beer. I skipeed dessert, but they sounded delish and the ice creams come from Humphry Slocombe. I definitely want to go back and try the pizza and homemade salumi. They accept reservation via phone up to 45 minutes ahead. If you're hungry, I suggest you choose that option.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I really wanted to like Starbelly...unassuming location in the Castro, casual and cool atmosphere, pleasant service, fresh and local ingredients...but the food was mediocre. The highpoint of my dinner was dessert - the salted caramel pot de crème.

Grilled little gems salad with market oranges, raw milk feta & toasted almonds - the lettuce had a nice smokiness from the grill, however, it was overdressed and soggy. This salad had potential because all the flavors were there, but they were muddled because the ingredients weren't proportioned correctly.

Market mushroom pizza with gruyere, thyme & roasted onions - they murdered this pizza with too many red onions. The overwhelming, sweet red onion flavor completely masked the taste of the gruyere cheese and delicate mushrooms. What a tragedy. 

Pan roasted black mussels with Mexican chorizo, market chilies & cilantro - the chorizo added a meaty richness to the mussels, but it was difficult to enjoy because the mussels were so puny. If a restaurant does not have decent size mussels, they should not serve them. Period. 

Grilled Sonoma lamb chops, cheddar grits & braised greens, fresh quince chutney - finally, a well-executed dish. The lamb chops were juicy, well-seasoned, and nicely complemented by the quince chutney. The grits weren't bad, but they weren't memorable either. 

Salted caramel pot de crème, rosemary cornmeal cookies - this pot de crème had me swooning it was so good. The rich, creamy caramel had just enough salt to curb the sweetness on the finish and make it incredibly enticing for another spoonful. This rivals Town Hall's butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème. 

For the most part, the food at Starbelly is unoriginal and needs refining. What good are fresh and local ingredients when you don't balance them correctly?
author: Karin V.

description: The food is outstanding but the staff seems put off. I want to go there but it always feels like I'm interrupting the waitstaff. Eating at the bar makes things feel less awkward. The Diablito is outstanding.
author: Jason S.

description:
I had the best dessert of my life here, the caramel pot de creme. Words can't describe the sublime heaven that this dessert is.

I would compare it to orgasmic.
author: Alesha G.

description:
Starbelly should really be a two on my account but I have a love affair with the ambiance afforded by the decor. I really only came here because a friend of a friend worked here for a short while. 

The food is very minimalistic and lacking in the rich flavors found in American food. On the flip side the ingredients are all from the best local/organic fresh sources and thats always sexy. The food left me unsatisfied for sure though. 

The one thing I will continue to find an excuse to go to Starbelly for is the famous Salted Caramel Pot De Creme with Rosemary Tea Cookies on the side... I nearly rolled out of my chair when I first had this. It is one of those desserts you purposely eat verrryyy slooowwly. 

Not my favorite but give it a try it might suit your pallet.
author: Camille B.

description: First time trying out this place, I would say the pizza is delicious with a brick oven taste like what real pizza should come from. The sangria is very tasty with a hint of spice. The chilaquiles with salad is a great blend of chorizo, corn chips, chile sauce and the salad perfectly offsets the heavy taste of the chilaquiles which makes this dish very well balanced. The service is very friendly, although the food did take a little time to prepare which is understandable with the new years crowd. I would need to try this restaurant a couple times and venture into different dishes before I give it a 5 stars rating.
author: Mike K.

description:
Came here on a whim (read: no reservations) on a Friday night. Not the smartest move, but we got space at the communal table.

This is the old Asqew space but you'd never know it. The place looks sleek and lovely inside.

Drinks: Went with the $6 red wine. Don't be frightened -- it's actually really good. My wife (who does not drink) had the grape & lime cooler. If you're expecting purple concord grape in that, you'll be disappointed. It was pleasantly sweet but not grape-y.

We started with the chicken liver pate, which was recommended here on Yelp. It was very good, although we didn't really have enough bread. As much as I liked it, I'd probably try something else next time.

My wife had the pear & blue cheese pizza with arugula and ham on top. The crust is very thin, but not too crunchy and pretty good. 

I had the pork shoulder, which I found to be very good but my wife did not like because she felt the salsa verde was too strong.

Hands down, the winner of the night was the salted caramel pot de creme. Seriously, ORDER THIS. And don't do what we did -- share. If you want to be friends after the meal, get your own. 

Also, don't do what we did when we got home. We forgot to put the leftover pizza in the fridge and left the box on the table and went to bed. When we woke up in the morning, we discovered that our cat had broken into the box and eaten all the arugula and ham!! Brats.
author: Kellie P.

description: Starbelly is, first and foremost, a great bargain. With a prime location, trendy, rustic ambiance, and an eclectic and inventive menu, they could certainly get away with upping their prices, but I'm thrilled they keep it affordable. Our group of seven was seated outside on a cold and rainy night, but luckily, they have a roll-away canopy that completely encloses the space, as well as VERY warm heaters that kept us comfy cozy for the duration of the meal. We opted to go family-style and ordered three pizzas, an assortment of sides and and a few entrees as well. Two of the pizzas were prepared with sunny-side-up eggs on top, which was fabulous! Runny yolk is about the only thing that can make a cheesy, crispy pizza even more decadent. Definitely a fan! The mussels, scallops, and gnoccho with pork were all delicious as well. In case you were wondering (and I was!) gnoccho, is similar to gnocchi except that it's served in more of a pie-like situation, as opposed to several small dumplings. This dish in particular featured a square block of the stuff topped with a pork ragout saucy situation and cheese. Filling to say the least, but very tasty! The entire table agreed that the best dish we tried was the side of Brussel sprouts though. Thats right, Brussel sprouts! Cooked to crispy perfection, mixed with crunchy bacon and topped with a drizzle of balsamic reduction, these little suckers were magnificent. I could have easily made a meal out of them, but I'd hate the miss the rest of the deliciousness on the table. Starbelly doesn't have a liquor license, but their wine-based cocktails were winning nonetheless. Try the Starbelly 75 with prosecco, ginger lemon, and wine liquer. Yum!
author: Katie C.

description:
guess it gets the benefit of the doubt.  definitely using all the right ingredients, and the right wording.  but for an sf brunch, didn't stand out among the other good places.  sampled the french toast, chilaquiles, and burrata pizza.  nice ambiance with an outdoor covered patio.
*chilaquiles, house made chorizo, corn chips, chile sauce & cilantro, house salad -- eggs / chips / chorizo in good amounts and nicely spiced.
*pan de mie french toast, bananas, maple- walnuts & mascarpone with bacon -- very sweet, buttery mascarpone, have tasted things like this before.
*pizza margherita with burrata & basil -- very thin crisp but not darkened crust.  ok
this place is good by playing it safe.
author: Rob C.

description: Creative, criminally inventive and a true original.  I first went here in pursuit of their highly recommended burger, and I became a devotee immediately when I looked closely at the menu which is thoughtful and inventive with flourishes of haute cuisine seldom found in casual joints.  True to my calling I ordered the cheeseburger although there was plenty to tug at my heart instead of that burger including tantalizing pizza's, some down home sandwiches, beautifully described salads as well as sandwiches, entree's and compelling side dishes.  It's a light hearted, fun restaurant that takes food seriously and fun the same way.  The physical plant is clean and lean, there is a trellised patio with outdoor heaters when needed, an elevated family style table, a small wine and beer bar and a well trained staff who are thoughtful, attentive and fun.  The burger is a true winner as are the fries and service, but since that first visit, I've tried salads that are inventive and excellent, appetizers like the mini corn dogs that are addictive and a couple pizza's that are as sensational as their choice ingredients.  Entree's have consistently been avante garde and really well executed, so I have trouble classifying restaurants that can make high dining a simple, fun experience for the masses.  I love Starbelly.
author: Stu S.

description:
I recently enjoyed a Thursday night dinner with friends at Starbelly.  Very nice ambiance: long communal table in addition to some two tops (the communal table appears to be the only way to get seated without a LONG wait), good energy in the restaurant (loud, but not too loud), impressive looking selection behind the bar, and open kitchen.

The appetizer selection is great, which makes Starbelly a great place for a shared eating experience. The chicken liver pate was great.  The french fries were great, too.  

On the negative side, I've had much better margherita pizza, even at chain restaurants.  And wine bottles were overpriced.  So, if you're with friends that get a little aggressive with their ordering, be prepared for a BIG hit at the end of the night.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Heavenly! 
3 of us ventured out on Saturday night without reservations. We waiting 35 minutes. Which was ok. The mussels in wine chorizo jalapeno broth was amazing. It had a little hint of spice but it blended well with the chorizo & wine broth. Order extra bread right away because you'll need extra to completely enjoy the broth!  

I had the pork shoulder with grilled pears and greens with a side of cheddar grits, the flavor combo was well balanced. My partner had a 1/2 chicken wrapped with apple wood bacon, the chicken was being rotisseried right behind us in the kitchen. Beer menu was exotic and plentiful. We'll be back!
author: Natasha S.

description:
Really this place deserves 3.5 stars with the biggest downgrade being for the seating. Sitting at a two top near the entrance on a busy friday night I found the booth side of the table to be the right height but the chair side to be to low, placing the table at almost breast level. This seating arrangement makes for awkward dinning especially at the already tightly packed tables. 

The food was good but not memorable, we had both the fries and the clams for an appetizer which were okay. We then shared the mushroom pizza which was rich and flavorful and on a decent (for San Francisco) thin crust. The highlight of the meal however was the Chocolate Peanut Butter Desert! This desert was very good and caused us to definitely leave on a high note. I would skip the appetizers just to leave room for the desert. 

For service, our server, Lauren was amazing! The food was timed perfectly, the water glasses were always filled without even noticing her filling them, and she was always there to answer a question but didn't hover over the table. 

The total bill for 2 appetizers, a pizza, wine, coffee and desert, plus tax and 20% tip $70, which seemed to be very reasonable. 

I would have to give Starbelly:
Decor : 4 stars
Service : 5 stars
Seating : 2 stars
Food : 3 stars (4 for just the desert)
Price : 4 stars

I would go here again if I was in the area and there was no wait, but I wouldn't go out of my way to get here.
author: Katie P.

description: We come here often and it's a good place for a reliable meal with good atmosphere.  Although the menu doesn't change as often as it should, there is a lot to choose from, so there is something for everyone.
author: R. S.

description:
I stopped in last night with two friends and we all had the Hamburger. It was very tasty and I loved the endless supply of Sparkling Water for the table and the friendly staff. 
The fries that came with our burgers were a tad too salty. They were removed and replaced with a fresh plate of fries immediately. 
I would definitely go back again and hope their dessert menu changes from time to time. There was nothing on the current dessert menu that was tempting.
author: Shivaun O.

description:
Went on a Saturday around noon with a group of 3.  There was about a 45 minute wait.  It took full 45 minutes.  It would have been faster with a group of 2.

I ordered the Bibb Salad, and our table split  the pizza with black garlic, asparagus, and truffle oil.   Also, we ordered a big french press coffee for table, also ordered Darjeeling tea cocktail with egg white.  All of it was tasty..

I'll come back if the wait isn't so bad next time.
author: Peter G.

description:
Many restaurants set up shop by having a nice environment--good interior design, and music and then the actually execution of the restaurant is an after thought.  Starbelly is firing on all cylinders.  For a long time there was a drought in The Castro--at least in the food department--and now with several good eateries like Kasa and Eureka there is another good one--Starbelly.

The California fare restaurant has a small yet well edited menu of both small and larger plates.  The wine and beer list is equally small but well chosen.  And to bring it all together is good service that dialogues with it's patrons and does so equally and thoughtfully.  I had the super fresh Octopus salad which was well balanced with spicy arugula and the citrus elements sewed each distinct flavor together.  I enjoyed the Prather Ranch burger with what seemed a lot of french fries--I was thinking how could I eat all of these?  But the were completely light, crunch and delightful.  The housemade ketchup was another plus--I am tired of high fructose sweetened mass produced ketchups.  This is a nice ketchup that allows you to enjoy your fry but not bury with overly thickened and dangerously sweet ketchup.

I could have eaten dessert but could not imagine eating a dessert by myself--that would have been too much.  I really wanted to try the salted caramel pot de creme but I will give that a try next time.  I enjoyed Starbelly on many levels and look forward to a return visit.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Had a fine & varied array of small plates, couple of sides, and 3-4 of their pizzas--for a group of 8.  Service was excellent, very attentive without being intrusive.  Wine was very good.   I especially enjoyed the duck sausage & brussels spouts.  They were done to perfection.  The duck sausage was accompanied with an  artfully arrayed sauce mixture, and the sprouts were just plain delicious.  I look forward to return trips.  It's mid-range in terms of price, so not cheap, but not ultra expensive.  An easy walk from any place in the Castro area.
author: Thomas O.

description:
3.5 stars here.  The service was solid, but really, at the end of the day, this wasn't all that impressive of an experience. 

We ordered your basic bocas - here they were from the menu:

Popcorn clams with Old Bay remoulade
House cut fries with three dips 
lamb meatballs, preserved lemon, kalamatas, tomato & feta
pan roasted diver scallops, gingered yam puree & pepitas  (only two scallops on the plate, really? for 14?)
oven roasted beets, chevre, horseradish

and a fall squash & sage, black garlic goatcheese, pepitas pizza

None of it was particularly remarkable, though they have my compliments on the seasoning of the lamb, and my wing man's kudos on the popcorn clams. 

Although it was an acceptable place to dine, we don't expect to be going back.  Too many more interesting places in the city left to try.
author: Theresa B.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood.  Let's face it, the food in the Castro sucks compared to a lot of other neighborhoods.  Starbelly brings a destination restaurant to the neighborhood that is also accessible to locals during the week.  I love the ambiance and the food, while nothing out of this world, is solid and hits the spot every time.

I love going there and sitting at the bar with a friend. The bartenders are nice and the service quick.  I have loved everything that I've ordered there, from the fries with house made ketchup and remoulade, to the BLT, and the pizzas.  

Thanks, Starbelly.  It's the closest thing I have to a neighborhood joint right now.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I was introduced to StarBelly this past Saturday evening by one of my foodie friends in SF.  She is not steer us wrong.  Excellent!  We did not have a reservation and after being told we would have a 2 hour wait I was a bit disappointed I would not be trying this wonderful restaurant she had raved about.  Luckily, a spot at the bar opened up and we were able to enjoy our meal there.

The cheddar grits and braised market greens were to die for!  We nibbled on the pan roasted brussel sprouts with Starbelly bacon and for the main course enjoyed the Fall squash & Sage pizza.  All in all, an excellent meal.  One person in our party of 3 ordered the Ranch burger which unfortunately after a second try was a bit too much on the raw side.  Our waiter graciously took it off the bill and substituted a delicious dessert!  

If you don't have a reservation, prepare yourself.....but it is worth the wait!
author: Monica R.

description:
UNSANITARY. 
Every morning I walk by this place and they throw all their garbage in the sidewalk and then hose it down the block. It's so gross. I have to ask the workers to move the garbage bins because they create a roadblock and can't even get through. Unfortanately they don't speak English, so I'm getting nowhere with them. I've talked with the manager on several occasions to no avail.

I've eaten here twice before I knew it was a dumpster haven. The food is less than to be desired. They should spend less time making homemade ketchup (takes just like any other ketchup) and work on the menu. I tried all 3 dessert wines and each one got worse and worse.

Boo Hoo, Starbelly. I hope the owner reads this as no one seems to want to respond to my 4 emails I have sent them in the past few months. I've seen neighbors bring it up to the staff in the am as well, but again, no speaka any English, amigo!
author: L U.

description:
After just one meal we were just about ready to call this our new favorite place. We tried it again last night with an out of town friend and that confirmed it.

Warm salads were great. Pizza was great. Mussels with chorizo, half chicken, perfectly cooked burger. Great fries. I'm eager to try everything now. 

The house-made spaghetti with bacon (smoky and thick) is also awesome, delicious frito misto, excellent fries. For dessert they have Caramel pot de creme, an awesome rice pudding, and they feature a few Humphrey Slocombe ice creams. The menu appears to change seasonally so we won't be getting bored.

Atmosphere is great, decor is warm and simple. Service has been sprightly but not clingy. The long bar down the center is a fun place to gather. We were on the patio last night and this is a nice 'oasis' option if there's a big noisy crowd. We reserved ahead but it's never totally jammed because they won't book the place out. They always keep a few tables open for walk-ins. I love this policy.

Starbelly has lots of small plate servings but portions are generous for small plates. Good value here.
author: Randall J.

description:
I really want to like this restaurant and I have been back many times to give it further chances, but today was the last straw. It is a great location and ambience and the food has been consistantly good but the service is so up and down it's frustrating.

A bit of history the first time I dined I had a full glass of red wine spilled over my entire outfit, granted the server and the staff was more than generous and I wasn't that upset I knew I could get the stains out.  The restaurant offered to pay and they discounted my check. So I wanted to return.

Second time I sat alone at the bar and ordered a leisurely three course dinner (I had a book and was comfortable) the food runner proceeded to try and squeeze in all three courses in front of me at the same time after I had very clearly given my order to the bar server. Granted she apoologized and the food was taken away and brought back in courses but it was very ackward nonetheless.

Today we decided to revisit brunch for the second time as the Chilaquiles that I had on my first brunch visit were delicious. We chose to sit inside and were the only table up in the front window. We watched three other tables enter and be seated on the patio or in the back of the restaurant and be served water etc. while no one came up to our table to even greet us. Meanwhile there are no less than three employees less than 10 feet away from us behind the bar but apparantly it's not their job to help the customers. After about 7-10 minutes we just left, one of the three employees behind the bar apologized but the hostess nor possible waitperson were anywhere to be found.

Granted the patio was busy but the inside of the restaurant was empty except for 1 or 2 tables in the back, if you expect to stay in business in this climate I think you owe it to yourselves to spend more time on training your staff in customer service!
author: Heather H.

description:
For the longest time, I had hoped to find a tranquil and sophisticated spot to go in the Castro for wine without thumping techno music.  A place where they have innovative and lovely appetizers that truly stimulate one's appetite.  

Yesterday, the day of the Pride Parade, we particularly wanted such a spot and found it in Starbelly.  The team was attentive and thoughtful.  And though we just had appetizers and dessert Chef Adam Timney executes each dish beautifully and with passion.  I will surely be back for many meals and experiences.
author: Emanuel B.

description: The patio is a great place to be on a warm summer day. Savor their simple yet  flavorful dishes using seasonal, local and organic ingredients . Awesome spot for brunch. MUST TRY ITEMS: grilled bavette steak salad and their pizzas!
author: aj s.

description: This is a very solid neighborhood brunch spot that doesn't require an hour to two hour wait. I only give it three stars because they don't have a full bar and I love morning cocktails, although they do some creative things with sparkling wine and other non liquor drinks. Start with the donuts and ask to sit outside.
author: Samantha S.

description:
We decided on eating here for our date-night (i've been to their sister's berretta and delarosa, also pretty good..but we were looking for a more laid back scene)
I would advised to either make reservation or call-in to put your party on their waitlist..... if not there will be a long wait.

The layout:
couple two-tops at the entrance of the restaurant, to the right the bar, towards the back communal tables and more four and two-tops.  clean, simple/laid back decor.

service:
friendly hostess and servers, our server was quite helpful in recommending and explaining dishes.

drinks: 
boy: barley flat oatmeal stout (dark and chocolately)
girl: hitachino nest $9 (beats monk's kettle's 13.25 any day!) 

food:
-fried smelts-- also fried lemon slices(refreshingly tasty), this was a bit of the let down, the dish seemed to be lacking flavor even with the remoulade.

-starbelly salumi-- rabbit rillette and house made chorizo. very very glad we ordered this, the rabbit tasted like a cross between tuna and chicken, and it had the same consistency of canned tuna(but less chunky).  The chorizo was also very good and surprisingly light for something that is usually greasy.  Both of the meat paired well with the mustard grains, pickled onion, and pickle slices.

-grilled little gems-- very tasty, loved the grilled flavor and meaty texture of the gems, the feta, sweet oranges and toasted almond brought the salad together.

-market pear, blue cheese and arugula pizza-- the pizza was thin and crisp and the pear and blue cheese worked very well with each other, a tad on the oilier side for me though, but nonetheless quite tasty.

overall it was a good meal, leaving me very very full, probably should have ordered one less appt (fried smelt).
author: Tara B.

description: Good food, nice to have in the neighborhood.  Can call ahead for a table and then shorten your wait.  The outside seating is not so great, weird picnic tables and awkward heat lamps that burn your skull.  It seems to get booked with LARGE groups of people that take 2/3 of the dining area then they put everyone outside that comes in (not cool).  Many items on menu are good, pizza and salads are killer. Lunch is best.
author: John F.

description:
Upping my review to five stars -- the bonus star based on customer service.

I've been back to Starbelly enough times now to have eaten my way through almost all of their lunch and dinner menus (brunch, here I come).

I've never had a complaint.

One time, during a lunch service where I'd ordered a pizza margarita, they accidentally sent my pizza to another table who had ordered the same thing.  No big deal... I had no problem waiting a few extra minutes for my pizza.  Stuff happens.

The manager owned up to the delay, apologized, and comped everything.  Not just my pizza... but my beer as well.

Today, eating with a friend, we sampled a lot of items on the menu... from the pate to gazpacho to a bibb lettuce salad with chicken and homemade bacon.  Everything was fabulous.  To end, we went for their cheese platter.... and to be honest, we weren't thrilled by it and talked to our server about what didn't really work for us.

Thing is -- it wasn't BAD... it just wasn't something we were knocked-out by.  We probably ate 1/2 of the the platter... and in no way were knocking it.  It just didn't please as much as the rest of the food.

When the server came back, she said she'd removed the cheese platter from the bill.  Amazing.  We both protested a bit -- saying that even if it didn't strike our fancy, we weren't sure there was anything wrong with it.

The amazing thing was -- when we talked about the cheeses on the platter, she had a binder full of info about the cheeses available.  Even though these weren't our favorites... Starbelly clearly goes out of their way to educate their staff about what they serve.  I really appreciate that kind of effort -- and they seem really concerned about customer feedback... even if it costs them a buck or two here and there.

Note to Starbelly staff and management: you've knocked stuff off of my bill even when I haven't asked you to... and made making me happy your #1 priority.  It may cost you a few bucks in the short run... but you've absolutely made me a loyal customer that will come back, often, to sample anything you offer.  I'm sure you'll get a 10x return by being this attentive.

P.S. love the herb garden in back.
author: Mark B.

description:
I totally enjoyed my meal here. The prices are great for the food quality and taste.  Any place that serves a good gazpacho at some point during the year is always near the top of my list, but the potatoes, salad pizza and desserts really put it over the top.

I would reccomend this place to people on any budget.  You can clearly choose to go all out and order the fancy full plate dishes, however mixing and matching the smaller plates as a couple or a group can provide a very filling and enjoyable experience!
author: Chris D.

description:
Most memorable dinner menu items consumed on a Thurs night:
- Shandy (beer and lemonade...amazing and exactly as it sounds)
- Chorizo and egg pizza (sunny side up eggs on top - fried eggs on any savory dish make it that much more savory)
- Split pea soup (flavorful with bacon, but teetering the overly rich/creamy end)
- Chocolate cake donut + PB & curry ice-cream from Humphrey's (imagine putting a spoonful of cold peanut butter in your mouth which subsequently converts itself into yellow curry as it sashays down your throat...not exactly to die for but worth trying at least once)

Not so memorable:
- Craaazy long wait 

Highlight:
- Waitress donning hipster-ish, oversized, clear-rimmed, square glasses which brought back memories of gramps with his reading glasses
author: Miriam K.

description:
In short: reasonably priced for absolutely terrific food and great ambience. Seriously, this kind of food usually costs twice as much.

We first stumbled on Starbelly on Saturday night - saw that Asqew (Ew...) was gone. The wait was 45-60 minutes so we passed. We came back on Sunday night, having reserved a table for 4 over the phone (not really a reservation - just putting your name on the list, basically).

We were seated immediately. The decor is great and the place is really busy, but must have better acoustics since it's not deafening like Home down the street, or Osha Thai downtown.

I had the gazpacho and we tried 3 of the vegetarian pizzas. All were really, really good. Crisp crust, perfect toppings that complemented each other, and high-quality ingredients. My bf got mussels and some meat dish - don't remember what it was but he loved it and he. is. picky.
