Desserts made us happy again though.  Yogurt sherbet was off the hook with its addictive sauce.  The salt in the pot de creme was delicious and very complimentary with the dessert.

Flow of service was fairly good.  Except we waited for brussel sprouts for a little while, but they made it to the table eventually.

This place definitely has potential to be a great place.  I think it's already popular, but we all know how long that lasts in the condense SF food scene.  With some improvements here and there, it will be a star in a belly I think. :)
author: Ziya A.

description:
This place keeps getting better every time.

I don't understand why people complain about the service. 

The service staff couldn't be more welcoming and warm.

The free bubbly filter water is great and their grape lime cooler is delicious. Great beer and wine selection too.

We had the pizzas and all I can say is WOW. The crust and the flavors were simply divine, pretty creative menu.

I love this place!
author: Jorge H.

description:
Really great new restaurant in the area. Stop by and check it out. Locally grown and prepared so good.
Starbelly is attempting to get approval to open their patio. If you live in the neighborhood stop by and ask the manager how you can help.
Try the mussels, pizza, or the yummy cesaer salad. You gotta try Starbelly!
author: Tom L.

description: We met here at 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon.  We had made reservations for a party of 7 the weekend before.. after leaving a message and waiting 36 hours for confirmation.  Immediately the problems began with beers that they were out of and leaves from the "vegetable garden" getting in my spouse's hair.Then they were out of three of the four varieties of donuts on the menu..  then they were out of cornbread.. all due to a busy brunch.  Then the the drinks FINALLY arrived.  And it is not as if this place was very busy.  It was not busy at all.  My spouse asked for extra ice in her glass for her diet cola three times.. and got attitude from the waitress.  This is not a place to bring elderly in-laws who are exhausted from a tour of the Asian Arts Museum..  We finally got to eat some very lackluster meals and left at 5:30!!!!!!  2 hours!!!  Skip this place unless you have a lot of time to kill and don't mind mindlessly going down a beer list until you find one they have in stock.
author: Chris B.

description:
I'm giving it two stars just because of the good bottled beer selection.   80+ dollar dinner for a small dish of olives, two small salads, 2 cold scallops (I'm assuming they were supposed to be delivered to the table warm) and a cube of burrata, which was not the typical creamy, yummy burrata I know and love.  My husband got a beer and I a glass of wine; we were done with them within 10 minutes and the waitress never asked us if we wanted another (which we did).  She asked if we wanted to see a dessert menu, answer was yes, and she brought us the check.  

Bottom Line:  I'm still hungry, thirsty and am wondering how I just paid 80+ dollars for that?
author: Rebekah R.

description: Good food. Friendly and efficient wait staff. One of the Castro's better eateries and social scenes. But nothing on the menu is absolutely amazing here. Definitely worth considering for a good dependable meal, just don't expect too much.
author: Brent H.

description: I always wanted to try this place because it simply looks like a cute restaurant, with an even cuter name. I had also heard the food was quite tasty, so I decided to take my mom here for her birthday. Well my friends were right, the food was super good! The only downside is that the online menu said that they had a Bass dinner, but when we got there, it was the only thing that was not on the menu- both of us being peskatarians, it was harder for us to find things to eat. We did however decide on the mushroom pizza, side of asparagus, and dungeness crab hush puppies...all pretty amazing. Even though it was rather tight, I did enjoy the communal seating,  because it added an extra touch I wasn't originally expecting. I would definitely like to come back for brunch!
author: Sonya D.

description: Ok yum!!!!!!!!! Went here for a friend's birthday dinner the other night. What great food! Awesome staff. It gives good atmosphere too. The food is AMAZING. I'm in love with their creamed corn. I want to marry it and have little cornbies.
author: Denise P.

description: The food is alright, limited menu and nothing stands out. It's a typical castro/mission cuisuine that I've grown tired of. Wait staff was very friendly and things came out quickly. Not overly priced for the category it fits in, but I feel like it's the same as many other restaurants in the area. So if that's your bag then you'll enjoy it. Didn't find anything that stuck out as new or original.
author: Lacy T.

description:
Since my original review we've visited several more times for lunch and dinner - still love the place! One of our "go to" places in the City. Excellent and creative food and drinks, with great service by knowledgeable staff.

We recommend Starbelly to all our friends and all those that have been have raved about it.
author: John H.

description: Off the beaten path but well worth it if you're interested in hanging out with the locals.  Went for lunch a few weeks ago.  Friendly service and the artisan pizza was pretty awesome.  Nice selection of wine and cocktails as well.
author: Patrick M.

description: I first came here for a friend's birthday dinner and was pretty pleased with the variety of food. There's nothing culturally authentic about any of their dishes, but they do a good job with their fusion efforts. The staff is really friendly and I love the seating area in the back--except when the weather isn't conducive. Overall, I had a good dining experience there and have definitely gone back.
author: Ty L.

description:
Our first attempt to try Starbelly was the second Sunday it was open for brunch.  We arrived at 10am (its advertised opening for Sunday brunch on its website) to try to snag one of the first tables.  However, our plan was foiled when we entered and the hostess informed us that they decided to move their opening time to 11am that day because the kitchen had been slammed in prior days and needed some extra time to get ready.  Huh?   Rather than wait an hour we took our business elsewhere.  

However, determined to give it a try, our party of 4 arrived on the following Thursday night at 6:30pm.  After a brief wait we were seated in the rear of the restaurant at a 6 top.   

Our server promptly offered Hetch Hetchy's finest sparkling or still and oriented us to the menu.  We started with the corn dogs, fried clams and butter lettuce salad.  All were served promptly and tasted great.    For entrees we ordered the diver scallops small plate; the fig, arugula and blue cheese pizza (but restrained ourselves from adding the Spanish ham); the spaghetti; and the porchetta.   All dishes were fantastic.  Standouts were the pizza - the flavors were wonderful and the crust a perfect balance of crisp and chewy, and the spaghetti - perfectly al dente with a nice amount of spice from the jalapeno.  We skipped dessert, but one of our group did order a decaf espresso.  It was considerably delayed, but we didn't really notice because we were enjoying our conversation.  However, the waiter comped it without solicitation.  Nice touch.   

Additionally, the waiter, who was very well informed about the wine list and offered just the right amount of background on the bottles we asked about, recommended a bottle of Qupe Marsanne with the meal. It was an excellent choice and worked well with the variety of dishes we had selected.

One note: the restaurant is NOISY!  After we left, all 4 of us were hoarse from speaking so loudly and our ears were ringing a bit.    

All-in-all, a great experience.  After 2 weeks, the kitchen seems to have hit a good rhythm.   Service was attentive, well informed and well executed.   Also, the price point is set appropriately.  We all agreed the bill was more than reasonable for the quality of the food and service.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Starbelly is a nice place in the heart of the Castro. Nice people around, Good food, nice ambience. The best feature though is Giordana. We sat at the Bar and she is the best Bartender we have ever had... Attentive, informed and informative, kind and cute as a button. Strongly recommended!
author: Diego S.

description:
Love it!  A new castro hot spot with creative plates and a great beer list.  Nice vibe, great fun staff and good energy, all at really reasonable prices.  Great location too. 
Some stuff tries too hard - like their dessert menu, which seems a touch complicated (sometimes you just want chocolate ice cream).  but in general, thank you!  A yummy new spot in the hood!
author: Juliana S.

description: Attended a group dinner here; not an easy thing to manage.  The service was wonderful.  I had the squash and goat cheese appetizer - wonderful!!  Followed with the trout dinner - delicious and very low carb.  Then a wonderful latte and great conversation with a great group of guys.  All in all, a wonderful experience.  I do wish that in this day of technology, they'd be able to easily do separate checks, even for a group of 15.  Can't be that difficult.  Isn't enough of a concern to drop the stars at all.  Absolutely delicious.
author: Pete H.

description:
ok, i love beretta. their cocktail menu kicks ass. especially once i was grown up enuf to learn there is life outside vodka. hello rye. but, i was a bit underwhelmed by their food. so i was in no hurry to try starbelly. lucky for me a friend planned a bday dinner here and i was forced into it. nothing like being forced into something that turns out to be oh so delightful. 

i'm actually still thinking/dreaming/drooling about and over their bacon, jalapeno, and arugula pizza with goddess dressing. really well executed, perfect thin crust, not quite as beautifully blistered around the edges as marzano's but i can let it pass. don't just go for the pizza tho. the menu has an eclectic mish-mash of appetizer options that are a fun way to start out. 

we tried the wild mushrooms with the over easy duck egg (good, but needed just a lil dash of salt), the crab hush puppies (really tasty and a nice hefty size) and the brussel sprouts (after having them at barbacco a week prior, these were a bit of a let down. whatever they did to them totally destroyed that essential tangy bitter flavor of the sprout. too sad.). and of course,  you can't get four women together without indulging in fries. which we did. loved them here. they were perfectly crisp, not too greasy, great PMS food. 

the beer and wine selection is extensive and not too pricey. and they have a cocktail menu too--this is the castro after all. but i was intrigued by the beer selection. i choose a really yummy malty beer from cooperstown, ny that was like dessert in a glass. i'd go back just for that beer.  they also give you the option between a small or large beer size, which i loved. why don't more places do this? 

we also had dessert, both were quite yummy. the chocolate and peanut butter sundae was super sinful, and had a little salt in it that really brought out the dark chocolate flavor of the ice cream. and the toffee cake drizzled with caramel and with a side of marscapone cream and dates was also ridiculous.  

the interior is a combination of natural and sleek with lots of blonde wood, and a spare, simple aesthetic. it's got a nice warmth to it, the long narrow space feels cozy but not crowded and the lighting is soft and low. it's a great casual date spot, or good for getting together to catch up with friends.
author: rachel p.

description: THIS PLACE derserves at least 4 stars.  I think it is quite cool inside, classy and interesting, and they have outdoor seating too.  The wine and beer selection is great.  So are the salads.  The chilaquiles were very bland though (needed more kick!) Everything else I have had is great.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I try to visit a place a few times before reviewing. Buuuut, Starbelly deserves a review for an awesome dinner. 

Six people ordered a variety of food including split pea soup, risotto, mushroom pizza and the crab salad. ALL was amazing. Honestly, that was the best split pea soup I've ever had. 

Our waitress was great as well. Super professional, helpful and took her time to explain the items on the menu.

Finally, they have one of my favorite drinks -- Pimms Lemonade. And they make it right. Can't wait to go back and try the brunch menu.
author: A K.

description: They are out of their league, and don't seem to know what they are doing.  The MUNI of restaurants in SF.
author: Stephen G.

description:
Ugh!

Poor service, dirty, wilted lettuce, with the ends left on, chicken fat and chicken parts in the "pulled chicken sandwich"...and nothing else.  Oh and it was served on burnt bread!
And this was in their first week of opening.  Are you kidding me?
author: Chad S.

description:
My friends and I stumbled upon this place today and the three of us had a solid lunch for 40 bucks...the food was fresh & tasty, the server was attentive, and the prices were very reasonable.  

Since the Castro is sort of an overpriced culinary wasteland...Starbelly is a welcome addition.  I'm eager to check out the weekend brunch.
author: Jon F.

description:
This is my favourite restaurant in SF.

I keep going back here and have never been disappointed with the service or the food.  For the price, its great.
author: Dave F.

description: Nasty service, mediocre food. No wonder it's such a success in the Castro. Just another reason to stick to other neighborhoods.
author: Mike M.

description:
A friend and I decided to try this place out, and we got there around 5:45pm. We were greeted by the GM Anthony, who I have known for years. He was a welcoming face and attentive. At this hour, good tables are available, and we sat against the wall in one of the three high tables of deuces. I t was an amazing table and we were able to people watch and see the action in the kitchen. We were then greeted by the owner, who by the way, was on the line expediting the whole time we were there, making sure all the plates were up to par.

As we enjoyed our corn dogs, the room started to fill up. The communal table was a big hit and the room felt good. The vibes were positive and energetic. 

We decided on the Caesar salad, porchetta and chicken pot pie. The Caesar was good, with a nice touch of avocado. The porchetta was amazing..moist, crispy skin and the salsa Verde was a nice touch.  The pot pie was delicious. My friend who loves pot pie, enjoyed the biscuit topping and flavor full filling.

We enjoyed a nice bottle of Broadside Chardonnay. Which to our as may, was bit more on the ML side, but still suited the food well.

We ended our meal with the Dynamo Chocolate Doughnut with Cream Cheese Ice Cream  and topped with Aleppo Chile's. Delicious and satisfying.

Great ambiance with great food and service. Bravo!
author: Mick's P.

description:
I had a great dinner at Starbelly last night. Although very busy we were looked after by one of the owners from the moment we got through the door.

The food was spot on, I had the lamb and grits and would highly recommended it. My friends had the pizza and salad and there were smiles all round. Our server was excellent and knew the menu well.

Check this place out, be prepared to wait a little but I'm sure you'll enjoy the food and service.
author: Rob P.

description: Had a great lunch here today! Liked the setting, great service, and yummy food! Enjoyed the chorizo and egg pizza and the burger, both were delish. Also tried the chiliquiles and highly recommend that too. And the fries were great. Had a nice glass of Pinot as well. Good vibe here, we were chatting with the folks next to us, very chill and friendly. We'll be back! :-)
author: Sarah R.

description: Whether you're at the communal table or a private one, there's nothing that could make you deny how fun this place is! Excellent food and friendly service and atmosphere. Their pizzas are sooooo delicious and the CHEESE plate is a must! And you'll definitely see the heat in the kitchen. Great place to stop in before a night out to the Castro.
author: Claude C.

description:
Away from the tourist path, Starbelly proved to be a great local gem! The place was packed, including the back patio dining area, but the staff proved to be perfectly capable of handling the volume. 
The menu was pretty brief, but all the dishes we had (there were 5 of us so we shared) were excellent. 
They do not have a full bar, but their wine and beer selections are actually very good and extensive.
I loved the liver pate, the scallops and the mushroom pizza, but the highlight was definitely the mascarpone risotto! The best risotto I've ever had! Dessert was a delicious surprise, too- make sure you pair it with a dessert wine!
It is a pretty noisy place, so do not go there to discuss important business, but it is the perfect spot to start a night on the town with friends.
author: Le Big Mac A.

description: I have been to Starbelly on two separate occasions and I felt lucky to get in both times.  Staff is very inviting and on point.  Food is plentiful and has a nice selection.  Tried the fries with three dips, garlic sesame chicken wings, and pizza with starbelly bacon, jalapeno, arugula & green goddess dressing. Everything tasted great and the jalapeno's matched well with the arugula.
author: Michael B.

description:
It's nice to see another good restaurant in the Castro.  We had the mini corn dogs, sausage, burger, pizza.  All good.

I had a homemade Pimm's cup and it was amazing.  They have some great cocktails.
author: Will S.

description:
One of my faves!  

Definitely a "go-to" for me.  For brunch, lunch or dinner- it's all good.  I have never been disappointed.  Never had a long wait, staff has always been welcoming and kind, food has been great and ambiance Is perfect. minimal and organic vibe.  I especially like the back patio with the herb garden and the wall plants.  I also like the re-use of the bowling alley flooring to make the long communal table inside.

Oh, but the food is truly devine.  I keep going back for the Liver pate.  Yum yum yum.  The menu changes a bit, but I notice they keep a handful of their staples and continue to use organic/seasonal ingredients.  Some other faves:  Chorizo and egg pizza, chilaquilles, star belly salad, roasted half chicken and scallops dish.
author: AdeleAdele S.

description: One work ... awesome ... great service ...  great food, great culinary team ... great vibe .. I love this place.  We go in for simple pizza and appy's all the time, god so good.  Thin crisp crust, awesome toppings and some of the best small bites you'll find in SF.  The Salumi is to die for!  Bout time the castro had an awesome spot for hip food.
author: Troy C.

description:
Today was my second visit and it was so good! The first time I came at the awkward time of day, between lunch and dinner and just had snacks. Cheese board and charcuterie. I have to say the housemade Mortadella was the best I've ever had - seriously I could have eaten it all myself!
Today I went for brunch and one of my friends is Vegan. Although not listed on the menu, the staff was very happy to accommodate her. I had their version of a Pimms cup w/ a garnish of cucumber and thyme - delish!  I ordered the butternut squash pizza with garlic and goat cheese w/ pumpkin seeds, so good!
I like the fact the server comes to the table with flat or sparkling water automatically - not having to go and order it. Making it onsite is brilliant. 
I only knock a star because the seats for me are uncomfortable. Stylish yes and I know seats in bistros are supposed to make you want to eat and to but my tush doesn't like the seats much. I'll suffer tho - for that food? for real!
author: Erica C.

description:
DISCLAIMER: This review is for the "Crab Feast" that Starbelly hosted on 12/7/10 and doesn't reflect a review of Starbelly's regular menu.

OK, so you're still with me?  Good.
I'm a sporadic reader of the sfeater blog but checked it last week and read that Starbelly would be hosting a crab feast to celebrate the opening of Dungeness season.  I immediately called and was thrilled to snag a table at 8pm (they were doing seatings at 6pm and 8pm).  

We entered the restaurant not having eaten there before and having no idea what to expect from the crab feast.
I was pleasantly surprised to be led to the covered patio, attractively lit with twinkle lights, and was happy to see newspaper on our table.  The pleasant surprises just kept coming all night.  Starbelly handled the crab feast beautifully: you sat down, saw a menu of what you'd be getting and then were promptly served a demitasse cup of ridiculously good crab bisque.  SUPER rich so the serving size was perfect.  They had the winemaker of the wine they were pouring AT the feast, so he came by and started us off with some blanc de blancs.  Then, it was basically a buffet which included ceasar salad and a guy in front of a grill and a huge pot cooking both house-made sausages and, of course, the CRAB!  They offered melted butter and a creamy-style sauce as accompanyments.  You could go up as often as you wanted for the food.  We were also offered chardonnay with dinner and appreciated the generous refill policy.  
Our server was lovely and full of personality, the free-flowing wine was a big plus and the crab was outstanding.  I actually ate most of it with no sauce and just enjoyed the sweet, fresh claw meat scented with Old Bay.  
There was apple cobbler for dessert but I just enjoyed more crab.

At $49/person, this felt like a deal and a half!  What a smart use of the patio and a great way to showcase both the restaurant and our local seafood treasure!  Our server said they'd do similar events in the future and to be on the look-out for them.  I absolutely will be and look forward to returning to Starbelly to try out their regular fare.
author: Auburn D.

description: Me and my partner-in-crime gave the 'Belly a whirl a few weeks ago, and I am super-impressed. Everything they serve is house-made ... a fact that becomes abundantly clearer with each bite. If (like me) you're not a fan of 'cattle cuddle' seating, wherein you wind up nestled next to other diners, be sure to phone ahead and put your name in for a table-table. They don't take reservations, but will permit you to add yourself to the wait list remotely. I sincerely had the BEST burger in recent memory, and cannot wait to come back and nom-nom-nom more from their menu.
author: Gregor G.

description: Nice food and great atmosphere. I especially like the different drinks they have. Outdoor seating is great in nice weather.
author: Erhan E.

description: I've been here three times now, twice for lunch and once for dinner.  The dinner was amazing.  I had probably the best split pea  soup ever (no hyperbole) as well as a succulent dungeness crab salad.  The prices are really reasonable considering the quality, and the staff always seems to be on top of their game.  While the lunches didn't wow me as much for whatever reason, the awesome back patio more than made up for it in my mind.  Definitely a fan!
author: Daryl W.

description: Yes, I know some people on the staff, but that does not change the fact that the food, service and overall experience here just gets better and better.  Today we split the dungeness crab salad, wild mushroom pizza and BLT. The BLT was on a dreamy, soft roll w/ a bit of sauce and that amazing SB bacon, but the star was the crab salad- O.M.G.  Sweet sticks of celery root and slices of tart apple were tossed with piles of sweet crab meat, all over a bed of baby arugula and scattered with toasted pistachios- to. die.
author: David M.

description:
I've been to Starbelly a half dozen times in the past few months. Perhaps due to the fact that I can't get the food out of my mind. I have tried: the house cut fries with three dips - heavenly. I always trick myself into thinking that all fries are created equal. One taste of Starbelly's fries proves how completely false that is. They are dense and crispy strips of delight. The three dips a perfect treat for the indecisive, and a nice substitute for the typical katsup. The domestic cheese plate has some incredible cheeses on it. I have been spoiled with knowledge of superior French, English and Irish cheeses so it is hard to find cheeses in California that have a robust or deeply nutty flavor. Somehow Starbelly has found them. If they have Brussels sprouts on the menu, get them. They know how to cook 'em exactly the way they need to be cooked. Every time we go in we get a pizza. We have never been let down. The half rotisserie chicken is a lot of food, but completely worth it. I am desperate to try their Pot Pie, but alas, it was sold out and then off the menu.

On top of savory and sweet treats, both light and comfort-style filling, Starbelly touts a cozy yet chic decor. The place has the wooden essence of a cabin, with the streamlined sexiness of a modern art store. It's the perfect spot if you aren't dressed up but want to enjoy a hot night out, and works well if you are dressed to the nines. Not many places can pull that sort of feeling off.

Be sure to sample the cocktail list. I highly recommend their bartender Ben, (tall chap, reserved - but the kind of reserved that is enticing, and so knowledgeable about what drink will suit your taste). Starbelly has it all, friendly and charismatic staff, delectable food, and a superior setting.
author: Tawnee K.

description:
I loved this place.  I have taken all my out of town friends to this establishment.  On Thursday we had the worst experience.  We made a reservation for 6:30.  My two friends arrived at 6:20 and I got their at 6:25.  The server was not bad nor was she exponential.   We order apps, three entrees, a bottle of win, several additional glasses of win and desserts. We got the check and we were finishing our drinks, when we were told by our server  they needed our table and could we move to a communal table.  I was annoyed.  There were folks that were at the restaurant before us and they were still linger and yet, they needed OUR table.  We got our first order at 6:40.  We got the check at 8:25 and Danielle, our server,  wanted us out.  I am sorry that they overbooked but guess what- NOT MY PROBLEM.  Oh, it gets better.  The manager is clearing our table with our wine still in our glasses and he says, did you have a good time.  When I responded, actually no.  He was a deer in headlights.  (Little coaching: do not ask a question  if you do not want a sincere response.) When I stated, we were here for less than 1 hour and 20 minutes...we were not done.  Why the rush?  I calmed down and called back that evening and Trent gave me a list  of all the things Starbelly strives for:

1.  Starbelly's does not want customer to feel uncomfortable. Grade: F
2. Starbelly's does not want customers to feel rushed.  Grade: F
3.  Starbelly's does not want customers to feel service was less than stellar.  Grade: B

To his credit, Trent realized we were at an impasse and he offered to take my phone number for his manager.   They get two stars for the professionalism of Jessica, the manager. She was understanding and apologized. Allegedly, they sent me out a gift card.  Will I come back?  Honestly, not sure!
author: Alison H.

description: Since my last visit I did try Starbelly for dinner and had a better experience.  I moved them up a star because the food and service were both good and the overall experience was what I would expect from a restaurant of this type.  Nice to see some improvement.
author: Matthew S.

description:
"I've come here to help you. I have what you need. And my prices are low. And I work with great speed. And my work is one hundred per cent guaranteed!" -Sylvester McMonkey McBean (The Sneetches)

Indeed, Starbelly had what we needed.  We walked in plain-bellied, and walked out...well, while not quite starred, our bellies were definitely grinning from love handle to love handle. This may have been due to the fact that three of us ate enough for six people, because gluttony loves company.

Virtually every element of our experience at this restaurant was awesome: the décor, the service, the bar, the food, and the vibe. BEa-u-TI-ful.

The décor was modern and minimalist, very Zen. My feng was shui'd by the tasteful details, like the wood paneling, cardboard lamp shades and bowling lane bar/group table. The bowling lane is a great way to "see" the menu based on what other people are eating (just don't turn your back or your neighbor might give in to temptation..."you gonna finish that?" nom nom nom).

Oliver, our server, was helpful, attentive, engaging, thoughtful, and reminded me a bit of Mr. McBean with his Dr. Seuss-esque handlebar mustache. He made some great recommendations, and was eager to assist in our gastronomical seppuku.

Our ritual began with some cocktails. I've never seen a bar offer such an assortment of mixed drinks without hard alcohol.  We had a Calimocho (coke and red wine) that got HUGE props for its presentation - a coke bottle stuffed into a cocktail shaker filled with shaved ice. The Housemade Pimm's cup with cucumber and mint was also a hit.  But the standout of the night was the mango Michelada - beer and mango juice, with the glass rimmed with a blend of cayenne and salt. (A portion of the proceeds from this particular drink go towards the Maitri Organization, which is an SF-based non-profit group that runs a women's peer to peer help network.)

Our food parade:
- POPCORN CLAMS: nummy fried clams, perfect consistency and ratio of batter to clam, but ultimately these were just sponges for the old bay remoulade (and we could have used 2-3 times more remoulade)
- House-made CHICKEN LIVER PATE: this was stellar - rich flavor, a smooth consistency, and a hint of sea salt and chive in every mouthful. Whoa.
- MUSHROOM PIZZA: mmm...gruyere, thyme and roasted onions - brilliant combo. Zero complaints; and very reminiscent of the pizzas at Beretta.
- Prather Ranch BURGER: THIS was a damn GREAT burger. Ours was with aged cheddar, and it was moist, juicy, and groan-inducing. The fries were a most excellent compliment, however, to me they were ever-so-so-slightly undercooked i.e., if you held one between your fingers, it would flop over instead of standing up straight (...yeah, sometimes the joke is just too obvious to be worth stating).
- ROASTED PORCHETTA: I can see a lot of people balking at this entree - imagine a slice of roasted pork belly the size of a Frisbee, which is easily 50+% fat. Granted, it is an authentic Italian delicacy, but it can catch people by surprise. We opted to have a dish of sea salt brought to our table, which we sprinkled over the fattiest portions - this cut the oil, and added a bit of texture, and was a great assist to the dish. The salsas (dashes of each) were an interesting, but not unwelcome accompaniment. The wilted greens, however, were oily and didn't add any character to the dish.
- SPAGHETTI: WWHHOOOO-HOOOO!!!! THIS was the highlight of the evening. The smokiness of the house-cured bacon, roasted tomato sauce, fresh basil and the jalapano kick: Party. In. My. Mouth. The spaghetti was thick cut, and per-fect-ly al dente. After the first bite of this dish, all three of us needed a private moment.

EVERY item on the dessert menu is appealing. Our guts were completely bursting by this point, but we couldn't not have one dessert. We went with Ed George's peaches with Humphrey Slocombe ice cream. They were out of the olive oil ice cream, so we asked for the balsamic-caramel flavor (against their recommendation). While both the peaches and the ice cream were delicious on their own, the flavors clashed. Still, our amateur mistake, and no marks against our lovely hosts.

Without any doubt, we will be back because at some point, our bellies will go back to being plain, and our bellies will once again want to have stars upon thars.
author: Nils E.

description: For a town with such great restaurants, this just isn't one of them.  It's not a bad choice and wine list is decent -- and they had some delicious fried anchovies, it's true.  But the patio is sorta bland and boring.  I want to like this place: they're doing everything largely right.  But it just doesn't quite satisfy.
author: David B.

description: I was happy with my brunch and the service.  Beautiful interior and relaxed atmosphere.  I had the eggs, spinach, and potatoes served in a small iron skillet.  Sparkling water was complimentary.  We sat at the front and didn't realize there is a gorgeous patio in the back.  The dining area in the back is just as lovely.  (Hm...why am I enamored with the design as much as the food?)   Go for both - food and atmosphere.  Enjoy.
author: Becky G.

description: Cute place, good service.  Average food.  I ate the chicken breast with quinoa and braised chard; very liquid-y (the quinoa floated).
author: Andrew W.

description:
we came for a later dinner last night and were able to snag a spot on the corner of the communal table.  i love communal dining.  since it was thanksgiving wknd, a lot of people were probably out of town, so it wasn't as crowded.

we started w/ the popcorn clams and the fries.  the fries were awesome, but i couldn't really tell the popcorn clams were clams.  it seemed like a lot of batter to me, but yet i ate it.  i would probably skip that next time.  we also got the celery root and apple slaw, which was really good w/ pistachios and dried cherries.  finally, we shared the mushroom and guyere pizza, and it was so good.  i wanted to try the squash pizza, but maybe next time.  the crust was really thin and crisp.  to finish, we got the warm toffee cake w/ marscapone and dates.  yum.  it wasn't a huge portion, but it was the perfect amount to cleanse your palate.

i like the drinks here.  i had a mango michelada which is beer w/ a chili-salted rim and some mango juice.  they also had other interesting beer and champagne cocktails here that i will have to try next time!
author: Helen T.

description:
Starbelly has major service problems.  Went for Sunday brunch at 10:15 since their website advertises that they open at 10.  Wrong.  We got there and were told that they were making "minor adjustments"  to their hours and they would open at 11:00 on Sundays instead of 10:00. OK...so maybe you should change your website?  And, as it turns out, the hours you print on your receipts?

Decided to return home since we live nearby and go back at 11:15.  There were a few tables already seated and we were seated at a table in the back of the restaurant.  There were two women already seated at a table near ours.  Then we waited.  And waited.  The two women near us finally gave up and left.  We flagged someone down who clearly was not supposed to be our server, but she took our order anyway.  She brought the iced tea we ordered and then we never saw her again.  Food runners brought the food, but didn't know who ordered what.  Thinking it was a reasonable request, we asked for some ketchup and then waited some more.  Since he clearly forgot, we asked someone else.   The ketchup finally showed up, but it sure would have been nice to have it while the fries were hot.

The food was disappointing.  The frittata (unsurprisingly, spelled incorrectly on the menu) was barely warm and, as another Yelper pointed out, it was clearly pre-made.  C'mon folks...even Cafe Flore can manage a made-to-order frittata!  The pulled chicken sandwich is not pulled chicken.  It was chopped chicken and mayonnaise (also known as chicken salad!) with some slaw on it.  I love a good chicken salad sandwich, but call it that so I have a reasonable expectation about what I'm going to get.  

We never did see our server again.  The guy serving all the tables around us, who probably was supposed to our server, came by after our plates had been cleared and asked how we were doing.   Too little, way too late.  To top it off, there were two women chatting with each other at the host stand as we left.  They didn't even bother to acknowledge us, much less utter a simple "thanks."

Where's the management in this mess?  The people we saw all seem to be new to the restaurant business and there doesn't seem to be any management watching the store to ensure a smooth opening weekend.  Given the pedigree of the owners, I expected a whole lot more.  Maybe they'll get their act together, maybe not.  Will I go back to find out before they disappoint a lot more people and end up closing?  Dunno.
author: Glenn R.

description: The wait-staff's attitudes aren't justified by the food. The food is pretty okay, but the tastes are muddied by the bad ones the staff leaves. Granted, some of the people in my group weren't very friendly either, but when I smile at a waiter, I expect one back. Too much to ask?
author: Christian H.

description:
okay, here's the story: when we arrived at about 8:30, i put my name on a list of people waiting, talked with a guy at the reception stand or hostess station or whatever they call it. we needed a four top and i was told it would be about 45 minutes, an hour tops. i think it was the first day of work for the actual hostess who was completely out of control of the list, taking random groups of people, telling us, when we asked, that it'd be only a while. 

the "a while" turned into 90 minutes, without explanation, without checking on us or other would be customers waiting on the sidewalk. and at the end of this 90 minute wait, the hideous communal table option was offered, nay encouraged, with this caveat "... if you guys are okay with not all sitting together."  fuck that.

so, we waited some more and finally got a table way in the back.  the waitress knew the menu pretty well, god bless her, cuz it's all pretentiously worded in that irritating way, tossing in words that only food-weenies will know, to keep it all exclusive and ooh, aah in-the-know ... i mean, lettuce is lettuce, and bacon is bacon and i don't care who smoked and cured it. meanwhile, she recommended everything on it. 

food was not bad, particularly in comparison the utterly mediocre food served at ALL of the restaurants in the Castro, but it wasn't good either, you know what i mean? it all looked cute, which is important, right?

it boils down to being treated like a plain old Sneetch while the bitches running the list are Starbellied Sneetches, being treated poorly from the gate in a way that i haven't experienced since decades ago in New York. i'm about to shell out 12 bucks for an appetizer and you're going to leave me standing on 16th Street for almost 2 hours? now i know better and will tell EVERYONE i know who eats out in the Castro to avoid Starbelly
author: Kevin M.

description: I don't know what to say about the food, because we never got ours... We went for lunch, waited 45 minutes for two sandwiches (that never came) upon which time the waitress said "I don't know what's taking your salads so long?" The chef was walking around looking sour-faced and perturbed. The bus boy seemed frantic. I noticed tables getting their food out of order from when they were seated. Over all, this place needs several more months to settle in service-wise...my opinion is to stay away for a while until they get it sorted out.
author: Benjamin K.

description: I love Berreta, and when I heard that it's the same folks who run this ship I had to check it out. It's a great space with a beautiful long bar that turns into a communal table on one side (smart!).  Cool indie music playing in the background. We started out with a nice wannabe greek salad (the call it "cucumber salad) which was good not the best but good, then we had their excellent green beans, slightly grilled and topped with tomato sauce and pecorino - you must order this for sure if it's still on the menu. Then onto the pies: The salumi pie was fantastic, but the mushroom one a little disappointing. It was missing this one ingredient that would take it to the next level... Nice beer and wine list and they else serve food until midnight! BUT it's damn hot in there!
author: Chris D.

description: Skip this place for now. We stopped in for lunch and after 45 minutes our sandwiches still hadn't shown up. (The waitress said there was a problem in the kitchen...never a good sign.) so we left to find something to eat somewhere else...first time I've done that in years!
author: keith S.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant. I thought the food was solid, everything was tasty, though I preferred the appetizers (pate, burratta crostini) over their entree (fish). The Starbelly Pizza with in-house cured bacon rocks.
author: Amy L.

description: There is better food to be had in San Francisco, but for a great meal out that doesn't require much thought (or often a reservation) it's hard to beat Starbelly. Order a plate of their decent charcuterie, some salad and a pizza with fig, gorgonzola and arugula and you'll understand why it's such a popular place.
author: Ben R.

description:
we went based on recommendations of two friends who love this place- on paper, the menu looks good. Got in early (630) so we didn't need to wait for table and the bartender and hostess were very polite. There is 2 stars right there- but wait, I have only given one star- how can it be....because the waitress and the food were awful! we ordered the octopus and the highly rated corn dogs. The octopus was grilled beyond recognition and then they tried hiding it with a salad and some awful citrus vinaigrette. Horrible. My wife is a fan of the corn dog and she couldn't even get thru the first one- the breading on the outside was so bad there was not enough ketchup and mustard to offset it. We then ventured on to a salad- hard to screw that up right? Holy shit- there was so much dressing on it that it resembled a soup more than a salad. Lets get this dinner over with- pizza. Bacon, peppers and tomato- yum, sounds good. WAIT- the bacon is not crisp but chewy and just gross. 

I will not give this a second chance at all. I am starting to think that the 2 guys who recommended did so because they go late night and looped!
author: Scott W.

description: Really solid food, try the wine/coke concoction, it's awesome!
author: Lucky L.

description: I just cannot stay away from Starbelly.  I stopped in today even though my favorite sandwich, the BLT is on hiatus until the return of tomato season.  I dined on the fish tacos and was most impressed.  The name does not do it justice... "fish tacos".  It was beyond my expectations.  And the service staff was absolutely wonderful, as usual.
author: M M.

description:
starbelly is a solid experience, and pretty close to where i live.  i went there for brunch on a weekend, and everything was really decent and satisfying.

many times, its the little things that make a place shine.  my belgian style IPA was perfect, and it seems like they know what theyre doing with beers on tap.  the cofee is mr. espresso, served french press style.  they even have a selection of dynamo donuts, of which i had an apricot.

i ordered the burger as per suggestion, medium rare, with a salad.  it was definitely above average and filling.  the best burger in the city?  ehhhh no...but it might belong in the top 5.  the condiments made the burger very fresh and crisp.

it also seems their brunch menu has the best hangover drinks and summertime cooler-type drinks.  i need to go back and try some of these, and some egg dishes.  ohh...and of course dinner!
author: Robert S.

description: they are very friendly and the food ought to be delicious. i just wish if they could have vegeterian/vegan options.
author: B H.

description:
Disappointing for the "solo diner", and I felt like a plainbelly sneetch.  I was excited about Starbelly opening up a few blocks from me.  From looking at the website I hoped it would a good place to sit at the bar and enjoy a glass of wine and a half chicken with a book. 

1) Ask the hostess for a seat at the bar, and she immediately seats me at the communal table (one star).  

2) Then...I wait.  20 minutes.  For anyone to even acknowledge my existence.  I began torquing my body around trying to make eye contact with anyone.  I would have flagged down my waiter, but I had no idea who they were.  

3) The waiter comes (finally) and I order the chicken with potatoes and beans and a glass of wine.

4) Another 10 minute wait, then my wine comes.  The restaurant was hot and loud, but no one ever came and gave me water. (Perhaps I should have asked, but there was no one to ask).

5) My food arrives, around 55 minutes after I sat down.  The beans and potatoes were good, but the chicken was disappointingly flavorless.  I wanted salt and pepper, but there was none on the table (and no one to ask).  

6) I try looking for my waiter to pay my bill and get the heck out out of there.  

7) The waiter comes over to the people (just sat) next to me and immediately offers them their choice of water. 

8) I feel like a total loser (all around me, groups of  starbellied sneetches are enjoying delicious food), and I still don't have my bill.  

9) Out of nowhere, a manager appears.  He asks how my meal was, and I say 'dreadful--no waiter, long waits, no water, but I understand it's your opening night'.  He asks how he can make it better--I just want to leave.  He comps my meal (unasked).  (second star)

10)   I'll try Starbelly again when I have some backup to go as a group, (the food looks like it's meant to be shared, and if I had multiple dishes I wouldn't be so bummed by my dud chicken) but for a place that advertises as "your home away from home.", really disappointing.
author: Edie H.

description:
Having lived and dined out in San Francisco for more years than I care  to remember, I had never once been in this building - not even when it was Josie's Cabaret !
We decided to give it a try on Sunday for brunch and arrived around 2.30.p.m. We were greeted warmly but informed that they had run out of food to cookn and serve !!!!!!!!
Astounding !
author: Harold G.

description: Another solid restaurant...I enjoyed the crab hushpuppies (which were basically just crab cakes but in the shape of a ball instead of a cake, but good nonetheless), and the pizza with pear, blue cheese, arugula and proscuitto.  Love the thin crust pizzas!  I also managed to snag a bite of the spaghetti with bacon, jalepeno, tomato and basil.  Simple but good flavor.  The pasta was thick and al dente, just the way I like it.  I wouldn't mind trying the burger next time...heard lots of rave reviews around the table.
author: Kelly H.

description: Searching for Brunch this Sunday was not an easy task. I had my 19 month old rockstar, her godfathers and the hubby in tow. We bounced from usual spots that were not cool to squeeze in the little one. Finally I saw a star in the distance with no long line at front. The hostess was HAPPY to accommodate us, the waitress was HAPPY to serve us, and we were HAPPY to eat the delish food. I loved the decor, I am IN LOVE with the SUMMER BLUSH cocktail! But one star off due to my pulled pork sandwhich. The meat itself was decent, but bland. I tried everyone else's dishes (mostly eggy stuffs) and the eggs were cooked to perfection. Can't wait to eat here for dinner.
author: Tricia G.

description:
My friends and I were excited to try a new place for Sunday brunch.  We were greeted well by the hostess and seated immediately.  That was the end of the good experience.  We sat for upwards of ten minutes before the waitress appeared and brought us water.  We ordered a bottle of champagne and one small oj for mimosa's.  This complex drink order was 10-15 minutes in the making.  Only after the waitress brought the mimosa's did she take our food order.  We've now been sitting here for 25 or so minutes.  Two of our meals come rather quickly, but the 3rd was no where in sight.  We waited a few minutes but begrudgingly began to eat while it was still warmish, only to find that there isn't any flavor to our dishes.  Even the figs had no flavor.  I don't know how they did it, but had I not seen that it was a fig on my fork I would not have been able to tell you what I was eating.  Almost another 10 minutes later, the long awaited burger arrived but didn't stay long.  It was ordered to be medium, but was so raw you could've milked this thing!  Disgusted and just over the whole experience, my friend sent it back and asked that it just be removed from the bill.  As a consolation, the manager brings us a trio of doughnuts to finish off our tasteless meal.  While eating the treats, the waitress stops back by and comments on how they bought them from "a Mexican girl who rides her bike around selling them".  She acted like this is a charming selling point.  Ummm...EW!! Where were they cooked? Who's touched them?   At this point we finished off the champagne, which was the best part of the meal, and got the hell out of there.  

There are certain things you can expect at a new restaurant, such as slow service.  In this case, the entire waitstaff standing around gabbing by the kitchen while most of the room is looking to them for their food.  This forgivable situation can easily be remedied by either a quick refresher on customer service, or termination.  What is inexcusable is the off timing of the food and it coming out raw.  Presumably, the chef has previous experience, in which case this never should have happened.
author: Dana E.

description:
Starbelly is a popular eating joint in the Castro. A group of us went the other night (with reservations) and it was PACKED on a Monday evening. The menu looked fabulous and I couldn't wait to try everything (our first time). Since there were nine of us, we were able to sample quite a bit of what Starbelly had to offer. Aside from being very popular and seemingly inexpensive....some of us were not so impressed in the end. Perhaps it was an off night in the kitchen but....

FOOD: the food is 2.5 stars....yes, and I'm being generous. The appetizers and salads are small (salads doused in white vinegar), the calamari Small Plate, while tasting very good, had only a tiny spoonful of calamari, the pizzas were very disappointing, the desserts were better. Since the pizzas are the mainstay there, I'll explain. They were salty, cheese not so great, toppings very very sparse and the crust dull and under-baked. The Margarita and the Fig/Arugula pizzas fared the best of our choices.
DRINKS: their wine pours are generous, which is nice. 
AMBIENCE: if you have ear plugs, bring them. The decibels are ear-piercingly, blood-drippingly painful--at least inside that night; the patio may be a bit calmer. 
SERVERS: they were busy...out it comes, down it goes on the table.  I did enjoy the bartenders though (hubbie and i were early, so sat there for awhile); they have more time to be gracious and attentive.

If you're in need of full-house human contact, this is the place to hang out. Everyone seems to love it.....but honestly, our $80 dinner ($340 smackers split nine ways) was not worth it at all....Starbelly is racking it in.
author: fused g.

description:
went with a friend for a weeknight dinner. no problem walking in and getting a table around 7:30. things i was pleasantly surprised by + enjoyed:

hostess = laidback, relaxed + accomodating
sangiovese from baja = great wine from baja. BAJA.
chicken pate dish = great for sharing
market apple + celery root salad = great seasonal salad
atmosphere = cozy + buzzing, not too loud or crowded 
scallops = great flavor

didn't get to try the pizza... next time. but overall nice place with yummy food.
author: Deena M.

description: The corn meal fried sardines and the blackened catfish was so lovely. For dessert, the caramel pot de creme was absolutely unforgettable...it reminded me of the darker parts of a flan which I adore.
author: Kandy F.

description: One of the only places in the city you can get bottles of Hitachino Nest white ale. Solid showing of draft beer, fantastic friendly service, and awesome hanging light shades sold me on their concept.
author: Alex B.

description:
My girlfriends and I went last night to celebrate a birthday. We had heard great things about Starbelly but we were blown away! The decor is a mixture of beautiful woods and glass; the outdoor patio is a combination of cozy, complete with overhead heaters, and chic. And although the restaurant was full, we were seated immediately and we did not feel rushed. The service was attentive and friendly, but it was the food that sealed the deal for us. We had such a hard time choosing that we ended up ordering five dishes to share. The hominy soup was a standout, as was the asparagus pizza and the salted caramel pot de creme, which was simply divine!  
While Starbelly may be a "neighborhood restaurant", those of us who live in the East Bay will come back time and time again to get our fix!
author: Cathy O.

description:
Finally, an establishment with good eats coming into my neighborhood!  I am ecstatic the team behind Beretta chose the Castro as the launching pad for bringing seasonal/sustainable American/California cuisine to my hood.  This is definitely a stretch from Asqew grill that previously sat in this building (hence why most of the gay men on here are saying how horrible the food/service is.  They don't get it's NOT Fuzio or Baghdad Cafe).  
The heirloom tomato gazpacho, amazeballs.  The fresh avocado and the salsa just give the gazpacho an extra kick to our palette.  The thin-crust pizzas, delish.  Who wouldn't want warm figs and fresh goat cheese on a pizza?  The fries and the three sauces, totally a mouth watering treat.  Especially loved the homemade ketchup!?  And the cheese plate, the best California has to offer.
The atmosphere, finally a mix of individuals who enjoy good eats, gay men steering away from places like Blue and Fuzio on their Friday night dates, and sustainable reused materials to make yourself feel comfortable whilst taking in a bite of fresh locally grown foods.  
The only reason this place is getting four stars from me is for the fact of them not being very quick to turn over tables, but this only occurs during peak hours (dinner).  If you want to get in without the hassle definitely do this place for lunch.  Also, they do not have their liquor license, which is a downside.  But don't blame them, blame the neighbors and the Castro Merchant Association (hence why their outdoor seating will never come to fruition).  This place will truly shine if they can bring in the type of choice liquor drinks like their sister, Beretta.
author: Boho H.

description: Going to try to keep this short and sweet.  So I went here recently with a whole bunch of girls as sort of a "bachelorette night" minus any naked men.  Just wanted some yummy food and wine.  Starbelly completely met my needs and actually was one of the best SF restaurant experiences I have had in quite some time.  There were 10 of us total and overall Starbelly exceeded my expectations.  The food and service was awesome, it wasn't too terribly loud, and no one made us feel rushed even though we were there for quite a while.  It was my first time there and honestly, I can't wait to go back.  The pizzas were interesting yet divine, and the toffee cake was unreal!  Highly recommended!!
author: Yvette H.

description: For the Castro this place is decent. But for a foodie? No, definitely not. Beretta's entrees have always played second to its amazing cocktails, appetizers and desserts. When you take away the fantastic cocktail options and don't offer interesting appetizers, then what do you have? I say go for a drink but don't expect anything too inventive. It's also loud. Maybe they will improve the menu - again, for the Castro, this place is a good option, but I wouldn't travel out of my way to go here. Side note - why more places don't open in the Castro, I have no idea. Lots of us don't have kids, like to go out and consider ourselves foodies. It's an untapped gold mine.
author: Kimberly H.

description: I would go back just for the Salted Caramel dessert. I'm a fan of their salads and I like the pizza. I wish they would add way more mushrooms!!
author: Mei F.

description: Had a lovely lunch here on a work day. The waitress was great, informative but not overbearing. Split two sandwiches with my man and we were both pleased. The vibe is cool and the cookies for dessert were bomb!
author: Elise B.

description: The duck liver pate with apricot pistachio compote is PHENOMENAL. Also the celery root salad with dried cherries is effin' good! Mini corn dogs with housemade ketchup-noms! Just sayin' Porchetta was a little too gamey for my liking but everything else was tasty!
author: Suzanne L.

description: Been here now four times each time there was a wait as the place is new and has a lot of folks checking it out. The Food here is pretty good, I've tried the pizzas, pastas, and the burger all in all they were quite tasty. The communal table made from an old bowling lane is nice for single diners but if you are with a group and need a table be prepared to wait. When crowded (which is almost always) the service can be a bit slow but on each of my visits the wait staff was very pleasant.
author: Pat C.

description:
+

prompt helpful service, servers knew menus.  food spectacular.  pizza with blue cheese and fig yummy.  

-
layout of restaurant is a little strange.  the chairs are a little short and they seem shorter when everyone is sitting on tall stools!
author: pete c.

description: Look, I live across the street. I eat here ALL the time. Probably around 50 times already. No joke. Dinner, lunch, brunch, you name it. I've had everything on the menu (including the fact that they change the menu), at least a few times. The food is awesome. I've never had anything not awesome, and I cook and am happy to criticize mediocre food. It's ridiculous the overall rating isn't close to perfect.
author: Marc W.

description:
Came for: Patio Picnic Tuesdays ($25/person)
Will come back for: well, yes

Just a few days ago I'd passed it and was quite intrigued.  Fortunately for me, friends invited me to dinner there the very next day.  
Upon entering, I immediately liked the decor -- the casual and low maintenance wood-sy look.  The Patio Picnic was held in the back area set up as a backyard with heat lamp and all (very appropriate).
When we sat down, our server immediately brought out the starter of seafood ceviche on tortilla chips (one for each of us).  Very good and a nice touch.
The main cast was Grilled tri tip "Santa Maria" style.  I regret to share that the tri tip was quite marbled and just too fatty.  It was cooked right (juicy, medium / medium-rare), but the cut was just too marbled.  
All other dishes were not wanting.  
The avocado and tomato salad was simple yet with fresh ingredients.  The tortillas (they had both corn and flour) and chips were noticeably good -- corn tortilla was just the right gritty and didn't turn rubbery when cooled down; tortilla chips were crispy without being too oily.
The chocolate pot de creme with the spice had a good kick.
The dulche de leche ice cream with chocolate shell covered with cornflakes was good. As a dark chocolate lover, I just wished both the desserts were with darker cacao.
From the tri-tip carver to our table's server, service was friendly and seamless.
We all came hungry and left stuffed.  Even if we hadn't gone back for seconds, there were still plenty of food in the picnic line-up to satiate our hunger and then some!

I left my first visit a little wanting (for reason mentioned above).  Nonetheless, the jury is still out and I want to come back for another visit.
author: Carol K.

description: I say it's a solid, great neighborhood rest.. When i want Little Star i go to Little Star. When i want to eat in a bar in the Mission w/ small plates i go to Beretta. When i want a "Starbelly" pizza (that's lite, simple, not loaded down, crisp AND chewy) or grilled Little Gems or  salty sweet greens w/ pear and goat cheese or the best savory bread pudding w/ simply roasted chicken.... Starbelly. Last few times thought the service was efficient and pleasant and that's all i'm really looking for. But please don't drop the check immediately after serving dessert (and put more ice cream on that thing!). You're casual, yeah, but not a diner. So don't. Some people finish w/ coffee, or a port, or another pizza or whatever! If you gotta get home THAT bad transfer the table.
author: T. J.

description: Warm atmosphere.  Friendly staff.  Excellent beer selection.  Tasty food.  Had lunch on my first visit here and dinner last night.  Manager came by to make sure we were happy.  Really enjoyed both meals.
author: Ivan N.

description:
Eh. This place could have been much better. The appetizers were probably the best part of the meal. We got a bunch to share amongst the table and they were tasty. The food wasn't memorable at all (I don't even remember any of the apps). For the entree I got a burger with fries. The fries were REALLY salty and the burger, even though it was medium rare, was pretty dry.

Service was good, but doesn't make up for the so-so food.
author: Young T.

description: Service is spotty, but the food keeps delivering. In the beginning I felt this place was hit or miss, but I think they've had enough time to hone their skills and menu for it to be pretty solid. The black garlic pizza is delicious, and the buratta appetizer (with english peas and TRUFFLE OIL) is stellar. Although this place is still pretty crowded on a weeknight, it's definitely worth checking out if you have the patience. You can also put your name in up to 45 minutes ahead, which helps if you don't have reservations...
author: Meredith M.

description: Stopped by for a quick, early dinner on a Monday - we walked right in and got a table. We ordered the cheese plate - which had a great variety of cheeses, a salad and a pizza. The service was good and the menu is reasonably priced.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
It goes without saying that Starbelly is going to be better than Asqew Grill, so I give points for that alone. To be honest, I looked at the dinner menu for this place, and was not that stoked to try it, simply because most of the items are things that I don't normally crave. Don't get me wrong: it's definitely a creative and varied selection...it's just not 100% in my comfort zone (brunch, however, has me drooling).

But I'm glad I let my friend drag me to dinner because the food was delicious and it was a very pleasant dining experience (though loud, like others have mentioned). We decided to split several things: the caesar, the popcorn clams, and the burger. Here's the breakdown:

*Caesar salad with butter lettuce, avocado, and buttery croutons: honestly, I was a bit skeptical about avo in a caesar, but this salad was great. Supper yummy housemade dressing and just enough of it. 
*Popcorn clams: must've been littleneck clams as they kind of looked like squid tentacles to me (tasted pretty much like calamari, too), though to be honest, I've only ever had clams straight outta the shell or clam chowder. The homemade Old Bay remoulade made the dish for sure (and be forewarned that it is rich, rich, rich!). 
*Prather Ranch burger, house cut fries & pickle, grilled brioche bun (with cheddar, of course!): probably the best burger I have ever had. It was melt-in-your-mouth tender and went well with the bun and heirloom tomato. The fries are shoestring style and honestly didn't look that great, but were quite tasty (and I don't really like fries). The clincher, however, is the housemade catsup and grainy mustard. The mustard is to-die-for. I'm a huge mustard aficionado and I would bathe in this stuff.

To round off our dining experience, we ordered a bottle of wine. It wasn't until we were a half-a-glass in that we noticed it was actually a more expensive bottle, which we had not ordered. Rather than just offering us the price difference--which would have been totally satisfactory to us--they  apologized profusely and comped the whole bottle. It was also quite nice that the self-proclaimed "wine wench" was really on top of filling our glasses--we didn't lift the bottle the entire meal. 

It's clear that Starbelly is really aiming to please in these opening months, and here's hoping it stays that way. I will definitely be back--next time for brunch!
author: Jasmine F.

description:
The layout of Starbelly is lovely, but our meal was pretty awful.  Here's why:

Hostess was curt to the point of being rude.  Server was friendly and knowledgeable!  But, our table was so bright I felt like I was in a spotlight.  I asked the server if she could dim the lights, and she said they would "do that later in the evening," and I swear the lights got BRIGHTER a minute later.  

So, the ambiance didn't work for us, fine.  How about the menu?  Our wine that was essentially unpalatable, and the food we ordered was unimpressive at best: Brussel's sprouts burned on the outside and undercooked on the inside.  No flavor, and I suspect they had parmesan even though we informed our waitress that one of us is lactose-intolerant.  Crab hush puppies fine, but $11 for balls of fried dough with hardly any crab flavor/meat seems excessive.  Mushrooms with croutons and fried egg were exquisite.  Sardines were HUGE and had HUGE bones to match -- not terribly pleasant.  

I bet their pizzas are great, but we won't be back.  I noticed they dimmed the lights on our way out.
author: C. M.

description:
Tonight I tried the "wild mushroom & pulled chicken risotto, roasted onions & thyme".... 
Well to put it kindly - risotto it was not.  There was not alot of it - but what you could find was undercooked and couldn't set as a risotto if it tried.  But then again, it was covered in wild mushroom, pieces of pulled chicken that needed to be cut in quarters and enough roasted onions to be a separate entree.  
Wild mushroom, pulled chicked and roasted onions are staples in almost every dish here - from pizza to salads.  It is just too bad that this combination ended up looking more like soup or goop than something that resembled risotto.
The good news is that it is cheap - but then again you get exactly what you paid for. 
The service, on the other hand was as usual terrific - too bad the "Chef" can't quite get it together.
author: Harold C.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal at Starbelly. Maybe I was impressed because I've been so conditioned to bad meals in the Castro neighborhood, or maybe it was because the food was really tasty at Starbelly? Both are true, but my review is based on the really great food at Starbelly. 

We had a salad, soup, a couple small plates, pizza and dessert. Many of our choices were based on recommendations from the helpful server.  The Starbelly salad coupled with the gazpacho (w/ spicy avocado) was fresh, simple, tasty and perfect for the rare 90 degree SF day.  Both the clams and the mussels were excellent.  The fig, blue cheese, arugula and spanish ham pizza was a tasty disk of crisp perfection. We based our dessert choice on the recommendation from the server and were not disappointed. I wouldn't normally have chosen lavender pot de creme on my own, but it was heavenly. The bill was surprisingly reasonable for the number of items we had. 

I'm not a drinker, but they seemed to have a great selection of beer, wine and newly popular Pim's housemade cocktails. 

Now for the bad, the hostess was disorganized and a bit sour. I'll chalk that up to the fact that the restaurant was new. It took longer than it should have to get our seat, but the bartender was friendly, and the communal bar great for people watching. So it wasn't so bad. 

Overall, highly recommended, especially in the Castro. This place would be very good in the foodie Mission, but in the dining desert that is the Castro, it's an absolute gem.
author: Robert M.

description: Good atmosphere, not too crowded when i went around 5pm on a sat. Corn dogs people lvoed were not so good to me  i took one bite and put it back . Mecheladas helped cure my hangover ...good  tomato soup and blue cheese pizza. I would go back for sure, but its not a new all time fav.
author: Ms. P.

description: I'm from Seattle and came here with a friend and I wish we had one of these in Seattle! The waitress was so friendly and warm- and I love the complimentary sparkling water alternative they had to still water. The decor inside is really fun but the outside enclosed patio was nice and relaxing.
author: Kelly D.

description: Starbelly, you have won me over!  The first time I went here, I was only lukewarm on the food. Since I live a block away, friends have convinced me to come here based on location. I'm glad I came back!  I've now figured out the things I love on the menu: burrata with peas, jalapeno spaghetti and the caesar salad.  I recently came in for brunch and was very happy with my meal.  Overall, I'm glad I gave you more than one chance, and you're now a standard in my rotation.
author: Julie B.

description: Thought that this place had a certain charm, but it turned out to be alot of hype.. had alot of pressure for my last meal before i left for burning man. it was tough to really enjoy my meal because everything took forever: seating greeting and food delivery. i gave this place up points for an adventurous menu; but it did leave me still feeling like my hunger was satisfied after salad appetizer entree and dessert. To be real i found the environment to be a bit pompous.. like yuppies in their element
author: alex m.

description: I love Starbelly!! The pizzas are absolutely delicious and the wine and beer selections are some of the best I've seen in the bay area. I've always had great service every time my partner and I have eaten there, which is often. One of our local favorites!
author: Frank S.

description: Delicious food, a little loud, but if you sit out in the back garden, it's great.
author: Geene R.

description: Not overly impressed. Food was good, but the service was terrible. We waited an hour to get our food (we had ordered about 8 plates to share), and they brought out our entrees before we even had received our order of bread and olive oil or any of the appetizers. Service definitely needed an attitude check - our server was completely unapologetic and then decided to ignore us after we commented we'd been waiting an hour and that our entrees were delivered before we'd even tasted one starter. Probably won't be going back, which is unfortunate because the food was tasty.
author: Annie H.

description:
I was excited to check out Starbelly last Friday.  I live down the block, and my girlfriend and I had both been looking forward to trying it, and finding a great new place to frequent.  Unfortunately, I am not able to write a good review.

Calling Starbelly:
The person taking my reservation was less than helpful.  I was immediately put on hold for 5 minutes even though I made sure to call at an off hour.  Then, after giving them my name, a short easy to pronounce last name, they later repeated it back to me incorrectly.  This is a small thing, but it is a pet-peeve of mine, and shows that the person doesn't really care about their customer.

Service at Starbelly:
The hostess was wonderful and sat us immediately.  That was the end of our good service.  We waited about 15 minutes to see our server.  Somewhere around 10 minutes in, our server sent someone to bring us water, and in the mean time we watched our server taking his time and chatting with another table.  This set the tone for our service.  The rest of the night it was if my girlfriend and I were an annoyance to the server that he had to check in on every 30 minutes.  My girlfriend and I have both waited tables before, so we always treat our servers with the utmost respect.  We didn't have any questions, we had our orders ready, used our "pleases" and "thank yous", we were ordering multiple drinks...service was still terrible.  It was emotionally painful for me to tip less than 20%, but I still regret that I even tipped as much as I did.  I always give servers the benefit of the doubt, but this service was unacceptable.  I do think/hope that we just got "the bad server."  Everyone else we dealt with seemed very nice, and the other servers seemed to be much more friendly.

Food/Drinks:
The drinks were great.  I wish I had just come here to sit at the bar and grab a couple of drinks and appetizers.  The mussels were also amazing.  The chorizo was a great touch and the sauce was by far the best part of our meal.  Unfortunately we had to pay for an order of bread to enjoy it because the mussels only came with one small piece of bread.  We ultimately had to purchase two orders of bread and olive oil even though we didn't want the olive oil and it was wasted.  The fried oysters were okay.  The pizza was adventurous to a fault.  I respect putting lemon on a pizza, and it may have been good if it was subtle, but the lemon was overpowering.  It was all we could taste, and we couldn't finish it.

I wish I had liked Starbelly, but I won't be going back.  The prices weren't bad, but they weren't low enough to deal with terrible service and hit-or-miss food.
author: AJ D.

description: First of all, great service and great wines: they offer tastes even when i'm only getting a glass.  Today the green tea was too strong - few people resize you only use a teaspoon of leaves and brew a fee minutes.  I told Ana, and she brought me a fresh cup - and didn't charge me at all for it.  The food is solid small plates - love scallops and a huge, huge portion of spicy mussels with chorizo.  Only complaint that food tends to be too rich for my tastes.
author: clark f.

description: There was a little bit of a wait - about 30 minutes - but at leas we were able to squeak in without reservations and sat at the bar which was lovely. Lots of happenings and things to watch, which was fun. The food was fantastic and service excellent. I'd definitely go back and recommend it.
author: Carol B.

description:
Sad. And this was a second attempt. The first should have been the last.

Inattentive service. 3 different people bringing food and if we needed to iron something out we had to just request it again. Why do they charge for a 3 1/2" piece of (non-warm, as per menu) baguette. When I requested more, they were going to charge us again. The burrata di stefano was delicious and perhaps worth the $13, but why give us only 3 small pieces of toasted bread. We requested more and it took quite a while.

The frito misto with oysters came with only 2 oysters. 
The local sardines turned out to be ONE sardine.
Chintzy. 

The table next to us finished their bottle of wine when the waiter made the announcement that their dinner would arrive late. He could have at least offered them bread. (Oh wait; he can't do that, for he'd have to charge). When the gentleman at that table got his spaghetti, I could tell he was disappointed at the small portion (It was no "plate"!).

We're pretty sure the bottle of Malbec, Padrillos, Mendoza, Argentina, 2008 gave us a headache.
author: Joe B.

description:
great, casual italian/mexican/californian food from those that brought you beretta.  it's always busy, so don't expect to be sat right away, but once you do sit down you'll thoroughly enjoy yourself. 
Sardines, perfect.
mussels, perfect.
porchetta, perfect (and unexpected flavouring)
Pizza with mushrooms and spanish ham, perfect.

Bon Appetit!
author: Maïa Cybelle C.

description: I'm going to keep this nice and short. The burger is juicy, gazpacho is a solid and the service is a plus. I'm glad asqew is outta there and now pasta pomadoro?? Even better! Now I can actually go to a place near where I WORK and eat good food, cuase if you know me I'm not to faraway. Thanks belly I'll see you soon!
author: Bronson M.

description: Loved the burrata di stephano or something like that. Bread was a bit burnt but they corrected that.
author: Chas B.

description: When I walked in the door the first thing that hit me was the aroma of bacon.  I love bacon and Starbelly's BLT with pesto was just what I needed to fill my belly after a meager breakfast.  The fries are excellent as well.  We sat on the patio on a gloriously sunny afternoon.  Definitely, a pick me up.
author: Alison B V.

description:
What a difference 2 1/2 weeks makes!  It's with mixed emotions that I'm giving Starbelly the new 5 star rating.  On the one hand I had high hopes for the new restaurant in that location, and on the other hand I will probably never be able to eat there again if it becomes as busy as it deserves to be.
They have a great selection of beers, I had the Le Merle Saison Belgian style California beer with my meal.
I started off with wonderful fried salted padron peppers.
For the main course I had the Banh Mi style Porchetta sandwich.  It looked like a white fat sandwich, but tasted like heaven in a french roll.  It was served with a pork jus dipping sauce, and perfect pomme frites fries with a sweet spicy ketchup.
The dessert may have been the best dessert I've ever had.  It was certainly the best one I can remember.  Rich Chocolate doughnut with Creme Chesse Ice cream and aleppo pepper flakes.
The service was great also, though a little laid back.  If you are in a hurry you should probably let them know.
Starbelly is now the best restaurant within a one mile radius of Castro and Market.
author: Michael D.

description: Beretta does SF's restaurant scene proud again. We had a ton of food (pate, fries with dipping sauces, pizza, broccoli) and every single item was exceptionally good for the fairly low prices. I loved the beers on tap also. Only drawback is the typically long wait, but if you're willing to grab a drink and go with the flow this place is definitely worth it.
author: Shoshana D.

description: The food is pretty good. We had a variety of appetizers and although nothing really stood out or seemed too different from a lot of other places with similar menus, it was a good meal. Can't say I'd go running back, but I wouldn't be opposed to giving it another try. Knowledgeable, nice, and efficient servers. Good wine choices.
author: Amarar S.

description: Food is consistently delish, been there at few times now for dinner. Can be very noisy, so if you want a romantic or intimate dinner this is not the place to go. It has a very vibin kinda feel. Some MUST haves is the Chicken Pate, and the Scallops, FANTASTIC! The pizza was good, I prefer Beretta's pizza.  They do allow walk-in although expect to wait a little...
author: Jackie L.

description:
Thought we'd try this place on a whim having never read any reviews and left oh, quite satisfied.  Think comfort food in xl sample sizes at affordable prices in a hip atmosphere...
We ordered all the appetizers, although they ran out of the oysters & mussels which was disappointing, but they were all generally good.  Cheese & Salumi platter were great for sharing and the olives & fries ruled. If you've never had a double IPA or a Diablito, these are also worth sampling..The thin crust pizzas were okay, although the competition in the city is fierce, plus I just went to Tomasso's for the first time earlier in the week, so there ya have it.
