Overall, the place is a winner and I wish it was closer to FiDi where I work so I can eat lunch here.  I've gotta come back to try the rest of the menu items.
author: Elena F.

description:
the first week of a new restaurant seems like an unfair time to judge a place, so i will definitely be going back to try it again in a month or so. the chicken liver pate was awesome, though the pickles served with it weren't great. also, it came with 3 tiny slices of bread! totally weird! totally not enough bread unless you were to really lay that pate on thick, and that would be gross. when we asked for more bread they charged us a dollar. dumb. really dumb.
the bean dip was super bland, also with 3 stupid slices of bread. for a bowl of bean puree? really? i don't mean to seem bread obsessed, i actually don't tend to eat much bread. but serving appetizers that need bread as a vehicle for the main event and then skimping on the bread seems really cheap and silly. ok.
the pizza with mushrooms was stellar. the crust was perfect and salty. yum. the padron peppers were good. we got 2 orders.
the octopus was flat out not good. it wasn't hot, it seemed like it was supposed to be crispy and it wasn't.

the drinks on the other hand were great, i love the small pour beer options! and the prosecco we got was affordable and quite good. we sat at the bar and watched a bar back make calimochos with dropper bottles of what i assumed to be hot sauce etc... way to overly precious for my taste. but it was cool that they had that on the menu.

the service seemed overly blase for a new restaurant. like they didn't have to know drink recommendations for the pate, for instance. when i asked for one, i actually got a blank and irritated look. as a longtime restaurant worker myself, this kind of thing really pisses me off.

so, in conclusion: the service was spotty, food ranged between great and not good, and the wine and beers were great.
author: Molly D.

description: Off the beaten path of the Castro with a trendy and casual atmosphere. We sat outside on the back patio and enjoyed lovely outdoors. Serving staff were all kind and very helpful. You could tell they all loved working there. The beverage list was extensive. My husband was very happy with the different beers and I loved the non-alcoholic listings. All the food is locally grown and prepared with care. The salad I had was perfectly dressed with homemade bacon. My only complaint was that I wanted more. My husband had a burger that was outstanding with fries that weren't over-seasoned. Overall one of the best dining experiences I have had in San Francisco. Can't wait to go back!
author: Susannah B.

description: The food at Starbelly was delicious and very reasonable.  The service was friendly and quite quick.  The decor was cool, but the space is a little bit on the loud side.  The only downside was the hostess.  She clearly had no idea what was going on.  Definitely worth going!  Maybe just wait until the hostess gets canned.
author: Garrett H.

description: The meal started out well. Ordered the Mushroom soup and it came out in a decent amount of time. After that things went down hill. Twice we had plates brought to our table that were not what we had ordered. This also happened to quite a few other tables we noticed as we sat and waited for our main course. 35 plus minutes later our main courses out : roast chicken and a pizza. Both tasted very good.,however the wait time was ridiculous. The couple next to us were not happy as well. They got a wrong dish that was supposed to go to someone else and they had to wait and wait.  They were still wating when we left and they came and sat down just after us. Would I go back? Very iffy. The management and kitchen need to get their act together. There are far too many other places to spend my hard earned dollars!!
author: Brian M.

description: Went to Starbelly tonight with my sweetie.  It started off a little strange because when we made the reservation 2 weeks ago, we specifically asked if the food for Valentine's dinner will only be pre-fixe or will we able to choose from an a la carte menu and we were told that they will serve from their a la carte menu.  So when we arrived tonight and were told it will be pre-fix, we protested and, voila, an a la carte menu, dated today's date, mind you, appeared.  So, knowing that we don't need to over-order (the pre-fixe consists of 4 courses), we happily went ahead and ordered a plate of oysters each and I ordered what I thought was a grilled fish dish (Escolar) but was actually a grilled vegetable dish (Escarole).  No matter, the dish was prepared so well, with a perfectly fried egg and pancetta strips on top, that I hardly missed the fish.  We also shared a mushroom pizza that was full of flavors and was a great way to end our meal.  We'd definitely come back!
author: Yvette F.

description: Good food, great beer. I went on a Thursday and we were seated immediately. The space is hip but still inviting. I was a little nervous to try this place since I'm a vegetarian, but they had delicious options and I was not disappointed.
author: Lizzie S.

description: We went to starbellys on Friday evening. We had a reservation for ten people, at 6:30.  J and I were late, and when we arrived by 7, we found that, luckily, the half of our party that arrived on time, was allowed to be seated without us (some places don't). And, we werent the latest people (yay), more came after. I had a strange but good drink, it had tea and egg whites and other stuff, but it was cold, and in a martini glass. It was a cocktail but with tea instead of alcohol. Tasty. We ate family style, and I think almost all of the starters and small plates got ordered. I (and others dining with me) would say that the small plates and apps are the best parts of the menu. The entrees listed were pretty boring and plain looking. I honestly couldn't decide which I wanted, because they all looked rather dull. Fortunately, we all decided to skip the entrees and just nibble. I liked the pate, although it could have used more bread to go with the amount of spreads they gave. The crab puffs were good, as well as the fries (especially the green dipping sauce), and the cheese/pear plate. I really enjoyed the mussles as well, and since J and I were the only ones on our half of the table who liked mussles, we got to eat quite a lot of them. Also ordered, that I did not try, were a cold cuts plate, an olive plate (ick olives) and some large, whole, sardines, which we passed to the other side of the table. To finish, we ordered some pizzas. I had a piece of the pear pizza, which was good, but kind of bland. All of these filled us up pretty well, so we skipped dessert. The restaurant itself was nice looking, and convenient to get to, once I realized where it was, and our waiter was very friendly. They had bottles of water right on the table, so I never had to go thirsty, which is always a major plus for me. I enjoyed my dinner a lot, but although my friend who invited me LOVES this restaurant and comes ALL THE TIME, I think it was just pretty good. I would come again, if someone else suggested it, but probably not venture there again on my own, and when polled, J had the same opinion as mine. I'd say, check it out and see what you think.
author: Merredith L.

description: I love Starbelly! The pizzas are all great, the cheese plate makes for a great starter or dessert and the salads are all fantastic (although on the small side). The staff is friendly and helpful- and the wine list is pretty good too. The only downside is the kind of hard to get to location in the Castro- but its worth the trek over there.
author: Molly W.

description: Great service, excellent food. Especially love the Joe's eggs for brunch!
author: Ben D.

description: O.k., I only had a salad and a taste of the cocktail, but the salad was delicious, the space was wonderful, the wait-staff was awesome (that is a HUGE sell for me... in addition to awesome food)... everything was super-cool. I definitely look forward to going back! I want more!
author: Miriam M.

description: I have never been a "regular" at any restaurant....until now.  My boyfriend and I are in Starbelly at least 2-3/month and sometimes more.  The food is delicious and well-priced.  The drinks are interesting and fresh.  The service staff is incredibly laid back and nice.  They don't hover....they are responsive and helpful...and often make GREAT recommendations.  We were thrilled when Starbelly opened up on this side of town as sometimes I feel we lack good neighborhood restaurants in the 'stro...however..this one is the total exception.  Highly recommend this place!!!  Oh..and in warm weather..the outdoor patio can't be beat!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Food was okay, nothing terribly exciting. The pizza was probably the best thing we ate, and its crust was dry in a bad way.

Drinks were interesting, but for a place trying to sell you on beer, they had pretty brief offerings and were out of about 3 of them.

Service. Oh the service. We had a waiter that I'd had at bacar before and he was delightful there. Here, I don't know what happened. We didn't see him much, had to flag him down a few times (though the food related issues were not his fault) we sat forever waiting for the check and waiting for our cards to be rung up. Non-waiter issues on service were worse, we called before we ventured out there, they told us they opened at 4pm for drinks. We got there at 4:45pm, and were turned away, they weren't open yet. Maybe you should communicate that with the whole staff. We sat down at our table probably around 5:15, and were told by the hostess, "I don't think this will be a problem, but I need this table by 8pm." Honey, if we take more than 2.75 hours to eat pizza and appetizers and drink beers, I'm going to guess it's not due to us, it's due to slow service. Our salumi plate came out with just 2 of the 3 items, we had to ask to get our 3rd item. We ordered the bean puree, it never arrived, but showed up on our bill. Which brings up the huge bone I have to pick with Starbelly's owner/sister resto, Beretta. Not once have we gotten the bill at one of their restaurants, and not had to check the bill against what we got, what we ordered and what we were charged for. CHECK YOU BILL THOROUGHLY WHEN YOU GO TO STARBELLY OR BERETTA. 

The bathroom was nice. That would be the only thing that would bring me back. And too bad about our nice waiter working there, I would have gone back to bacar just for him.
author: Meredith H.

description: I want to love this place...but it falls a little short. prices vers portion sizes/quality are not appropriate. It can be super busy and difficult to get seating on a weekend. However, they make a GREAT drink of Lavender Lemonade wow :)
author: R J.

description: i want to go here today..good food, good price, good atmosphere, nice staff, can be a BAD wait.. but just look down the street at the wait for Ikes place and you feel better..
author: andria p.

description: Got seated right away without reservations. Labor day weekend at that. Service was fantastic, everyone helps everyone. Food was superb, the crusted scallops were so tender yet crunchy mmm! Go with an appetite, order a bunch of small items. Salted carmel pot de creme was my favorite with its rosemary cookies. Will go back for sure. ooh and real coke in glass bottles
author: jessica b.

description:
tasty and good ingredients, pretty friendly service, outdoor patio, pretty good beer list.

went recently and had scallops; avocado-crab gazpacho; three bean salad; and an asparagus-black garlic-hard boiled egg pizza.

the scallops and pizza were both really fantastic, the gazpacho had a lot of good stuff going on, but the smoky flavor was a little overwhelming, the three bean salad had really tasty feta and tomatoes, but kind of boring beans. not pickled, a little undercooked, no flavor. something needs to be done to motivate those beans.

finally, i don't get why places that want to be known for beer put regular old dark beers on the "after dinner beer" menu. an after dinner beer should be high alcohol, sweet, and sold in tiny 4oz pours...
author: Wangston P.

description:
the service was very good, and the apps were all delicious. meat platter, mussels, hush puppies -- all great. 

i don't think starbelly charged us a corkage fee for the wine we brought in -- which was nice. 

however, my entre (pork shoulder) was almost inedible. the garnish was so strong that i couldn't even taste the pork. i just felt like i was eating salsa. the grits and veggies that came with it were fine -- but i was hoping for more. in fairness, my wife loved her burger. 

i will say, their beer selection (as noted in other reviews) is wonderful. 

but at the end of the day, this dinner for me was just OK.
author: Jason P.

description: We dropped in around 3:30pm for a quick bite to find a restaurant barley a 1/4 full. The pessimist in me would say that it was 3/4 empty, which made our server's slight disinterest in our drink order somewhat annoying, but not tragically so. Speaking of drinks, I know this is a touch nit-picky, but I don't understand a beer menu that refers to a "small" and a "large." When I order a "large" beer I am expecting more than a pint. A pint is not  "large," a pint is a pint, so call it a pint and stop playing games. A large beer should be something in the neighborhood of 20oz. The BLT was solid but the fries were soggy and over-seasoned. I like flavorful food but shouldn't be driven to sneeze the second a plate is put in front of me. But alas, I can't base an opinion on the inconsistent fries as much as I would like to. Instead I will base my opinion on the quality of the ceasar salad, which was downright dreamy. In the end the space won me over, my wife enjoyed her food and even though the service was slow, it wasn't exactly unpleasant enough to leave a permanent negative impression. I will definitely give Starbelly another shot.
author: crow s.

description: This place was very busy when we went there on a Tuesday night.  So we ended up sitting at the community table.  This was great.  I ordered the beet salad and a pizza.  Everything was just right.  The decor was my favorite part.  Definately would go back.
author: Andrea H.

description: I coerced my partner to join me to try Starbelly in SF.  It was a bit early for dinner, but I had heard that it had a menu including small plates, lighter fare and different tastes.  Over a glass of wine and a signature 'mocktail' we enjoyed deep fried oysters, asstd cheese plate and steamed drunk mussels with chorizo. Delicious, each dish -- perfectly prepared, portioned and presented.  The staff is informative and make you feel right at home.  I'll be back!
author: D B.

description:
Was excited to try this place after seeing it on SF Station's best of 2009 restaurants (http://www.sfstation.com/best-eats-of-2009-a25431). 

Can't make a reservation, but i love that you can call 45 min ahead of time to put your name on the list. we did that and were able to walk over and get seated right away.

Definitely had some great dishes here, and a couple that were just fine. 
here's what our table got: 
-house cut fries with three dips (thin fries and 2 delicious aiolis + ketchup).
-oven roasted wild mushrooms, levain croutons & sunnyside duck egg which was very good, but somehow not memorable. maybe we gobbled it up too fast. :)
-pan roasted diver scallops, gingered yam puree & pepitas which was really well done! i've had a few cases of bad scallops recently so i was ecstatic to eat these well-cooked scallops and the yam puree went perfectly with the crispy outer layer of the scallops.
-fuyu persimmon & butter leaf lettuce salad, Oregon hazelnuts & raw milk feta. decent - can't go very wrong with sweet nuts and soft, flavorful cheese in a salad. wasn't a standout though.
-starbelly bacon tomato pizza with greek goddess sauce.  big pieces of fatty bacon. good, but I was wishing it was better. esp when we have a lot of great thin crust pizza places in the area like pauline's or little star. 
-salted caramel pot de creme with 2 rosemary cookies. i really liked the mix of flavors, particularly the rosemary in the cookie. the salt crystals on the caramel were a little big, but salted caramel is always tasty.

The service was slow (maybe had more to do with the kitchen/bar).  We got our drinks halfway through the meal after we had forgotten we ordered them and we never got one of the dishes we ordered (roasted beets) . 

I'll probably go back and give them another shot since they're nearby, affordable, and have some good items.
author: Sushmita S.

description: Maybe it was because we were a little taken aback by the less than enthusiastic attitude of the hostess when we arrived....or the screaming babies a couple tables away from us...but i just wanted to like this place more. Very good food in general, especially the pizza, and the oysters. The Gazpacho was a big miss---it just didn't taste good, and texturally it was stringy. Our waitress (from Connecticut) was an absolute treasure...sweet, informed, relaxed...lovely
author: ellis m.

description:
Just went here with a few friends for the first time. We called to put our names on the list an hour in advance, but still had to wait another 30 minutes to get seated (there were 3 of us). Well, I thought a long line probably means good food... 
We ordered a glass of wine while were waiting, and I thought it was a bit pricey at $10/$12 dollars a glass... I mean, this is not a white tablecloth, fancy place... but ok, that's how restaurants make their money. 
When we finally sat down, we ordered the butterlettuce salad with beets and candied walnuts; dungeness crab hush puppies; and the mushroom/onion pizza to share. All of it was OK, not great... the salad was a bit bland, and the hush puppies were a bit gooey, although good with the dip that accompanied it. The pizza was the best item of the three things, but I think I'd still prefer a pizza at the Fly or Little Star. I'd say it was a very average pizza.
I was pleasantly surprised when the check came, it was about $13 each for all of this food (we paid the wine separately), so I guess in the end, the food was worth what we paid for.  The service was good too, so no complaints! 
I may go back again and try other items in the menu, but will probably try a few other restaurants in the neighborhood first....
author: M L.

description: Jalepeno and bacon pizza was delicious, but the star of Starbelly tonight was the Cheddar Grits with kale! Yum. The crab hushpuppies were just okay for us, but overall the food was good. The waitress was sweet. The place was very busy for a Wednesday night too. Their beer menu is very extensive. The only thumbs down was the women across from our communal table. They were not friendly and very rude. We didn't try to befriend them or anything, but for sharing a meal 2-3 feet across from someone, a rude attitude doesn't help anything. I'd still recommend the communal tables. The place was packed and we still got seated as soon as we walked in because we didn't care where we sat.
author: Paul H.

description: decide to come here after i tried Ike's place and ended up not liking them, we sit down to order drinks, i saw spicy tomato juice,stawberry kombacha and lavender lemonade. Feeling adventurous, me and my friend decide to try all those three drinks. The spicy tomato juice made my lips really spicy and taste like salsa. The strawberry kombacha taste good and the lavender lemonade was delicious. The food was not really good but their dessert is superb. I order the rice pudding and the pot de creme. Wow they are delicious. The pot de creme is not too sweet and turn up to be just nice. The rice pudding taste good too,a must try dessert!
author: fourevindo h.

description: for an expensive restaurant with hype, this place is pretty okay.
author: Villager E.

description: I went into Starbelly on New Years day and lets just say, I had a little too much fun the night before. I went in to visit my roommate, drink and eat the good grub I have been hearing so much about. When I walked in I was greeted by a tall woman with short red hair...she was NOT pleasant...AT ALL. I proceeded to tell her I had a group of 7 and she looked me up and down, rolled her eyes, walked away and then came back to tell us they have room, but only on bar stools. Cool, we'll take that. I don't think she was enjoying the fact we were about to stay. Anywho, after we didn't have to deal with that monster bitch anymore we were seated and greeted by our oh so lovely waitress, Calli. She was amazing!! So sweet, joked around with us a bit, served us our drink and food promptly, she was the best waitress EVERRR!! The food was delicious, and although I wanted a bloody mary, I got their Diablo which was pretty much bomb diggity. I will most def be coming back to this place, but hopefully the red head will have a better attitude or not be there :)
author: Yalina P.

description: Everything we ordered was excellent.  Scallops were tender and savory.  Roasted beets mixed well with the cheese, but horseradish was a little over powering.  Rotisserie chicken was filled with flavor
author: Gary D.

description: The burger and fries were excellent - as good as any burger in the city.  The rest of my party enjoyed the meal as well although one of the pizzas was a bit ordinary.
author: Brad A.

description: Service was quick but had an air of hostility toward my slow-chewing friend, so one star knocked down for that.  The crispy smelt were not crispy or salty enough, but I still enjoyed them.  The asparagus-truffle oil-black ginger-egg pizza was excellent.  The salted caramel pot de creme was also excellent, though the accompanying rosemary cornmeal cookie was dull.
author: Sumomo O.

description: Had Starbelly for the first time last night and it definitely won't be the last! The heirloom gazpacho was sweet, salty, and deliciously spicy, the chicken liver pate was awesome and the pizza with chorizo, cilantro and sunny eggs was perfectly balanced. The beer selection is quite a plus as well. Overall a great meal.
author: Josh M.

description: A standing O for how the waitstaff handled our tardy, untidy brunch group. Our yummy fritattas, french toast, pizzas and clam poorboy were served with a patience and friendliness that was almost startling. Good luck, fledgling restaurant!
author: Midori S.

description: A small group of us went there after yapping too long and finally getting out of the house. We were just going to poke our heads in and move on but I'm glad that we were able to get seated. Overall it's a nice place with good food and a friendly staff. The day we were there I believe was their first weekend. They were out of something and you can sense they were a bit in the weeds but as a former waiter there was nothing terrible in our experience. The michelada with mango was mmm different but alright and for charity. My salad with tuna was very delish, a decent sized portion. I love olives so I was happy.  The stringy fries were nice n light n guilt free- the portion was moderate and great to share with others that like to indulge in the occasional somewhat not all that healthy treat. What else? Others at my table ordered vegetarian friendly foods, some drinks and they were all happy. The signature quirky donut was the only thing that was a little out of place. I'm not into that sort of thing and the guy that ordered it wasn't all that pleased either but... it did disappear. So there. The place itself is very sharp. As a new place in a good location it's also great to people watch. I think they will have a patio too. That would be good. I generally don't like shared benches and bar stools. It was a little awkward but we did agree to be seated there. It's worth a visit and I do plan on going back.
author: Lu R.

description: For the price, the food and ambiance is definitely as good as it gets. We went for the 2nd time recently, and the food has improved and is now even more tasty. The pea soup is to die for. The meat appetizer has a rillet that makes it one of our favorites. For the main plates, the roasted porchetta is yummy. You can't go wrong with the signatures pizzas.
author: K K.

description: I've been here two times and the first time I had the Crab Louis which was really good so I thought I would try this place again.  On my second visit my friend and I shared the Pizza Margarita and that was good but my entree the pulled chicken sandwich was just horrible. It was not a barbeque sandwich like a pulled pork sandwich would have been, it was a really gross warm mayonaise based dressing that was described as a radicchio jalapeno slaw.   Yuck and no thank you...  I thnk the word mayo should have been on the menu.  I think this restaurant is a great addition to the Castro but stay away from the pulled chicken sandwich!  Honestly, I think I may have picked the worst sandwich in San Francisco!
author: John V.

description: I've been to Starbelly twice, and both times it was solidly good. The salads and pate are great, the brunch is ok (will improve with time i am sure). Also looking forward to the outdoor seating!
author: Ali C.

description: Had the pleasure of trying out this great "BRAND NEW" 8 day old restaurant today!  Celebrating a galpal's "milestone" birthday, we are of the age where we don't fool around.....we either like it, or leave it and never return!  This is for SURE a "return" venue!  Neat, clean, service WONDERFUL!  Steven was our waiter and could not have been more attentive and pleasant.  He obliged by taking photos of us together with BOTH our cameras.  We had a great selection to chose from, but had the BLT.  It was the bomb!  Fresh tasting, great flavored bacon, FABU bread and we even split the small salad and an order of fries with the 3 spectacular tasting "dips".  We left JUST enough room for a shared dessert, the hot fruit crumble!  We were in heaven!  No one "rushed us out" and let us chat and chew to our hearts content.  The weather was perfect and never even circled the block-got a parking spot right nearby!  All in all, a wonderful place and we can't wait to take our husbands back to treat us to one of their weekend brunches soon!  Nice new addition to the Castro area!  Don't miss this.  All the best luck to them.  Anyone that braves this economy and opens up a restaurant must REALLY love what they are doing!  By the way, we'd just come from seeing "Julia/Julie"......we were STARVED watching all that great food Ms. Child prepared!  She would have loved coming to Starbelly.....even if there WAS no butter, tee hee!  Gotta see the flick to know what we mean!  Bon Appetit!
author: E. Lynn D.

description: Been twice - enjoyed it both times. We've eaten our way through most of the menu by now - hard to find serious fault with any of the food we ate. Prices are very reasonable and the service, although still a little shaky, is genuine and without attitude. Porchetta, pizza, mussels - all big winners - but I would order everything I have had again - except for the chicken. The chicken needs some work - but my guess is that they will figure it out and I will try it again in a few weeks. Loved the attention to detail, prices and choices with the beverage/wine list - really nice. A really nice night out for not a lot of dough - beats anything in this hood hands down.
author: stephanie d.

description:
I have now officially become a Starbelly Stalker. Yes folks, I have dined at Starbelly six times in the scant week that they have been open and every experience has been top-notch. 

The beauty of Starbelly is that it is not striving to be the next in your face, avant-garde, hipper than thou flash in the pan.  The partners Edmondo Sarti, Deborah Blum and Adriano Paganini, Executive Chef Adam Timney, and the entire staff are passionate about creating a comfortable yet sophisticated atmosphere. All of this is delivered with grace at a price point that is shockingly reasonable for an SF eatery.

The interior design is quite brilliant. They did not rely upon the use of the same tired formulas used throughout SF's culinary scene that other restaurants try to pass off as hip and original even though it really is just so ten years ago. You know the style... enormous pivoting steel doors, uncomfortable seating, statement light fixtures, and pseudo-green touches. Starbelly's style, on the other hand, is chic, comfortable, and truly green. Anything salvageable left behind by the former restaurant was repurposed and or reused. Walls and patio are clad in reclaimed lumber of various shades, species, and sizes. Lighting is simple, yet stylish, recycled cardboard or glass pendants. The bar, which transitions into the communal table, was created from a repurposed bowling lane - totally fun! One of my favorite touches is the bar's surround which is a stroke of genius created from the icky old Askew table tops which have been chopped to size, applied in a staggered pattern and stained a flat black creating a very cool texture.  I cannot wait to be able to sit outside on the gorgeous deck and dine surrounded by those lush vegetable/herb boxes which were planted by the Chef himself who I hear is an avid gardener.

The opening events were spectacular. The servers and busboys were all amazingly cheerful and attentive. The food was beyond scrummy.  The comments overheard from fellow attendees were astoundingly positive. Everyone was clamoring over the food, which was lip-smacking and abundant. The kitchen staff was sharp and service was so good that many people could not believe that it was a brand new restaurant yet to open. Several attendees immediately proclaimed their love and desire to marry or otherwise steal Chef Timney. (One of these proclamations came from a couple that had been sent to crash a tasting dinner by a food-writer friend of theirs.) While kinks in the sound-system early in the week did cause the music to be party-atmosphere loud, (can you blame them for being excited?) the bugs seem to have been worked out and at my last meal was at a quite pleasurable sound level.

Because I have had a variety of out-of-town visitors of all ages (4yrs-60+) this week I have returned multiple times since the opening. I chose to bring them to Starbelly because the menu really has something for everyone. The list of farms showcased on the Starbelly website is a true testimony to Chef Timney 's passion for showcasing the purity of his ingredients which shine throughout. 

I have tasted much of the menu so far and have loved every bite. To highlight:

* Brunch: We had sourdough pancakes, French toast, Greek yogurt with granola and market fresh fruit, and the fried egg sandwich. All were awfully delectable as were the Calimocho and French-pressed coffee. 
* House-made Mini Corndogs: D-licious!! Tender and juicy homemade hotdog bites dipped in a fabulously fluffy batter. These are a big crowd-pleaser and the reason for my return visit tonight. 
* Muscles w/Chorizo (Mmmmm...chorizoooo) | Octopus | Scallops: As with all of the seafood on the menu, these luscious dishes were treated with the care and respect needed to properly cook them. They were divine.
* Leaf-lettuce Salads: While these are admittedly more simplistic than the trendy mixed and micro green salads that dot the city, they are utterly refreshing.
* Pizzas: Starbelly pizzas how do I love thee? Let me count the ways. Queen Margherita would have been quite proud of her namesake. The tomato sauce on this and the other tomato-based pizzas was beautiful and delicate and brought me back to Italy in one bite. Figgy pie...better with or without ham I cannot decide. I just must eat it both ways over and over and over until I can determine a winner. 
* Prather Ranch Burger: Simply the best burger in ages! Chef Adam's catsup & mustard recipes are so tasty as are his other sauces. 
* Lamb cheeks: Really make me want to traipse through the countryside pinching little lambies. These are succulent and tender and not overly seasoned which would obscure the delicate flavor of cheek meat.
* Desserts: LEAVE ROOM. It seems as though the non-traditional ingredients in the desserts are confusing to some diners. I wish that I could stamp the menus with "Shut up. Don't think. Just eat. You will say, 'YUM'!!"
Okay, I have gone on long enough. Explore the rest on your own. See you at Starbelly!
author: CJ S.

description: Starbelly has done a great job making very simple dishes VERY tasty.  Honestly who talks about a Caesar Salad on Yelp but theirs is worth mention (and it includes avocado :)), as are the roasted peppers.  We sat at the communal table from which you have a great view of the kitchen AND the gorgeous woodwork throughout the dinning room.  The whole experience was quite enjoyable.
author: Krista M.

description: What a great addition to the Castro !!! Had lunch there today and the experience was so positive from the front of the house through to paying the check. The menu is innovative and inviting.....so hard to choose. The only reason I might take back 1/2 star is due to the dessert menu. A bit limited if one doesn't happen to like the mix of sweet and savory. I don't live in or near the neighborhood, but I'll definitely return.
author: Jeri P.

description: Every now and then, Starbelly hits one out of the park. The menu is ambitious and occasionally well-executed. More often, not. The issues that others have reported here with slow, incompetent service have been consistently true for me, too. One problem seems to be dispatch from the ktichen. Dishes come out of the kitchen and they go randomly to tables. Courses come out of order. Things you didn't order show up. Stuff you order never shows up. Soups come without spoons. My most memorable visit was when my soup came without a spoon. I sat with my soup for a while, then I finally saw my server and asked her for a spoon. I watched her pick up a spoon by the bowl (i.e., the eating end) with her bare hand and offer it to me. The fact that it was a teaspoon and not a soup spoon just added insult to injury. I don't know how they make hiring decisions for wait staff, but hiring is obviously not based on skill or experience. Wait staff don't know the food and they don't know food safety, and nobody at Starbelly seems to know or care about what they don't know. I live a block from this place and I never go there anymore. You shouldn't either.
author: Paul Q.

description: geeeeez! Man - it take something to impress me. But wow - its rare that you find a place that is as good as it wants to be. However be warned - Starbelly exceeds expectations. We were a little down as our party of 8 couldnt make a reservation - however we put our name down for the "communal table" which turned out to be even better. So lets get to the important stuff - the Alcohol - in our party of 8 we covered all sins - white/red wine and the full spectrum of beer. while we waited for food to arrive (pleasently fast!) we all big up'd our drinks choice - personally I was knocking back the 1554 and the anchor bock beer - just too good. Food was FANTASTIC - seriously, Im a BBQ-a-holic and make my own gourmet burgers from scratch so I know a good burger and I have to say Starbelly gave me my best burger in san francisco since i moved here 2.5 years ago - I want another one asap - the pizzas that our group ordered were great too. This place is a gem, congrats to the owners and staff - 8 of us left v happy and texting our friends about the new must go to place! Long live starbelly - thank you!
author: Stuart g.

description: Fun, hip, and very fresh food items! Beer and wine menu is exquisite with many local vendors but not limited to local. Started off with the Salumi appetizer. Wow! Never thought I'd like lonza salami but it was deeeelicious! All the salumis, pickles and assorted condiments were smooth and tasty! We shared the apple and celery root salad which made you forget that you had no actual greens.  Shared 2 diverse pizzas, the bacon, jalapeno & arugula as well as the market mushrooms with gruyere with roasted onions. Both are on the thinnest crust imaginable (the kind I love) and both had nothing but the freshest and tastiest ingredients. It will make you stay clear of thick crust, nasty, old & stale, childhood-type pizzas.  One of our friends got the hamburger made with Prather beef and the absolutely wonderful Pt. Reyes blue cheese. While it was good, it wasn't great. I think our pizzas made him jealous and he had to say it was a good burger no matter what!  Ending it all with the rice pudding was divine.....even if you're not a rice pudding fan, you will love this version with the sweetest (but sour) cherries and hazlenuts that just stand out amongst the melt in your mouth pudding.  Ambience is fun but a little loud. It is difficult to hear across the table but for such great food, it's worth the need to lean in a little to hear your friends. There are two bathrooms here but it took us a minute to realize it. While there is a very obvious one within a hallway and a unisex door sign, there is another one behind a very large drapery at the back of the restaurant.
author: P G.

description: A good friend brought my husband and I to Starbelly last night, 3-13-10. The atmosphere is good, cozy, inviting. Small plates, emphasize on pork. Service was great. Our server knew the menu well and even more important knew the wines. We went with the very reasonably priced rioja, her recommendation, and we loved it. We shared the asparagus, black garlic, and egg pizza, which was very nice. The boys shared the skirt steak and spaghetti with bacon and jalapenos- delicious by all accounts. They wolfed it down. Friend and hubby are omnivores and I'm not. Hubby and I shared the crab cakes (balls), which were good but nothing to write home about. To complete the meal we ordered the beets. Beware the horseradish! They were cooked perfectly and served with a nice soft mild goat cheese, in addition to the horseradish. My first few bites were full of horseradish and it nearly blew my head off. BTW, I love wasabi / sushi, so I am no stranger to horseradish- not to mention it is a favorite condiment of my people. The best dish of the evening was the desert. Lillet soaked cherries in rice pudding with hazelnuts. It was divine. I'd give Starbelly another shot for sure. Definitely fit for a foodie.
author: Anastasia C.

description: Went here last night. Made reservations, but still had to wait 45 minutes. The crab hush puppies should be called "crab flavored hush puppies.  And two scallops for $11 is not worth it. They were good, but a rip off. Pizzas were fine, but nothing to write home about - we had the blue cheese and arugula and the mushroom one. I prefered the mushroom one. The side of beets arrived with a warning that the dish was really, really hot, but the beets themselves were luke warm and tasted a little musty. The two sardines we got did not taste fresh. The cheese grits with greens were good, the grilled little gem lettuce salad was good. The wine was good. But I must say value for money - this place was just not worth it. It was also extremely loud. Maybe outside brunch is what they do best, because I don't understand how this is getting so many rave reviews. I guess there's not a lot to compare it to in the Castro.
author: Lucie F.

description: Went here late on a weeknight after hitting Truck for a drink.  The hostess tried to seat us at the communal table in seats that were already taken.  It was a bit awkward.  They walked us back to the front and asked us to wait.  And it took awhile for them to clear and clean a table that had been empty since we walked in.  The server was sweet and attentive and made great suggestions.  We tried the corn-dogs first.  Lots of hype.  I suspect because of the fond childhood memories.  But without yellow mustard what good is a corn dog?  Then the hazlenut salad, which was fresh and had a good dressing.  Enjoyed the tomato soup with cheese toast, and the gazpacho  with chunks of avocado.  Didn't care for the grits, although I'm generally a big grits fan.  We had the pork as our main dish and after each taking a bite asked them to take it away.  It was tough and looked like a giant anatomical model of a penis sliced lengthwise.   Asked the waitress to take it away because the smell was becoming unpleasant.  So a mixed bag all the way around.
author: The P.

description: This place is great!  Starbelly completely blew me away!  I have to admit I was a little "iffy" about the name at first, but after eating here, it's now my new San Francisco favorite!  The ambiance is upscale casual and hip, yet very comfortable and down to earth.  It has just enough noise to feel alive and happening, but not overpowering in any way.  The food is amazing!  Everything from appetizers to dessert was great - nothing skipped a beat!  We were a big group and tried many things...I especially loved the little gems salad, french fries and spicy pizza!  I will NEVER forget the chicken - anyone who comes to this restaurant MUST order that dish!  Wine list is well priced and pretty diverse.  The service was warm, welcoming and friendly and went out of their way to accomodate us.  It's even located in a convenient, easy to find spot!  (This is important for out-of-towners...)  I'd recommend Starbelly to everyone I know!
author: kimberly s.

description: I was excited to see that the owner of Pesche, Antica Trattoria, and Baretta , three of my favorite Italian restaurants, had converted Asque into an attractive new alternative in the Castro. Our party of 3 stopped in at 7:00 on a Saturday to put our name on the list while we had a drink across the street for the estimated 45 minute wait. After 45 minutes turned into 2 hours and we were finally seated. The hostess offered us two complementary appetizers to make up for the awful wait and things were looking up. By 9:00 the place had been packed for several hours and several choices were no longer available so our entire party ended up ordering the porchetta a dish that I'm often eaten in Italian markets, where it's usually served on a panino. I lived in Italy for over 6 years and this is not a dish that is often found in restaurants; possibly because it is difficult to present in an attractive way . Starbelly's version of porchetta was a center cut so large that it covered the plate. The sauces slathered on the meat were quite tasty ; but, the serving was so large that throughout the meal, my plate resembled a biology project gone amuck. In the dim light it was also difficult to distinguish between the tasty white lean pork and the white glutinous fat that surrounded the lean meat. This added up to inevitable mistakes and awkward dining moments. The dish was tasty; but, it's really not restaurant food.--more pork belly than Starbelly. If Starbelly would open up a booth at the Castro Wednesday market and sell this on a roll, I'd be the first in line. But, as presented it didn't work. I usually don't rush back to restaurants where I've been kept waiting for 2 hours; but, Starbelly is so appealing that I'm sure that in time I'll give it another try for a late lunch when the crush has subsided. The rest or the menu was appealing and if their pizza is as good as Baretta and if they'll add Pesche's warm octopus and potato salad to the menu, I'll be your biggest fan; but, the Porchetta was Misery on a plate to eat.
author: Rick F.
